column31: The Fijian Ministry of Health and Medical Services is currently investigating two Fijian citizens for novel coronavirus after their arrival into Fiji on Monday February 3rd from Guangdong in China. Both currently have mild symptoms and are under isolation at Nadi Hospital. Lab samples for confirmatory testing for 2019-nCoV are being sent to the WHO Collaborating Centre reference laboratory in Melbourne Australia. The Ministry’s response teams are also managing close contacts of the patients.

column31: Former Governor General and senior statesman Sir Nathaniel Waena says if there is disagreement on the security treaty with China, there are authorities to deal with it. Sir Waena expressed disappointment on the US and Australia's continuous push into the sovereign affairs of Solomon Islands. He says he is happy that the country has diplomatic ties with China, adding, Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare must, at all cost, protect the sovereignty of this nation. Sir Waena argued that few of the country’s traditional partners view Solomon Islands as “cowboy country” which is not right. “We are a sovereign nation, operating under an independent constitution that gave us our political independence,” he says. Listen to Sir Waena's observation here.

column31: 𝐌𝐚𝐫𝐨𝐯𝐨 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐭𝐮𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐲 𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐬 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫 𝟏𝟔𝟎 𝐟𝐢𝐬𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐛𝐨𝐚𝐭𝐬, 𝐞𝐧𝐠𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐞𝐬𝐤𝐢𝐞𝐬 Marovo Constituency in Western province today handed over 160 fishing boats, engines and eskies to 160 recipients within the four wards in the constituency. This is part of the Marovo Constituency Fishing Project. Recipients received and installed their engines in preparation for a signing of the Terms of Agreement between the recipients and the constituency office later tonight. The handing over ceremony took place at Doku Dola Boat Building site. The official launch of the Marovo Fisheries Project will launch together with the Handing over of the Gasini Market House tomorrow at Gasini Village. The project is funded by the National Government and Peoples Republic of China (PRC) through the Ministry of Rural Development. Supervising Minister for Rural Development Hon Rollen Seleso, Member of Parliament for Marovo Constituency Hon. Chachabule Amoi, Minister of Commerce, Immigration, Labour and Industry, Frederick Kologeto, Minister of National Planning and Aid Coordination, Rex Ramofafia, PRC Ambassador to Solomon Islands His Excellency Li Ming and other government dignitaries attended the event. 𝘉𝘺 𝘚𝘪𝘮𝘰𝘯 𝘛𝘢𝘷𝘢𝘬𝘦 𝘐𝘯 𝘔𝘢𝘳𝘰𝘷𝘰, 𝘞𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘳𝘯 𝘗𝘳𝘰𝘷𝘪𝘯𝘤𝘦

column31: TAIWAN WARNS SOLOMON ISLANDS OF DEBT TRAP Taiwan's visiting Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Dr. Szu Shein Hsu has expressed grave concerns over the China debt trap issue for Solomon Islands. Dr. Hsu revealed in a media conference yesterday, reports had it that China wants to offer the Solomon Islands Government a 500-million US dollars loan to finance the country's infrastructure needs. But with Solomon Islands facing a weak fiscal status, Dr. Hsu expressed concerns over how it will repay such an amount for years. "While your country is going slowly or going down with the fiscal income and you have people proposing stepping into making another huge loan, how much was that, I heard there is a saying that the Chinese government would like to provide 500-million US dollars for our infrastructure project. How is Solomon Islands going to pay for that debt, unless your government come up with a reasonable plan even through multiple years, but you need a plan, how to pay for that debt in the long run. You have to understand there are countries in this region that have stepped into so to speak, that trap". Meanwhile, the Taiwanese Foreign Minister said pushing oneself into the debt trap when alternatives are available is senseless. "Also I understand that your Central Bank has also come up with a report that has not being taken into consideration saying that your country is no longer able to afford more loan, more debt. I think that's very very important so this is something that I would like to bring to your attention and I think alternatively other countries like the U.S. Australia, New Zealand and Taiwan, Japan, we have come to Solomon Islands, come up with ideas of helping you to develop infrastructure in the long run without putting you into a debt trap and that's a visible alternative path. Why don't we consider that? SIBC News understands, Dr. Szu Shein Hsu's visit was the last attempt by Taiwan to salvage the 36 years of friendship being severed by the Government of Solomon Islands.

column31: IN late 2019, Solomon Ports decided to buy a mobile X-Ray machine, not because every other regional ports has got one but because it would greatly assist in clearing in-bound overseas cargo. The $16 million machine was built by ‘Nuctech Company’ of China. It uses the state of the art imaging technology to analyse contents of containers as well as vehicles and is one of the most sophisticated mobile container scanner models available in the market. Shortly after it was commissioned by Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare on 10th February 2020, Solomon Ports was advised to handover the machine to the Customs Division of the Ministry of Finance and Treasury. Today, this state of the art machine is gathering dust at the Point Cruz Wharf because Customs appears to have refused to use it, according to Solomon Ports’ Chief Executive Officer, Eranda Kotelawala.
column35: $16M X-RAY MACHINE GATHERING DUST

column31: 𝐂𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐚 𝐀𝐧𝐧𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐜𝐞𝐬 𝐔𝐫𝐠𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐀𝐧𝐭𝐢-𝐂𝐎𝐕𝐈𝐃 𝐀𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐒𝐈 The People's Republic of China will provide urgent assistance to the government and people of Solomon Islands following the increase of COVID-19 cases in the country. A statement from the Chinese Embassy in Honiara confirms, the first shipment of assistance will include, a humanitarian funding of 2-million-560-thousand Solomon dollars and 50-thousand doses of SinoPharm vaccine. Others are, Personal Protective Equipments (PPEs), more than 51-thousand packs of disposal syringe, 20-thousand rapid antigen test kits and 50 units of 5 by 6 meter tent kits for the Field Hospital's makeshift buildings. The Embassy assures that the urgent medical supplies will arrive next week in a Chinese government cargo flight. It says, the Chinese government and people share empathy with the government and people of Solomon Islands for the recent surge of COVID-19 cases in Solomon Islands. It adds, after first daily announcement of newly confirmed cases by Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare, the Chinese Embassy in Honiara discussed anti-Covid 19 aid supplies with officials of the Office of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Ministry of Health and Medical Services and Ministry of Foreign Affairs and External Trade. China stands firmly with Solomon Islands in its fight against the pandemic and in the past years and has provided hundreds of thousands of PPEs, helped build the first PCR laboratory, established the first isolation ward at the National Referral Hospital, and shared China’s knowhow. At this difficult time, China is sympathetic with those affected people and their families and will provide urgent assistance to the government and people of Solomon Islands to help contain the spread of virus. ENDS///

column31: 𝐒𝐨𝐥𝐨𝐦𝐨𝐧 𝐈𝐬𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐬 𝐛𝐫𝐨𝐚𝐝𝐞𝐧 𝐒𝐞𝐜𝐮𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐂𝐨𝐨𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐭𝐧𝐞𝐫𝐬 Solomon Islands is working to broaden its security and development cooperation with more countries. The approach taken by the country is in line with its 2020 National Security Strategy and the Country’s Foreign Policy of “Friends to all, enemies to none”. The Government recognize the state’s responsibility of protecting its people from fear and to live in dignity. Broadening partnerships is needed to improve the quality of lives of our people and address soft and hard security threats facing the country. The government is expanding the country’s security arrangement with more countries. The proposed security arrangements have a development dimension to it, covering humanitarian needs of the country besides maintaining the rule of law. Solomon Islands values its 2017 Security Agreement with Australia, it is the country’s first Security Agreement. In diversifying the country’s security partnership including with China, the Government is working to sign off and implement a number of development frameworks with China to further create a secure and safe environment for local and foreign investments including Civil Aviation Services Agreement with China, Expanding Trade under Non Reciprocal Trading arrangement with China and sending more students to China for tertiary education in addition to those that left our shores this week. Read More➡ https://www.sibconline.com.sb/solomon-islands-broaden-security-cooperation-with-more-partners/

In an exclusive Zoom interview with SIBC News from Beijing, HE Fugui said his Beijing Office will negotiate for more Covid-19 vaccines. He said this is his current top priority. He has signed 50,000 sinopharm vaccines in the past week. “I will ask China for all the support the country currently needs at the moment, whether it is a mobile morgue, mobile clinic, mobile hospital, test kits - all these things,” HE Fugui said. He calls on the Ministry of Health and Medical Services and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to throw in their full support. Listen to H.E Fugui’s interview here.

column31: THE news of the Baegu region of Malaita’s move in accepting China as a foreign investment has caught many Malaitans by surprise, Friday. Solomon Star was told that Member of Provincial Assembly (MPA) for Ward 11, Elijah Asilaua is behind the move. In Auki, Premier Suidani was not a happy man. Suidani said this move to bring in any China-led development on Malaita is a ‘big no’ citing the Auki Communiqué as a document that blocks China from his province. “The stand against China-funded development in Malaita Province was a decision made by the Full Malaita Assembly,” Mr Suidani said. He explained that when the MARA government came into power in 2019, all 33 Ward members signed the Auki Communiqué which disapproves any China-funded development on Malaita Province. The Premier said the Ward 11 MPA also signed the Auki Communiqué.
column35: ‘COMMUNIQUÉ BLOCKS CHINA’

column31: MANY Chinese individuals and families have lost everything and are also homeless following the widespread looting and burning of shops and properties last week. This was the statement of Solomon Islands Chinese Association (SICA) this evening (Sunday 28th November 2021) as it condemns the unlawful events which had endangered many innocent lives since Wednesday last week. “SICA condemns, in the strongest possible terms, the senseless widespread looting and burning of shops and properties that have endangered the lives of many innocent individuals and families, including the indigenous Solomon Islanders. “Many Chinese individuals and families have lost literally everything and are also homeless,” SICA said. The association said indigenous Solomon Islanders will also be heavily affected through loss of employment, and lack of timely supplies for their businesses and canteens. “The majority of Solomon Islanders are friendly, caring, easy-going and peaceful people. “The criminals who loot and burn are but a very small minority of the country’s population,” the statement said. The association on behalf of the Chinese community then thanked the many peace-loving Solomon Islanders who have offered their support and sympathy during this difficult time. “The bravery of the RSIPF, PRT, securities, Chinese individuals and friends of the Chinese community are recognized and acknowledged. “These organisations and individuals risked their lives to protect other community members and properties from criminals, and SICA will forever be grateful for their help,” the statement said. SICA also thanked the Government for their continuous support in helping to rebuild businesses and support the Solomon Islands’ economy and also the governments of Australia and Papua New Guinea. “The support from the governments of Australia and Papua New Guinea in assisting the RSIPF to stabilise the situation and provide security is deeply appreciated,” SICA said. The association encouraged all Chinese owned and operated businesses to continue operating in an ethical and fair manner; respecting and abiding by the laws of the country. SICA said SICA and the Chinese community are confident that no matter how difficult or long it will take, they are looking forward to a brighter Solomon Islands. Meanwhile, Chung Wah School which is located inside China Town has announced that the school will close on Monday 29th November 2021 until further notice.

Speaking exclusively to SIBC News in a recent interview, Solomon Islands Ambassador to PRC His Excellency John Moffat Fugui outlines the business opportunities. These are in the areas of Tourism, Fisheries, Agriculture and Forestry products, Information Technology, Timber products and round logs as well as sister-relations between Solomon Islands provinces and provinces in China. Ongoing negotiations also include education exchange between Solomon Islands and China as well as on establishing a Chinese Bank, or a branch of it, in Solomon Islands. On the direct flight arrangement, the country’s first diplomat to China said his office is working on a direct flight arrangement from Honiara to China – in particular, Guangzhou. Read More➡ https://www.sibconline.com.sb/solomon-islands-embassy-in-beijing-negotiates-diverse-business-opportunities-with-prc/

column31: Solomon Islands academic and Associate Professor at the University of Hawaii at Manoa - Center for Pacific Islands Studies, Dr Tarcisius Tara Kabutaulaka takes a comparative and comprehensive analytical look at the Solomon Islands Security Treaty with China. Among other things he touched on, Dr Kabutaulaka talks on the Peoples Republic of China's partnership and security apparatus in other countries, and draws on how they use this to extend the arm of the Chinese state beyond China and into the territories in other countries. “What raises the issue of concern in the situation in Solomon Islands is, whilst we argue that Solomon Islands has sovereign right to sign any agreement, by doing that, we are undermining our sovereignty by allowing a government of a different country to do things that we are supposed to be sovereignly responsible for,” he says. Dr Kabutaulaka was speaking to Sharon Nanau of SIBC News & Current Affairs in an exclusive interview recently. Listen to the full interview (in pidjin) here⤵️

column31: Fijian-born United Kingdom rugby league star Siva Naulago was denied watching weekly rugby club games while growing up. Every Saturday when villagers go to watch the Ravoravo rugby team play in the Nadi Rugby Union’s club competition, Siva and his elder brother Kini would be out weeding in their cassava farm. Couple of times, they would accompany their cousins to watch the club games but their dad, Jona Saturu Naulago, would chase them home. Naulago, 59, who works for Fiji Airport Limited yesterday told SUNsports that he was proud of his son’s success.

column31: The Australian Government, Peoples Republic of China (PRC) and the Solomon Islands Ports Authority (SIPA) have stepped in to provide food supplies that will be distributed to identified families within the Honiara Emergency Zone during the lockdown period. A statement from the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock (MAL) today (Thursday 27th January) said the donation was received by the Livelihood Sector Committee (LSC) on Wednesday at the MAL Headquarters in Honiara. Australia’s assistance include 22,000 x 20kg Rice, and 7000 carton canned tuna while PRC donated 1000 x 40 pounds bag rice, 200 canned tuna (medium) and 100 canned tuna (baby Taiyo), Solomon Islands Ports Authority (SIPA) gave 15 tonnes of rice (1,488 x 20kg rice) and also supplied six containers for storage. LSC Chairman of the National Disaster Operations Committee (N-DOC) Michael Ho’ota thanked the three parties for their timely support.

column31: FB ban, no answer to people’s frustrations: Suidani “What will the government achieve by banning Facebook from the country? “So many people included myself cannot see any better reasons to ban the world's most popular social network from Solomon Islands,” says Malaita Premier Daniel Suidani as he reacts to the national government’s latest act of leadership. Cabinet reportedly agreed on Monday this week to ban Facebook nationwide. Cabinet says it is a temporary ban in response to the many public criticism against the DCGA government and its ministers since it took office. This ban follows a growing string of unpopular actions Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare’s government has implemented following its embracement of communist China last year. In a statement yesterday, Premier Suidani said, “It should be plain and clear to the national government and the cabinet that complaints seen on Facebook is a reflection of people’s frustration towards the government. “Especially on how the government is running the affairs of the country. It is simple one cannot be his own judge. “Cabinet need not to go to Pluto or to the Moon to see why people say the things they said on social media like Facebook. “People are no longer ignorant of the issues surrounding them and they are frustrated because their concerns have not been listen to. That is the simple truth. “It is not a question of using other media plat forms but rather is the question of how do we ensure we use our responsibilities as leaders in a fairer way to help our people use these platforms more appropriately. “Transparency and accountability that we leaders have talked so much about is a two-way process and that there is no one way traffic in a democratic society. “Do not go into public life and make laws and decisions for your own good or for your own protection as is seen with the banning of Facebook. “Doing this will only lead to further frustrations. You can be guaranteed that going against your people only leads to failures. “It is time the leaders and especially the government learn to listen to our people and address the issues raised and discussed on the many local Facebook pages. “Times have change and the demand for change in leadership attitude and style is real. That is really the call for us leaders of today.”

column31: 𝐂𝐚𝐬𝐤𝐞𝐭 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐒𝐨𝐥𝐨𝐦𝐨𝐧 𝐈𝐬𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐬 𝐀𝐦𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐬𝐚𝐝𝐨𝐫 𝐭𝐨 𝐏𝐑𝐂 𝐚𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐯𝐞𝐬 𝐡𝐨𝐦𝐞 The National Government has formally received the Casket of Solomon Islands Ambassador to the People’s Republic of China (PRC), His Excellency the late John Moffat Fugui yesterday. The body of his Excellency the late Fugui was transported home on a special chartered flight from Beijing. Prime Minister Hon. Manasseh and Madam Sogavare, Deputy Prime Minister, Hon. Manasseh Maelanga, Foreign Minister Hon. Jeremiah Manele, other senior Ministers and the PRC Ambassador to Solomon Islands, His Excellency Li Ming were at the Airport to receive the casket. Speaking at the ceremony to officially receive the casket at the airport tarmac, Prime Minister Hon. Manasseh Sogavare thanked the government and people of PRC for the support and assistance rendered in bringing back the body of our late Ambassador. “I convey my sincere thanks to Ambassador Li Ming and your hardworking staff who have worked tirelessly to ensure all the logistics and transport arrangements are in place,” Prime Minister Sogavare said. The Prime Minister further extended his appreciation to the hardworking staff of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and External Trade and the Solomon Islands Embassy in Beijing for their efforts and commitments over the past days to ensure the repatriation arrangements are smooth and forthcoming. “...I join you all as we grieve the loss of one of our leaders, the late Ambassador John Moffat Fugui, whom our good Lord has called to rest on the 22nd of December 2022 in Beijing. I pray for God’s healing, blessings, comfort and strength to be upon the immediate family and relatives of the late Ambassador.” The Prime Minister, on behalf of the government and people of Solomon Islands also convey through Madam Fugui and children and relatives and extended family members the country’s sincere gratitude for the service that the late Ambassador have rendered to this country throughout all his public service life. “We thank our almighty God for the life of this wonderful man, and pray that the legacy he left for us will continue to be a shining light in our country’s nation building.” Prime Minister Sogavare also formally handed over the body of the late Ambassador to his family and relatives. “...I on behalf of the Government, humbly handover the body of the late Ambassador John Moffat Fugui to you Madam Jennifer Fugui, children, family member and relatives and pray that God’s sympathies will be with us, as we spent these final moments with our father, brother, colleague and good friend.” Handing over the casket to the Solomon Islands Government, the Chinese Ambassador to Solomon Islands, His Excellency Li Ming described the late Ambassador Fugui as a ‘pathfinder’ to the China-Solomon Islands relations. “Ever since he took office as Solomon Islands Ambassador to China in May 2021, Ambassador Fugui earnestly performed his duties and worked diligently to promote in-depth development of our bilateral relations and cooperation in various fields, while continuously paying effort to consolidate the friendship between our two peoples,” Ambassador Li Ming stated. His Excellency Li Ming further stated, the special chartered flight to bring Ambassador Fugui’s body is China’s respect to Solomon Islands. “I think that is also a manifestation of the special friendship between China and Solomon Islands and the profound sentiments between our two peoples.” The official funeral Service of the Late Ambassador will be held at the St. Barnabas Anglican Church tomorrow Thursday 29th December. Ends/// Prime Minister’s Press Secretariat

column31: The first group of students will arrive on the first repatriation flight from the Philippines tomorrow,Tuesday 29 September 2020 at around 5 pm local time. The Solomon Airlines Airbus A320 left Honiara at 10am this morning for Ninoy Aquino International Airport, Manila. A statement from National Disaster Council said, all returning student have completed 3 sets of COVID-19 tests prior to boarding the flight. It said, the returning students will be accommodated at the government managed Quarantine Stations at Guadalcanal Beach Resort and Chengs Building both located in East Honiara. The first Philippine repatriation flight will be the 12th flight the Solomon Airlines will do. Of the 12 flights, 6 were from Brisbane, two from Vila and Nadi, 1 from Auckland, 1 from Guangzhou, China and 1 from Apia, Samoa. Ministry of Health and Medical Services continues to lead the Government’s multi-sectoral approach to stem COVID-19 infiltration on our shores. Meanwhile, Solomon Islands remains COVID-19 free to date and the government remains committed to implementing strict measures to prevent the importation and potential spread of COVID-19 within its borders.

column31: THE People’s Republic of China (PRC) has further injected another SB$172.4M to build the PG2023 modern Games Village at SINU to accommodate athletes and officials during the 2023 Pacific Games. According to the signing agreement sealed on Friday, SINU will be the biggest beneficiary when the National Hosting Authority (NHA) handovers the facilities after the Games. This will allow SINU to accommodate more students in modern accommodation facilities in the near future. Witnessing the signing yesterday was Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare, who described the SINU Dormitory Project as Five Wins. Sogavare said the project will be a win-win for the National Hosting Authority (NHA), SINU, the Tertiary students, the Solomon Islands Government and Peoples Republic of China (PRC). “I refer to this project as the Five Wins, a win for the National Hosting Authority (NHA), a win for SINU, a win for the Tertiary students, a win for the Solomon Islands Government and a win for the People’s Republic of China (PRC). “Thank you the Peoples of China for coming on board and agree to fund this project which will enhance the capacity of the National University of Solomon Islands, transform its image and provide ultra-modern facilities for our students to the level and quality of Hotel accommodation. Read more: https://bit.ly/CHN-AID:=:https://www.solomonstarnews.com/chinas-170m-aid/

column31: Namah calls for closure of ports and bans on flights, Passengers and Cargo out of China Leader of the opposition, Hon. Belden Namah today called for a closure of ports and ban on flights, passengers and cargo out of china until health authorities confirm that the Coronavirus epidemic is containable and that it is not a threat to human lives. Mr Namah said the lack of health facilities and health care professionals everywhere in PNG made it imperative that all are treated as emergencies because the chance for an infection to pass unnoticed among the population is high. “For the Health Minister, Mr Jelta Wong, to give assurances that there are no cases of infection among the population is like saying nobody has the flu”. “How does he know the virus is not here? Has he scanned every traveller into PNG from anyone of our ports of entry in the past week?” “In a situation like this, we have to adopt to a worst case scenario and reduce the alert downwards as health authorities downgrade the threat.” The leader of the opposition said PNG had too many people and business contacts with China, the origin of the virus, and it is most likely the virus could spread here as quickly as it has in Australia. “Just because nobody has been diagnosed with the virus does not mean it is not here or that the danger has passed.” He said. “It is irresponsible for the Minister for Health to give assurances when he is absolutely not in a position to do so. The borders are wide open and lack adequate government capacity for mere routine checks at any time of the year”. “For this reason, I want the border at Wutung closed until further notice. The Indonesians have taken a sensible stance and have increased health and security checks. Since we do not have the capacity to do likewise, we must close the border until further notice.” “I further call on government to close small ports to Chinese traffic and for very stringent measures to be applied at main ports to flights, ship calls, passengers and cargo out of China, regardless of cost. This should be lifted only after the all clear is given”.
column35: Namah Calls For Closure of Ports

column31: FRC CHAIR SAID CABINET'S DECISION "REGRETTABLE" Chair of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Foreign Relations, Hon. Peter Kenilorea Junior has described as "regrettable" the cabinet's decision to establish ties with China. In a statement yesterday, Hon. Kenilorea said this is ignoring the ongoing process that was embarked upon by the Foreign Relations Committee. He said what is more, the decision to switch may not have benefitted from sound analysis. Mr. Kenilorea said decisions to establish and sever diplomatic ties are always going to be a sovereign decision saying, in this case, focus has always been on establishing ties with Beijing as opposed to reviewing or even deepening ties with Taiwan. He said the vote by caucus and cabinet reflected this saying, the leaders have met the deadline set by China to switch before their 70th anniversary. Meanwhile, the FRC Chair said he intends for the committee to complete its work and present its report to Parliament. He said how the government conducts its foreign policy is also part of the terms of reference for the current inquiry so the FRC's findings will still be very relevant even more so, now that a dominant China has entered the national consciousness of Solomon Islands. He adds, there are broader foreign policy issues that still needs to be examined and observed. Hon. Kenilorea said in terms of the vision for a modern democratic Solomon Islands, he feels the country may have missed an opportunity to standout from the rest and perhaps even lower the trend. The FRC Chair maintains, the country will need to quickly learn how to manage relations with China as it is unprepared for the change at this stage. by Rickson Jordan Bau

column31: 𝐗𝐢𝐞 𝐗𝐢𝐞 𝐓𝐀𝐈𝐖𝐀𝐍 𝐏𝐫𝐞𝐦𝐢𝐞𝐫 𝐒𝐮𝐢𝐝𝐚𝐧𝐢 𝐫𝐞𝐜𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐚𝐟𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝐦𝐞𝐝𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐥 𝐭𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭, 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐤𝐬 𝐑𝐎𝐂 𝐓𝐚𝐢𝐰𝐚𝐧 THE Malaita Provincial Premier Daniel Suidani successfully underwent his medical treatment in Taipei, Republic of China (Taiwan). Speaking exclusively to Solomon Star Auki from Taipei, Premier Suidani said he is now feeling well after receiving the much needed medical treatment. Mr Suidani underwent his medical treatment at the National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH), after being flown from Australia towards the end of May. Information gathered stated that Premier Suidani has been ill for a few months with a provisional diagnosis pointing to a probable brain space occupying lesion, following a medical check-up in Honiara. After the medical check-up, local medical doctors referred Suidani for an urgent Head CT/MRI scan diagnosis and treatment overseas. According to medical reports, the Malaita Premier suffered a throbbing headache on the right side of his forehead, supraorbital, parietal, and temporal region. It was reported during his trip to Taiwan that Suidani’s medical case was referred to the Overseas Referral Committee (ORC) of the National Referral Hospital (NRH) in Solomon Islands on 5 March 2021 for assistance, but there was no response. Following the discovery that the Premier needs to go for medical treatment overseas, a GoFundMe account was also created online in mid-February to reach out to friends and supporters overseas through which funds were raised to aid the Premier’s medical trip. In an effort to do private fundraising to support Premier Suidani’s medical case many good hearted Malaitans and friends have given financial support to help the Premier get overseas medical treatment as soon as possible. Through this concerted effort of these friends reaching out to Taiwan, it made it possible for Taiwan to support the diagnosis and treatment. After Taiwan had offered Mr Suidani the lifesaving assistance, he thanked Taiwan for making it possible for him to seek medical treatment in one of the most advanced medical places in the world. Meanwhile, after the successful medical treatment, Premier Suidani again thanked the government of Taiwan for the lifesaving help through its humanitarian assistance. The Malaita Premier also thanked those who helped him in their prayers. “Your prayers have been answered as my health is now improved,” he told this paper. The Malaita Premier is expected to arrive back in the country in the third week of this month ahead of the Malaita Second Appointed day celebration in August next month. By WILSON SAENI Auki News Bureau

column31: RCDF GRANTS PAID Take it or not for Constituency refused assistance from China By Alfred Sasako DEPUTY Prime Minister Manasseh Maelanga is this week expected to tell six Malaitan MPs who refused to accept any financial assistance from China that their Constituency share of the RCDF grants has arrived. But receiving the grants by the MPs comes with a catch. “They must first renounce and remove their names from the Malaita Communiqué in a public statement or they get nothing. This is a government decision, not China’s,” insiders have confirmed to Island Sun. “So the onus is on them. If they want the money it is there, but at the same time they are required to do certain things in order to access it. If they want the money it is there. If they do not want the money, it will be there all the same until they fulfill their part,” Hon Maelanga is expected to tell the MPs. It is understood that China wasted no time in filling the financial vacuum left by Taiwan when it was banished in a decision by the Solomon Islands Government to switch diplomatic relations to China last September. Constituencies that support the Government’s diplomatic move are expected to receive their share of the RCDF grants this week. According to sources Beijing has paid some $55 million or $1.1 million per Constituency into an escrow account in one of the commercial banks in Honiara in recent weeks. For purposes of accountability, the account will be jointly administered by the Solomon Islands Government and the Chinese Embassy in Honiara. The $55 million is equivalent to Taiwan’s annual contribution to the RCDF grants, which it jointly funded with the Solomon Islands Government over the years. Maintaining the RCDF grants for the next three years is one of five projects Beijing has agreed to fund. The others are the National Referral Hospital, the 2023 Pacific Games, the Upgrade of the Honiara Water system and the Upgrade of Solomon Islands National University (SINU) facilities in the capital, Honiara. Inspired by Premier Daniel Suidani, the Communiqué said in part that Constituencies on Malaita would not accept any financial assistance, including the RCDF grants from China. The six MPs, including Opposition Leader and MP for Aoke/Langa Langa, Matthew Wale, Small Malaita MP and former Prime Minister Ricky Houenipwela and other have signed the Communiqué, which also said Malaita would look to the United States of America, Japan and Australia to assist in its development endeavors. Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure Development (MID) Maelanga is believed to have been authorised by Government Caucus to dangle the “carrot” before the six Malaitan MPs and their constituencies. “It will be up to the MPs to decide,” the sources said. Hon Maelanga did not return calls by Island Sun over the weekend.

column31: THE construction phase of the 2023 Pacific Games main stadium had created over 100 job opportunities for locals in various construction areas while injecting more money into the economy over a period of six months. During the same period, the project contractor of the Stadium Project has purchased 1,800 tons of cement and over 20,000 tons of sand and stone from local suppliers. These positive developments were revealed by Chinese Ambassador to Solomon Islands Li Ming during the signing of the Implementation Agreement of the Solomon Islands National University Dormitory Buildings Project between the Solomon Islands National Hosting Authority and the Peoples Republic of China Embassy in Honiara on Friday 12 November. The project when completed will initially house athletes and officials during the 2023 Pacific Games and will be handed over to the Solomon Islands National University (SINU) after the games to accommodate students. The SB$172 million project will build 3 new 4-floor dormitories, one activity hall and one equipment house at the SINU Kukum Campus. When completed, it will provide 216 dormitory rooms, which will accommodate more than 900 students. It will also be equipped with all necessary furniture and sanitary facilities. Read more: https://bit.ly/100plus_:=:https://www.solomonstarnews.com/100-local-jobs-on-offer/

column31: HEAD of the Chinese Embassy Taskforce in Solomon Islands Yao Ming wants the Solomon Islands Government (SIG) to ease the travel restriction to allow their diplomat officials to travel to Solomon Islands. The travel ban was placed by SIG in early February 2020 after the coronavirus (2019-nCov) outbreak in Wuhan, China, towards the end of 2019. Speaking to senior journalists on Wednesday Ming is very worried that this travel restriction has caused a lot of setbacks for them. “We really need our diplomat officials to travel to Honiara so that we can resume official activities with the Solomon Islands Government,” Ming said. When asked if Ming has already spoken to the SIG Officials, he confirmed that he has already met with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and External Trade. “Yes, I have met with the minister and his permanent secretary (PS) and I also met with the responsible officials within the Office of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (OPMC). “In fact I raised our concern with the OPMC Chief of Staff in several occasions to ease the travel ban for our diplomatic officials,” Ming told the journalists. He further stressed that it’s in the best interest of the Solomon Islands to ease the travel ban because if the current status continues the country’s economy will be greatly affected. MORE HERE...http://bit.ly/travl-ban-:=:http://www.solomonstarnews.com/news/national/item/22928-china-wants-travel-ban-reconsidered

column31: #UPDATE: Statement from National Carrier Air Niugini. AIR NIUGINI OFFERS TO UPLIFT STUDENTS IN CHINA FREE OF CHARGE. Air Niugini is offering to uplift Papua New Guinea students studying in China out of Hong Kong airport free of charge(FOC) back to PNG as long as they meet all health and quarantine as well as our government’s requirements to mitigate the corona virus risks. The airline will uplift students studying in any provinces of China, except for those from Wuhan city or Hubei Province. The students must make sure they meet all government requirements and go through full health screening and quarantine checks being carried out at the respective airports in China and Hong Kong. Once all cleared by authorities, they will then be uplifted by Air Niugini at Hong Kong airport free of charge(FOC) back to PNG. Further checks and monitoring will be carried out by our health and quarantine authorities upon arrival here in Port Moresby. The students’ parents are advised to contact Air Niugini Customer Care on the following email address for further information and requirements: wecare20@airniugini.com.pg ends... #airniugini #png #coronavirus #pnghealth

column31: MISS RHIANNON QUAN - NEW BODY BUILDING QUEEN BY PETER ZOLEVEKE II “I was overwhelmed and so happy……I didn’t know what to say!” It took her only five months into the art of muscle building and little did she know that she will become a beacon nationally representing the minority in the sport. Australian born Solomon Islander Rhiannon Quan is the newly crowned Miss Solomon Islands for Bodybuilding flagged by the Solomon Islands National Bodybuilding Federation (SINBBF) during its 2020 national competition last weekend at Pacific Casino Hotel in Honiara. The 22 year old was drawn to bodybuilding to be a better version of her, and she said that's what drove her to keep going with it after her first competition. Born from a well-established prominent family business here in the country, QQQ Wholesale. Rhiannon’s father a Chinese born here in Solomon Islands and her mother part Malaitian and Gilbertese percentage are one of the founding businesses in Honiara since the ’80s till today. She begins her early education at the Woodford International School from kindergarten to Grade 3 before moving to the land down under for further studies. “I usually return home (Solomon Islands) on holidays mostly working with the family’s business,” says Rhiannon. She graduated from Year 12 in Australia and undergoes a year to study Mandarin in Shanghai, China. “After that, I saw that my father needed help with the family business so it prompts me to return home and help him.” It was in August she found interest in going to the gym to take up a new challenge for herself representing the Pacific Flex Gym at the Pacific Casino hotel. “I started to get serious about going to the gym in August this year, I went every day. Since the covid 19 pandemics and having mostly nothing to do I wanted to challenge and push myself in fitness rather than just staying at home” she says. “I began to take my new hobby seriously when I met the SINBBF athletes and they encouraged me to compete. And I also saw that like there are not many females involved so I said to myself I can join and encourage more women and girls to join a male dominated sport.” “And then I met two other ladies who are also apart of SINBBF, they are so nice, we all like talking to each other and that’s when my interest grew." Rhiannon competed and won in the Bikini and Physique category where female athletes get to be identified for the proportion in muscular size with the maximum amount of leanness. “I was just giving a shot at it,” she said. “I was so surprised, I just started but I’m just really happy that I won. And I want to encourage more girls into the sport.” Next for Rhiannon, she wants to continue from what she does and improving it as a role model for others in her gender. “I realized I wanted to own my appearance, my hard-earned muscles, and celebrate them. That belonged to me. I felt good about being a part of a community that applauded and encouraged the work that went into it. “Body Building is an ongoing process, there is always room for improvement, and therefore I want to focus on improving my body more. I’ll be looking forward to next year’s competition to see if I can retain the title. Maybe there’ll be more women and girls to compete in the competition next year so it will be more exciting, something new!” she says. Rhiannon also expresses her excitement to work closely with SINBBF supporting athletes in their preparation build-up towards the 2023 Pacific Games. “I want to get more females aware, that anyone, any girl can do it and by also making history if more females represent the Solomon Islands. I’m hoping to compete and yes with others too. "I'd love to get up on stage again,” she expresses. “No pain no gain, have a strong mind even if you feel down at least you do what you have to do and your hard work will pay off and it will show for everyone to see.” "If you've got the patience and time, it can be a wonderful sport with a large community of people." She’s the second born in her family of having an elder brother who currently on studies overseas.

column31: The Embassy of the People’s Republic of China strongly condemns the recent riot in Honiara, which left China Town and Chinese-owned shops among other areas in ruins, resulting in huge property loss and social panic. Hundreds of Chinese families including elders, kids and women were driven homeless and displaced in distress, it said in a statement issued over the weekend. “There is no any excuse to justify the blatant damage to properties and lives.” The Chinese Embassy extended its sincere sympathies to Chinese community members who were hit hard by looting and destruction. “We are trying the best to provide assistance. The first dispatch of support for homeless Chinese families will arrive shortly,” the statement said. The Embassy said the Chinese community is a member of the family of Solomon Islands. “Since early last century, Chinese people have travelled through vast oceans to Solomon Islands and made long-standing contributions to local development. Their contributions should be remembered and appreciated, not victimized. Read more...

column31: STOP THE DEAL! Australia asks Sogavare not to sign China security treaty BY MAVIS N. PODOKOLO AUSTRALIA yesterday asked Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare not to sign the controversial security treaty he’s negotiating with China. Its Minister for International Development and the Pacific, Zed Seselja, relayed the request when he met Sogavare in Honiara. Seselia flew into Honiara on Tuesday specifically to meet and relay Canberra’s request to Sogavare. “I met Sogavare, his deputy and a number of other ministers,” Seselia said in a statement issued after the meeting. “We have asked Solomon Islands respectfully to consider not signing the agreement and to consult the Pacific family in the spirit of regional openness and transparency, consistent with our region’s security frameworks,” he added. “Australia will always support our Pacific family. “Our view remains firmly that the Pacific family will always meet the security needs of our region. “We are proud that SIAF responded swiftly and effectively to restore calm in Honiara following civil unrest in November 2021, at Solomon Islands’ request, and under the direction of the Royal Solomon Islands Police Force.” It’s not clear last night what Sogavare’s response would be. Foreign Affairs permanent secretary Colin Beck told reporters yesterday government would issue a statement on Seselia’s meeting with Sogavare later. Seselia’s trip here comes ahead of a similar meeting the United States is intending to have with Sogavare later this month. Washington has announced it is dispatching its top Asia official, Kurt Campbell, later this month to Honiara to discuss the China security deal. Although Sogavare had said earlier the proposed security treaty does not cater for the construction of a Chinese military base, the West is not convinced. It’s expected the US will deliver the same message to Sogavare. Meanwhile, Seselia said Canberraa welcomes recent statements from Sogavare that Australia remains Solomon Islands security partner of choice, and his commitment that Solomon Islands will never be used for military bases or other military institutions of foreign powers. “We look forward to ongoing engagement with the Solomon Islands Government, and with our Pacific family members, on these very important issues. “Australia’s commitment to working with Solomon Islands on its security needs is to do so swiftly, transparently and with full respect for its sovereignty. “Australia will continue supporting peace, prosperity, stability and our shared democratic values in Solomon Islands and across the region.”

column31: Choiseul request government to fulfil compensation promise BY BARNABAS MANEBONA CHOISEUL demands the national government to fulfil its promise to compensate them with $3million, after the whole province and its people were being sworn at on social media during the diplomatic switch from Taiwan to China. Deputy Premier of Choiseul Province Hon Nerio Ulemiki said like any other ethnic group in Solomon Islands, they deserve respect as well, and because of the swearing is why they demand for the national government to must compensate them. To this date, Mr Ulemiki said they do not know of what had become of their earlier request, however, they warn that if the national government ignores their demand, they will not take part in any national event which includes reopening their border at the western end. “It seems the National Government has no longer considered our request on the compensation towards swearing made to the Prime Minister and people of Choiseul during the past with regards to the diplomatic switch from Taiwan to China,” said Ulemiki. “We have not received or heard any response to our request. Whether it was considered, we do know. “Because of the swearing is why we people of Choiseul Province gave an earlier demand for the national government to must compensate us because we the people are innocent and such treatment towards us also hurts us. “With three points, if the national government does not meet our demand, the Prime Minister must step down, secondly, in any national event Choiseul Province will not take part to show that we are not happy about this issue. Third, having the borders now closed, with the government not considering our cost, we will not take serious of the border closure, meaning we will only open our border. “These are three points on which the Choiseul Provincial Government will still come out more with on the media. “To this date we do know of what happened to our request so we now demand the national government to fulfil their promise for giving $3million compensation to Choiseul Province. “The Prime Minister and national government have only been quiet on this issue on which this is an important point that we raise for the national government to address.”

column31: AERONAUTICAL ENGINEERING STUDENT WINS DESIGN COMP This is Louis Sivina, who hails from Rigo District in the Central Province. Louis is an Aeronautical Engineering graduate, he studied in China for 6 years and as a student in a foreign country he had to have a side hustle for extra expenses. Being someone who gained an interest in drawing or designing overtime, he decided to use these skills to earn an income. He said, “I needed money so I started off by drawing tattoos and also framing my drawings and selling them.” Louis said, temporary art pieces and traditional tattoos have always been of great interest to him, because of their significant meanings. As a recent winner of the Jack’s of PNG’s design competition, Louis shared his inspiration behind his wining designs. “The inspiration behind my designs are the daily activities that people do, whatever we see, feel, taste and our relationship experiences,” he said. According to this designer, little things inspire how we think. Louis hopes that his designs on these fabrics are comfortable and people feel beautiful in them. His story is a reminder to better your skills and to always do more outside of your field of expertise.

column31: 𝐂𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐚 – 𝐒𝐈 𝐒𝐞𝐜𝐮𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐂𝐨𝐨𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐬 𝐭𝐨 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐧𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐥𝐚𝐰 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐧𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐬: 𝐂𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐞 𝐄𝐦𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐬𝐲 The cooperation in security and other fields between China and Solomon Islands conforms to international law and norms, and is conducive to regional stability and development. This is according to the Chinese Embassy in Solomon Islands, in response to the United State’s warning after their high level delegation's visit to Solomon Islands on Friday. A White House statement released shortly after the visit said, Washington would have “significant concerns and respond accordingly” to any steps to establish a permanent Chinese military presence in Solomon Islands. But the Chinese Embassy in a statement today stated they ‘object to any third party’s intention to interfere with security cooperation between China and Solomon Islands as sovereign states.’ “During its visit to Solomon Islands, the U.S. delegation openly warned the Solomon Islands government over the security cooperation between China and Solomon Islands, which had once again exposed some countries’ condescending acts in disrespect to other nations. “In accordance with the principles of on equal footing, mutual respect and non-interference into each other's internal affairs, the cooperation in security and other fields between China and Solomon Islands conforms to international law and norms and is conducive to regional stability and development,” the statement says. It adds, both China and Solomon Islands have repeatedly emphasized that reports on so-called Chinese military base in Solomon Islands are misinformation fabricated by those people with ulterior motives. “Since the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and Solomon Islands, the exchanges and cooperation between two countries in various fields have yielded fruitful results and been warmly welcomed by two peoples. “Any attempt to inflame the situation, provoke tensions and stir up confrontation in the Pacific Islands region does not serve common interest of regional countries and is doomed to fail,” it says.

column31: 𝐌𝐅𝐀𝐄𝐓 𝐚𝐧𝐧𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐜𝐞𝐬 𝐩𝐚𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐀𝐦𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐬𝐚𝐝𝐨𝐫 𝐅𝐮𝐠𝐮𝐢 𝐢𝐧 𝐁𝐞𝐢𝐣𝐢𝐧𝐠 The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and External Trade (MFAET) announced the passing of Solomon Islands first Ambassador to the People’s Republic of China (PRC), His Excellency the late John Moffat Fugui on Thursday (22 December 2022). The 61-year-old late Ambassador passed away in Beijing after suffering Cardiac Arrest. MFAET is liaising with PRC’s Foreign Affairs Ministry on arrangements to bring the Late Ambassador Fugui home. A condolence book will be made open for signature to the Government and the diplomatic community. The Ministry has described the passing of late Fugui as a loss of an inspirational leader, a person who loved his country and devoted his life to serve. He was also described as a Diplomat with great visions to connect Solomon Islands with the biggest country in the world, PRC. He was also a well-read diplomat who interacted well with youths until his passing. Apart from his recent assignment as a diplomat, the late Fugui was a Member of Parliament from 2010 to 2020. He held a number of Ministerial posts including as Minister of Education and Human Resource Development (MEHRD), Minister of Public Service, Minister of Environment, Conservation & Meteorology, and Disaster Management and as Deputy Speaker of Parliament. He has a Bachelor of Arts in Political Science from the University of Canterbury in New Zealand and a Masters in Politics from the University of Hawaii, Monoa, Honolulu. The Ministry conveys its deep condolences to madam Jennifer Fugui and their four children, may God bless his soul. MFAET PRESS RELEASE

During the medical trip, an MRI test was carried out on the suspected brain space-occupying lesion that was suspected by doctors at the National Referral Hospital (NRH) in Honiara. The NRH doctors then referred the premier to seek further diagnosis overseas on the suspected conditions since there is no CT scan or MRI machines in the country to carry out check and treatment for the Malaita Premier. column31: Lilo warns government not to ‘over-heat’ the economy By EDDIE OSIFELO FORMER Prime Minister Gordon Darcy Lilo is warning the government not to re-heat the economy with the proposed proposal to borrow $800 billion (US$100 billion) loan from foreign donors. Lilo signals the warning after leaked documents show the Minister of Finance and Treasury, Harry Kuma was in discussion for possible loan through middle man or broker Terry Wong in Beijing. According to Australia Broadcasting Cooperation (ABC), in one of the letters Kuma accepts in principle a proposed 11 per cent brokerage fee — amounting to $92 billion SBD (US$11 billion). Solomon Islands has a gross domestic product (GDP) of $10 billion SBD ($US1.3 billion). Lilo, also the former Under Secretary to budget, Permanent secretary and two times Finance minister, said this borrowing will create heavily indebtedness, economy overheating and inflation for the country. He said Solomon Islands has a small population, land issues to invite more investors and structural problems. “You compare $10 billion GDP to $800 billion loan. Is this a realistic amount you need?” he asked. “Remember you are talking about half a million people. “Our domestic capacity to repay it is based on tax which is very small,” he said. Lilo said the action of the government is like putting a six horse power on a barge. “Can you tell me that motor will survive? “When it reaches 50 meters, the whole propeller will smash,” he said. As such, Lilo said when you pour more liquidity in the economy; you are heating up the economy. “Don’t dream about some kind of windfall revenues or treasures to re-heat the economy. “What supply side of the economy will absorb that?” he asked. Lilo said take the $800 billion and amortized it. Amortize is to gradually write off the initial cost of (an asset) over a period. “For example, the repayment period is the minimum of 10 years and maximum of 20 years. “In 20 years, repayment will be $50 billion. If 10 years, it will be $100 billion,” he said. Lilo believed it can result in 56% of GDP on repayment which surpasses the 30% threshold of debt. He said this is just a raw figure. “Ask the CBSI to use IMF format. “If China or USA borrow such amount, they are capable to repay the loan because of their domestic strength,” he said. Lilo is currently awaiting his decision on the Petition case against Member of Parliament for Gizo Kolombangara, Lanelle Tanangada. It is likely to be heard in two weeks’ time. CAPTION: Former PM Gordon Darcy Lilo

column31: Former bilateral partner, Republic of China, Taiwan closed down its embassy in the Solomon Islands as of today. Taiwan President, Tsai Ing-wen issued a statement on the termination of diplomatic relations with the Solomon Islands last night. President Tsai said all technical and medical mission personnel stationed in the country are being recalled immediately. She thanks all Taiwan Government personnel in the country for fighting bravely to save our diplomatic relationship. President Tsai said, it is indeed regrettable that a number of unfinished cooperative projects must come to an end, and it is a loss for Solomon Islands people. She said this is the choice that Solomon Islands' government has made, leaving Taiwan with no other option but to respond in this way. Taiwan strongly condemns the Solomon Islands government's decision to establish diplomatic relations with China. Over the past few years, China has continually used financial and political pressure to suppress Taiwan's international space, said President Tsai. She said, in the face of China's interference and suppression, Taiwan will not stand to be threatened, nor will we be subjected to ceaseless demands. Meanwhile, the Solomon Islands Embassy in Taipei has issued a statement to the Solomon Islands students studying in various universities in Taiwan, calling for a meeting with the executive committee members of the student body tomorrow. His Excellency Joseph Waleanisia said the discussion will be on the implications of the Government decision and what to do next. His Excellency Waleanisia will put out further notice to all students later today after consultations with Honiara and further instructions from ROC's Ministry of Finance. Solomon Islands student studying in Taiwan are shocked at the sudden bilateral switch saying, this decision comes at the expense of their future. The news was a great shock especially to our students who have completed their studies and will be graduating this year. SIBC News understands Taiwan is yet to comment on this.

column31: Huawei-SI talks to build towers here CHINESE tech giant Huawei is in advanced talks with the government to build 200 telecommunication towers around the country. Still in its design stage, this plan, once successful, will enable all Solomon Islanders in the country access to internet services. While the national government is tight lipped about this project, consultations have taken place between different government officials and a Huawei representative in Honiara. The Minister for Communication and Aviation, Peter Shanel Agovaka, confirmed that he had set up a technical team to work with a Huawei representative with the view to advise his Ministry and Cabinet on the matter. Agovaka has been instrumental in pushing forward Solomon Islands fibre-optic backbone, and his vision is to implement a country-wide infrastructure roll out to bring faster broadband to rural areas. “After taking office I embarked on a policy of getting a fibre-optic cable for the country,” the Minister said. “The next phase of my plan is to connect the rural communities with internet and to do so means we must have broadband towers. "The third phase is to have the provinces that have no optic fibre cable connected.” The Minister said that whatever plans the government has, and how it decides to implement such plans is a sovereign decision. Huawei, once removed from a contract in Solomon Islands, is most likely approached by the government to build the 200-telecommunication towers while China is the most likely financier for this project. Details on this project are still sketchy but it is said that the government is keen to pursue this initiative with China. It is understood the 200-telecommunication towers report has not yet reached Cabinet level. Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd is a Chinese multinational technology company and a world-leading telecommunications provider with $USD 109 billion in annual sales. The founder and CEO of Shenzhen-based Huawei, Ren Zhengfei, is a former Chinese military officer. The U.S. government actively discourages U.S. carriers from buying Huawei telecom equipment because of security concerns. Google recently restricted Huawei's access to its Android operating system and apps after the Trump administration blacklisted the firm. Huawei is also banned from bidding or building 5G networks in Britain, France, Germany, and Australia because of similar security concerns. In the Pacific region, Papua New Guinea’s Communications Minister has insisted that his country should not repay a $US53 million loan to China, money that was used to build a national data centre. A report obtained by the Financial Review found that the PNG data centre, designed and built with Huawei equipment, exposed secret government files to being stolen. The report stated that data flows could be easily intercepted without detection. China’s foreign affairs official, Zhao Lijan, in a recent press conference, told theGlobe and Mail that the Ministry is not aware of the report. He insists that the Chinese government requires all Chinese enterprises operating overseas to abide by local laws and regulations. The data centre has not been operational as it quickly fell into disrepair as insufficient money was set aside for operations. The data centre was part of an Integrated Government Information System (IGIS), which planned to link 57 sites in Port Moresby and five regional centres. It was meant to store confidential government information and the entire data archive of the PNG government. By Georgina Kekea

column31: Kenilorea praises Taiwan DEPUTY Opposition Leader Peter Kenilorea has praised Solomon Islands former diplomatic partner, Republic of China (Taiwan) for its success to deal with coronavirus (COVID-19). Speaking in Parliament during the debate on the extension of the public emergency for another four months on Monday, Kenilorea referred to the need to learn from other successful countries that have, so far, kept the covid-19 virus at bay. He said two of these successful countries are Taiwan and Singapore. “They are island nations which make them great models for island countries like Solomon Islands to emulate. “In fact the world can learn from these success stories,” he said. Kenilorea said while much needs to be understood about covid-19, Taiwan continues to lead the world showing how this pandemic could be handled. “Acting early, fast, using technology, and a united people placing trust in their authorities are some of the ingredients for success. “While Solomon Islands may not be receiving any masks or support from Taiwan now, I still stand with pride in the knowledge that our old friends are helping other friends globally, despite their lack of political recognition around the world. “After all, we are all human facing a common global threat. Thank you, Taiwan,” he said. Solomon Islands established diplomatic relations with the Republic of China (Taiwan) from 24 March 1983 with resident diplomatic missions in both respective capitals. However, the 37-year relationship was cut when Solomon Islands shifted to Peoples Republic of China (PRC) on September 16, 2019 to recognise its one China policy.

column31: Nine contractors upgrade KGVI for quarantine site By EDDIE OSIFELO NINE contractors are racing against time to complete the maintenance of all King George Six dormitories to quarantine people arriving on flights. The nine contractors started work on Monday and expected to complete it by today on all nine dormitories including the girls’ hostel. Ministry of Infrastructure Development selected the contractors due to the threat of the coronavirus (COVID-19) which has confirmed cases in neighbouring countries like Fiji and Papua New Guinea. Solomon Islands is still to record a single case since the virus was discovered in Wuhan, Hubei province in China last December. Island Sun visited KGVI yesterday and saw the contractors including men and woman busy painting, removing windows, cleaning the ablution blocks and changing nets of the rooms. LPS Contractor Managing Director Luciano said they worked 24 hours in order to complete the work in time. He said all the work should be complete by today. About $2.3 million was allocated for the maintenance work at KGVI which will be shared among the nine contractors. As such, one contractor should receive about $250,000. There are more than 100 rooms at KGVI which can accommodate up to 200 people for the 14 days quarantine period. MID officers were stationed at KGVI to witness the maintenance to make sure it is completed on time. It is understood KGVI will start hosting incoming passengers by Friday this week. One of the MID officers said KGVI, GBR at Honiara International Airport and Telekom hostel are the three sites for quarantine. Island Sun also visited GBR and found out that people are already been quarantined in the site. Media is not allowed to enter the premise of the GBR. In the meantime, Governor General Sir David Vunagi has declared a State of Emergency yesterday to allow the government to impose rules for citizens to follow during this pandemic situation. CAPTION: Contractors hard at work on one of the KGVI's dormitories.

column31: Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare has acknowledged the contributions made by Hon. Rick Houenipwela as a national leader and senior Cabinet Minister of the Democratic Coalition Government for Advancement. But the Prime Minister said, Hou's actions to betray the principles of Cabinet responsibility, by manipulating the transparent intentions of collectively approved foreign policy objectives as a tool to create political division within the Government and provoke political instability is unacceptable and unbecoming of a National Leader and former Prime Minister. Prime Minister Sogavare said, overwhelming evidence gathered over the past weeks combined with ongoing assessments confirms the ulterior motives and intentions of Hon. Rick Hou and his co-conspirators to destabilize the Coalition. "He Undermine my leadership and provoke social harmony by using the China-Taiwan issue, as a political tool to dismantle the Democratic Coalition Government. This included a million dollar offer to each minister, members of parliament who signed in support for Taiwan. This is to avoid demeaning the status of Taiwan as a long time friend for a narrow political interest of a few." Mr. Sogavare adds, DCGA Leaders who were approached with 1-Million dollars each to betray the Coalition decided not to refer the matter to Police. He thank Hon. Hou for publicly admitting that he was responsible for the release of the unsanctioned media statement on behalf of the 16 Ministers and MPs which Coalition Parties condemned as being in direct breach of Cabinet protocols by taking a stand before any reports were submitted. Mr. Sogavare said, that also included reference to the PM's position on the issue without his consent. Prime Minister Sogavare made this statement to counter Hon. Rick Hou's media comments against him yesterday.

column31: Under a veil of secrecy, China has convinced Vanuatu to enforce Chinese law within its own borders. Six Chinese nationals were arrested, detained without charge on the premises of a Chinese company with numerous large government contracts. column31: Ministry of Communication and Aviation to divert funds earmarked for Malaita Projects KEY POINTS: -Suidani led-government refuses the $31.7-US million dollars World Bank funding support because of the China Harbour Engineering firm’s involvement -Ministry of Communication and Aviation submits cabinet papers to divert the refused funds The Ministry of Communication and Aviation has re-diverted the USD$31.7 million dollars World Bank funding earmarked for various projects in Malaita Province to the Ministry. The fund was re-diverted after the province refused to allow the China Harbour Engineering Firm to work on the projects. Minister for Communication and Aviation Hon Peter Shanel Angovaka says his Ministry is working on a cabinet paper to inform the cabinet on the decision. column31: Leaked information exposed the government’s attempts to acquire a loan of USD$100 billion (SBD$800b) from a private businessman in China after switching diplomatic ties from Taiwan to China in September 2019. According to corresponding information sighted by this paper, the Minister of Finance Harry Kuma have written two letters to a middle man named Terry Wong on 27 and 28 November 2019 regarding the USD100 billion proposed loan. According to the proposal, an 11% interest will be paid to a middleman for this loan. The information stated that Mr.Wong has a representative in the country who is pushing for the USD$100 billion loan. The first of the two letters were written on the 27 November 2019, with the title, "Potential Grant/Loan to the Solomon Islands," addressed to Mr.Terry Wong, 6-201, Li Baoli Villado, Tang Road, Ching Ping District, Beijing. Read more...http://bit.ly/100B-loan-:=:http://www.solomonstarnews.com/index.php/news/national/item/22754-loan-deal-exposed

column31: FORMER Prime Minister and Member of Parliament for Small Malaita Hon Rick Houenipwela says the security treaty with China was supposed to be a secretly orchestrated deal. Hon Houenipwela said the secret undertakings on this agreement started way back in 2019 when the Police Minister indicated in Parliament then that ‘if the government had its way, they would have China as the preferred security partner.’ He said it was a clear indication of the Government’s policy intentions but they intended to keep it under wraps until it was leaked. Hon Houenipwela said the signing of the security treaty would have also been kept a secret if the Opposition Leader did not question the Prime Minister on the floor of Parliament last week. “ If it wasn’t for the leak document, the security treaty would be kept a secret from citizens of this country. It is even surprising how the security deal was quick to be signed after it was leaked last week. Why is this even a priority issue?” he questioned. Hon Houenipwela said the Prime Minister was not prepared to tell the truth about the progress of this agreement at anytime.

column31: THE recent Honiara riot has left around 1,000 people jobless. Wilfred Iro was working as a delivery cargo personnel for QQQ Holdings limited the longtime importer and exporter, wholesale and retail on general merchants. He is one of those that lost his job when the rioters looted and burned down China Town. In an exclusive interview with Solomon Star yesterday, Mr. Iro shared his experience during the recent unrest and how the situation will now affect his family. He said on Wednesday after knowing of the incident that took place around Parliament area, his boss advised him and his colleagues to look after the QQQ building in China Town. “Thinking of saving my job for the sake of my family, I volunteered to look after the building (QQQ Ltd) here in China Town. Because without this building (now burnt), I will not earn money to provide for my children,” Mr. Iro said pointing to the burned down building. He said when the rioters looted the Chinese shops in China Town on Thursday 24; the building he worked for was still standing. “My colleagues and I were also advised by our boss that if the rioters came closer and over powered us, we will have to open the shop to the rioters and tell them to take anything they want without burning the building,” Iro said. Read more...

column31: 𝐓𝐀𝐈𝐖𝐀𝐍 𝐅𝐎𝐑𝐄𝐈𝐆𝐍 𝐀𝐅𝐅𝐀𝐈𝐑𝐒 𝐃𝐄𝐏𝐔𝐓𝐘 𝐌𝐈𝐍𝐈𝐒𝐓𝐄𝐑 𝐈𝐍 𝐒𝐎𝐋𝐎𝐌𝐎𝐍 𝐈𝐒𝐋𝐀𝐍𝐃𝐒 The current talked about topic of whether Solomon Islands is switching ties to China or remaining with Taiwan continues today but with a timely visit from Taiwan’s Foreign Affairs deputy minister, Dr. Szu-Chien HSU. Dr. Szu- Chien HSU arrived in the country and was welcomed warmly by a group of Christians supporting Taiwan. “The welcome today was remarkable. I was so touched by the singing and basically by how the people welcomed me here. It is something I will remember for a very long time. Thank you very much Solomon Islands.” The Foreign Affairs deputy minister expressed. The Taiwan Foreign Affairs deputy minister wasted no time and delivered a press release an hour after his arrival. The press release contains some valuable information including some new plans within the relationship between Solomon Islands and Taiwan. SIBC news team along with other media team were present at an exclusive press release and all details and information will be available on the news programs running tonight and in the morning. 𝘗𝘩𝘰𝘵𝘰: 𝘛𝘢𝘪𝘸𝘢𝘯 𝘍𝘰𝘳𝘦𝘪𝘨𝘯 𝘈𝘧𝘧𝘢𝘪𝘳𝘴 𝘥𝘦𝘱𝘶𝘵𝘺 𝘮𝘪𝘯𝘪𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘳, 𝘋𝘳. 𝘚𝘻𝘶-𝘊𝘩𝘪𝘦𝘯 𝘏𝘚𝘜.

column31: Solomon Islands Foreign Minister, Hon Jeremiah Manele, Calls for Unity of the Country in response to Malaita Provincial Premier’s Statement that challenges Solomon Islands recognition of the “One China Policy”. Minister Manele condemns the statement issued by Premier Daniel Suidani yesterday when the Premier made reference to the Republic of China (ROC) as a state rather than a province of the People’s Republic of China (PRC). Solomon Islands recognize the one-China policy as of 21st September 2019 when it signed diplomatic relations with the People’s Republic of China (PRC). Taiwan is an integral part of the People’s Republic of China’s territory. “Such divisive statement from a Provincial Premier threatens the unity of the country at a time when we need to work together in keeping COVID-19 from entering our borders and not politicize the virus,” Minister Manele said. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and External Trade is also investigating possible external interference into the Solomon Islands' domestic affairs. This was after the Ministry received a call from DHL seeking confirmation whether a certain private citizen is a member of staff of the MFAET. MORE HERE... https://bit.ly/FM-mindfl:=:http://www.solomonstarnews.com/index.php/news/national/item/23615-foreign-minister-urges-suidani-to-be-mindful-of-foreign-relations-policy

column31: 𝐁𝐨𝐝𝐲 𝐨𝐟 𝐋𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐀𝐦𝐛𝐚𝐬𝐬𝐚𝐝𝐨𝐫 𝐅𝐮𝐠𝐮𝐢 𝐭𝐨 𝐚𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝐭𝐨𝐝𝐚𝐲 The body of the Solomon Islands Ambassador to China, His Excellency late John Moffat Fugui will arrive in the country tomorrow (27 December 2022). The flight carrying the body of the late Ambassador, his three children and the Second Secretary to the Solomon Islands Embassy left Beijing yesterday afternoon and will arrive in Honiara 2pm today (Tuesday). The Prime Minister, Hon.Manasseh Sogavare, cabinet Ministers and Officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and External Trade will receive the casket of the late Fugui from the People’s Republic of China’s (PRC) Ambassador to the Solomon Islands, His Excellency Li Ming. The Prime Minister will then hand-over the casket to the family of the late Ambassador which will be taken up to the private residence of the late Fugui. An Official funeral program will be held at the St. Barnabas Anglican Church on Thursday (29th December). Details of the program will be made available soon to the public. The 61-year-old late ambassador passed away in Beijing after suffering Cardiac Arrest on Thursday (22nd December 2022). MFAET PRESS RELEASE

column31: The Government has given its blessing for the four repatriation flights to Asia to go ahead starting early next week. This was approved by Cabinet during its deliberation yesterday, a statement issued by the Office Prime Minister and Cabinet (OPMC) confirmed last night. “Cabinet at its meeting today (Thursday 27th August 2020) has approved the repatriation flights to Guangzhou in the Peoples Republic of China (PRC) and to Manila in the Philippines,” the statement said. The first trip scheduled to take place next week on Tuesday, 1st September is for China. This will be followed by three other flights to Manila in September and October to bring back close to 400 local students from the Philippines. The first trip scheduled to take place next week on Tuesday, 1st September is for China.

column31: MALAITA has accused two of its national MPs of betraying the province when they invited and led a Chinese delegation to their respective constituencies early this week. Premier Daniel Suidani said Baegu/Asifola MP Makario Tagini and Fataleka MP Rex Ramofafia’s behaviour is “disrespectful and a betrayal of the provincial government”. Honiara-based China’s acting ambassador to Solomon Islands Yao Ming had told the Solomon Star after his visit they wanted to improve health facilities in Malaita. But Suidani said Tagini and Ramofafia should know well that Malaita, under the Auki communique, will not allow any Chinese Communist Party involvement in the province’s development. "Yet the two acted arrogantly and disrespectfully in sneaking into Malaita Province officials from the office of China,” the premier said. "There action is seen as a betrayal of the people of Malaita Province and as their premier, I am very disappointed,” he added. Suidani said his government is opposed to China’s involvement in Malaita because it’s a communist country with a communist government. MORE HERE... https://bit.ly/betrayd-:=:http://www.solomonstarnews.com/index.php/news/national/item/23485-suidani-to-tagini-and-ramofafia-you-betrayed-us
column35: Suidani to Tagini and Ramofafia: YOU BETRAYED US - Solomon Star News

column31: The premier of Malaita province raised concern at the behavior of two Malaitan national MPS recent actions to bring into Malaita province representatives of the People’s Republic of China PRC. He said the MP for Baegu Asifola Makario Tagini and MP for Fataleka Rex Ramofafia have shown a very disrespectful attitude towards the elected government of Malaita Province. The two MPs and ministers knew very well that Malaita province under the Auki communique does not allow any Chinese Communist Party involvement in the province development. Yet the two acted arrogantly and disrespectfully in sneaking into Malaita Province people from the office of PRC. “This action is seen as a betrayal of the people of Malaita Province and as the premier of Malaita province, I am very disappointed. The stand of MPG against any CCP involvement in Malaita is on the very fact that PRC is a Communist country and have a communist government. Malaita province stands are against the ideology of communism. That is the bottom line. MORE HERE... https://bit.ly/Betrayl-MPG:=:http://www.solomonstarnews.com/index.php/news/national/item/23479-actions-of-the-mps-for-baegu-asifola-fataleka-is-betrayal-of-mpg-suidani
