column31: 𝐒𝐨𝐥𝐨𝐦𝐨𝐧 𝐈𝐬𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐬 𝐬𝐢𝐠𝐧 𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐜 𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐛𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐝𝐚𝐫𝐲 𝐚𝐠𝐫𝐞𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐅𝐢𝐣𝐢 History is in the making as Solomon Islands and Fiji signed a maritime boundary agreement after years of ongoing consultation and negotiations between the two countries. The signing of the letter of exchange took place on the margins of the 51st Pacific Islands Forum Leaders meeting in Suva, Fiji, last night. The signing means the two countries will now secure the rights and responsibilities over their marine resources and exert maritime claims as Parties to the 1982 Law of the Sea Convention. Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare said the signing signifies a celebration of the rolling out of the Ocean chapter of the draft 2050 Strategy while continuing to invest in the sovereignty and sovereign rights of our people over our maritime zones. “This signing signifies our commitment to the 1982 United Nations Law of the Sea Convention which Solomon Islands and Fiji are both parties to. “Itself is one of the achievements the Pacific region is, and in shaping the international convention as we celebrated the 50th Anniversary of the Pacific Islands Forum,” Prime Minister Sogavare said. Prime Minister of the Republic of Fiji Josaia Voreqe Bainimarama said signing of the agreement is an important milestone. “Mapping ocean boundaries is a determinative challenge for us large ocean states in the Pacific, implementing regional ocean solutions depend on such agreements. “They are the foundation of the great blue Pacific wall of sustainably-managed ocean space we are looking to build,” Prime Minister Bainimarama said. Bainimarama said the signing of the agreement is an important milestone to demarcate the region’s 48 shared maritime boundaries, of which remain to be finalised through an agreement. In 2018, PIF forum leaders acknowledged the urgency and importance of securing the region’s maritime boundaries as a key issue for the development and security of the region, and thereby for the security and well-being of the Blue Pacific. Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare also attended the Group of the African Caribbean Pacific Leaders’ (PACP) Meeting yesterday. The PIF Secretary General Henry Puna said one of the key issues which will be unpacked this week is the 2050 Strategy for “our” Blue Pacific Continent. The 2050 Strategy for the Blue Pacific Continent is a regional strategy to protect and secure Pacific people, place and prospects. This is the first face-to-face meeting of the PIF leaders since the start of the pandemic. Other issues that are on the discussion table this week include climate change, healing the Micronesian rift, Pacific partnerships with China, Ocean and fisheries issues and nuclear policy. By Jared Koli In Suva, Fiji

column31: CHINA’s Foreign Minister Wang Yi has arrived in Solomon Islands on a two-day visit – his first since Solomon Islands and China established diplomatic relations two and a half years ago. The plane carrying Minister Wang and his delegation of top officials at Vice Ministerial level – touched down at Henderson International Airport in Honiara at 12:12 this morning. Solomon Islands senior government Ministers led by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Trade, Jeremiah Manele met the top level Chinese delegation on the tarmac as Minister Wang stepped off his plane to a red carpet welcome.

column31: CHINA DONATES PPE TO WESTERN PROVINCE By EDDIE OSIFELO WESTERN Province has deepened its relationship with China after it received 2,500 medical masks and other clothings in Honiara yesterday. Premier David Gina took delivery of the gifts from Ambassador Li Ming. “We will foster the friendship relations with Western province and provinces in China,” Ming said. “Hhe Chinese embassy is now working on the sister-province relationship between Western province and Fujian province, a prosperous coastal province of China, which should be a showcase for our sub-national cooperation,” he added. “We will support the pandemic response efforts by Western province. “We understand the Western province is facing some challenges on that because of its geographical location. “I am honoured to handover PPE to the people of Western province, including 2500 medical masks and other clothings. “China honours its commitments and never pays lip service when it comes to mutual assistance.” Ming said Western province is rich in forestry, fishery and other resources, China is the world’s second largest economy with huge middle-income population, and big market for the exports from Western province. “Solomon Islands have already been granted ‘approved destination status’ for Chinese tourists, and Western province will certainly attract more visitors from China. “The Chinese Embassy will encourage Chinese companies to participate in the infrastructure development of Western province. “I hold a strong belief that the potential of our cooperation is huge, and the future of our cooperation is brilliant. “I also look forward to opportunities to visiting Western province in the near future.” Premier Gina said he was so grateful to get the gifts as part of the province’s preparedness and response to covid-19. He added it is not a mistake to establish diplomatic relationship with China.

column31: THE proposed $100 billion loan deal between the Solomon Island Government (SIG) and a confidential Chinese donor through broker Terry Wong has shocked Chinese officials in Honiara. The loan deal hit the local media headlines last week after the responsible Minister for Finance come out publicly to explain the leaked documents. Just five months after the Solomon Islands switched its diplomatic relations to China and severed ties with Taiwan a loan proposal was in the pipeline. According to the official, the letter obtained by this paper that Mr. Kuma wrote, Mr. Wong would receive a proposed 11% fee if the $100 billion loan is secured. Speaking to Solomon Star over the weekend the Chinese official in Honiara said they were not aware of such a deal. Asked if they discussed such deals with the Minister of Finance and the government the official said they never discussed anything related to a loan. “I mean this is ridiculous and for a small economy like your country seeking such a huge loan that will pose a great economic disaster for your country,” the official told this paper. Read more...http://bit.ly/CHN-shckd:=:http://www.solomonstarnews.com/index.php/news/national/item/22801-shocking-revelation

column31: MALAITA Provincial Premier Daniel Suidani has recently cautioned the National Government not to accept Coronavirus kits from China in light of the government’s plea for assistance in safety and protective equipment to fight against the Coronavirus Pandemic. Premier Suidani made the call in an exclusive interview with Solomon Star Auki following two news items that Guangdong Province in China is prepared to send in masks and other protective garments and the announcement by the Prime Minister that the Chinese government will be assisting the country with testing kits to help the country in its fight against COVID-19. "While we should appreciate any genuine support, we must also be mindful that whatever we are given is workable, applicable and serves the purpose to which it intends to serve and must be internationally accepted and of high quality,” the premier said. “I said this in light of a number of international reports revealing that a dozen countries including, Spain, Netherlands, Philippines, and the Czech Republic's have returned faulty Chinese made COVID-19 testing kits,” Mr. Suidani added. column31: SYDNEY (Reuters) - Australia will soon offer millions of dollars in funding for infrastructure projects in the Pacific, two sources familiar with the plan told Reuters, as part of its efforts to undercut Chinese influence. Australia has long enjoyed nearly unchecked prominence in the Pacific but its position has been challenged by China in recent years as it increases its aid to the sparsely populated region that controls vast swathes of resource-rich ocean.

column31: MAY God bless the hand that gives and those that have received what has been given says the Malaita Provincial Premier Daniel Suidani. Premier Suidani echoed words of thanks and heartfelt gratitude to the government and the people of the Republic of China (ROC) ROC on Taiwan's COVID-19 food support to Malaita Province by funding 2,600 20kg bags of rice. The Malaita Premier told Solomon Star Auki in an exclusive interview during the launching of Taiwan's COVID-19 support to Malaita Province yesterday that those rice bags will be distributed to vulnerable communities in Malaita that are often faced with food shortage due to their locations. He said communities that will receive the food supply supports are from; Langa Langa Lagoon, Lau Lau Lagoon, West Are'are Lagoon, Walande and Fanalai, Kwai, and Ngongosila, Basakana, Dai, Manaoba, and Malaita Outer Islands (MOI). The Premier said communities in the said location often face a shortage of root crops due to their location which makes it difficult for them to grow root crops. He said many people are returning home due to the COVID-19 threat and put more pressure on these vulnerable communities forcing them to dig deeper into their pockets just to put a single meal on the table to sustain their lives. He said as a responsible government, MARA is taking a leading role in engaging with traditional partners to ensure there is food on the table for the most affected communities in the province. column31: CHINA has lived up to its promise by delivering much needed emergency humanitarian assistance supplies to Solomon Islands today. The support comes as the country tries to grapple with COVID-19 community transmission since last week. A statement issued by Government Communication Unit said on Wednesday January 26, 2022, Cabinet Ministers of Solomon Islands, the Hon. Culwick Togamana, Minister of Health and Medical Services and the Hon Anthony Veke, Minister for Police, National Security and Correctional Services with His Excellency Ambassador LI Ming of the People’s Republic of China Embassy in Solomon Islands were at Honiara International Airport to receive emergency humanitarian assistance supplies from the People’s Republic of China. The two countries further celebrate the strength of its relationship with China’s support today with the presentation of 50,000 Sinopharm vaccines, 20,000 Rapid Antigen Test Kits, 21,000 disposal syringes, 50 tent units and financial humanitarian assistance of USD320,000 to the Government through the Ministry of Health and Medical Services, the statement said. The consignment also includes the second shipment of Anti-Riot Gears, equipment and police uniforms to assist officers carry out its law and order mandate during this challenging time. The first shipment was delivered back in late December 2021. The partnership is given in solidarity and with a “yumi tugeda” spirit of togetherness, echoing the global mantra that “no one is safe until everyone is safe”.

column31: The recent USD100 billion-dollar deal exposed in the media is a classic debt trap in the making, according to Peter Kenilorea Jr, deputy Leader of the Opposition. Kenilorea made this statement in response to the recent revelations of the Minister of Finance Harry Kuma entering negotiations with a Beijing agent for the enormous loan of USD100 billion. “When this government decided to switch to China, many of us warned of the dangers of the debt trap. But pro-China supporters said we were making this up and repeating Western propaganda. “But the proof is in front of us in black and white,” he went on to say. “The classic sign of a debt trap is convincing a desperate country into taking on too much debt for it to handle. And when the borrower defaults, the provider of the money has control over the government. This is exactly what we have in front of us today.” Read more...http://bit.ly/debt-trap-:=:http://www.solomonstarnews.com/index.php/news/national/item/22855-china-s-debt-trap-is-already-here

column31: China distances itself from loan brokerage negotiations BY ALFRED SASAKO THE Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has distanced itself from media reports that Solomon Islands is seeking a $100 billion loan from Beijing. “We have nothing to do with it,” an official of the Chinese government told Island Sun on the weekend. “The Chinese government does not lend that kind of money. As a matter of fact when the media report on the matter came out we did a search of the address in Beijing the individual provided and it was found it is not a company premises. “It seems that it is an apartment, which the individual might be using for his own business,” the Chinese government official said. The news of the reported $100 billion loan emanated from leaked letters, allegedly written and signed off by Finance Minister Harry Kuma to a Terry Wong in Beijing. In the first letter, dated 27 November 2019, Mr. Kuma wrote: “I have been advised by your representative in the Solomon Islands in respect to the potential funding that could be made available to the Solomon Islands government. My Ministry is interested in officially opening dialogue to investigate this proposal further in detail based on the information that was provided to me at the initial briefing, “I encourage you to provide further detailed information regarding this funding proposal so that my Ministry and I can have a better understanding of what is being tabled, and be able to make a fair judgment. “Note that we are very interested in any potential funding that would contribute to the improvement of our economy and the betterment of our people,” the letter addressed to a Mr. Terry Wong said. The second letter the next day (28 November 2019) disclosed an 11 per cent brokerage fee which Mr. Kuma said “is noted and accepted in principle.” In today’s exchange rate, 11 per cent of $100 billion is USD11 billion, which is equivalent to SBD91.85 billion (1USD = SBD8.35). That disclosure touched off a flurry of activities in Honiara in the past week, prompting the Opposition’s call on the Government to provide details. Former Prime Minister Gordon Darcy Lilo also bought into the debate, demanding answers from the Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare-led government on the loan negotiations. Others are also questioning why dealings between two sovereign states as is the case between Solomon Islands and the PRC should be conducted through a third party. “It would have been acceptable if we did not have diplomatic relations with China. But we do,” one critic said. “Now the onus is on the Minister of Finance to explain his action to the nation, given that Honiara and Beijing normalized diplomatic relations in September last year. His letters to Terry Wong came two months after the fact or does he not know about the change in diplomatic relations?”

column31: Government comes out with new reason for China flight BY MAVIS NISHIMURA PODOKOLO GOVERNMENT has come up with another reason to explain its controversial plan to send a direct flight to China to bring over Chinese nationals and Chinese with Solomons passport. Now Government says the proposed flight to China is aimed at giving back the so-called stranded Solomon Islands nationals in China their constitutional rights. Speaking at a public forum on Friday last week, Dr Jimmie Rodgers, Secretary to the Prime Minister, gave this response to a question on “Why China?” “The reason to going there is to give them their constitutional rights,” said Mr Rodgers. “China is guilty of where virus has started from, [but] right now China is one of the safest countries. The risk now is Philippines. This country is 100 times riskier than China. “So why China? The questioned is why Philippines we have 53 nationals in China are waiting repatriation so this why we are looking at making sure that they are repatriated and every country 750 will be coming back and 53 in China have the same constitutional right as you and I for the government’s protection “I will say this because I have been hit hard on why China, let’s be very clear we assessed the risk and any one coming in from any country has to have a clear assessment on health and any one boarding the plane must have negative test whether its China , Indonesia, UK or Australia or wherever no exception no one steps in the Plane unless they fulfill our procedures,” said Rodgers. This fresh excuse, coupled with their previous claim that it is much safer in China than anywhere else our citizens are stranded in, Government says justifies the proposed China-flight. This latest ‘reason’ only adds salt to wound on students stranded in the Philippines and their families who have been pleading with government since the early months of covid-19’s wake for their repatriation. Government has since then been unenthusiastic in answering their calls, only recently announcing that some plans are in the pipeline for their repatriation. [Yesterday, government announced during the weekly radio talkback show that repatriation flights have been arranged for students in the Philippines for September 15, 18 and October 22]. Transparency Solomon Islands (TSI) recently revealed that the so-called Solomon Islands nationals stranded in China which Government is so keen to bring over are in fact Chinese who have attained Solomons passports. TSI also called on government to release to public a list of these so-called stranded Solomons citizens. Government has since been silent.

Prime Minister Sogavare will resume duty on the 12th of January of 2023. The Prime Minister left for his home village in Kumanibai in East Choiseul, Choiseul Province yesterday. Prior to his departure, PM Sogavare had engaged in two important occasions namely the dedication of the Seventh Day Adventist Church at Sukiki, East Guadalcanal and paying final respect to the country’s ambassador to the Peoples’ Republic of China (PRC) the late John Moffat Fugui. It is customary of Prime Ministers to take a break from national duty but not for the usual 28 days as applied to public servants. Given the importance of ensuring leadership continuity, PMs often take shorter breaks and PM Sogavare is no different. During his absence the Deputy Prime Minister Hon. Manasseh Maelanga will be the supervising Prime Minister. End/// Prime Minister’s Press Secretariat

column31: SIPA TAKES DELIVERY OF A $16 MILLION X-RAY By Alfred Sasako SOLOMON Islands Ports Authority (SIPA) trading as Solomon Ports yesterday took delivery of a $16 million X-Ray machine, which is certain to save it and the Government hundreds of millions of dollars in lost revenue. The top-of-the range machine arrived in Honiara yesterday. It was manufactured in China. Solomon Ports’ workers and Chinese engineers yesterday wasted no time in getting the machine off the container ship at the Point Cruz wharf yesterday. Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare will officially commission the X-Ray machine between the 8th and 15th December this year. It is understood Solomon Ports decided to buy the machine after increasing incidents of false declarations on in-coming and outgoing oversea cargoes. False declarations cost Customs and Solomon Ports hundreds of millions of dollars each year. Now there is a warning out to those engaged in false declarations in the past to watch out as the X-ray is capable of picking up everything in a container for example. The machine has a robotic arm which would be used to scan containers before the cargo leaves the Ports Area. The machine (PICTURED) stands 4.6m above the ground and has a control room described as a mini coffee shop, big enough to accommodate four people. In acquiring the machine, Solomon Ports now joins Papua New Guinea, Fiji, Vanuatu and Samoa in owning an X-Ray machine.

column31: AS the debate rages over who is and who is not genuine in its infrastructure development effort in Solomon Islands, China simply keeps piling it in. And to maintain its international reputation that it is a major donor with a heart to help, a Chinese PLA Airforce Y-20 transport plane carrying anti-epidemic supplies landed at Henderson International Airport in Honiara last Friday afternoon. Chinese Ambassador to Solomon Islands Li Ming and Solomon Islands Minister of Health and Medical Services Culwick Togamana were at the airport to receive the life-saving medical supplies from China. Anti-epidemic supplies, including test kits and oxygen generators weighing over 20 tons arrived onboard the flight intended to fight a growing number of COVID-19 cases, another severe challenge following the unrest that took place in November last year. The supplies were delivered by a Chinese PLA Air Force Y-20 transport aircraft. The supplies include 320,000 test kits, 20 oxygen-making machines, 20 oximeters, 180,000 pairs of gloves, 20,000 pairs of goggles, 10,000 protective suits, 100 foldable beds and 70 tents. column31: KAIBAR FACES TERMINATION BY ALFRED PAGEPITU The Honiara City Council (HCC) is considering an option to terminate the business license of the Chinese restaurant YC Kaibar. The Kaibar which situated at China town was closed down for indefinite period for allegedly using drain water for cooking its menu and washing. City Clerk Rence Sore in an updated interview with Island Sun yesterday said YC Kaibar was close down for an indefinite period while investigation proceed. He said pending on the results of their investigation, HCC is considering an option to terminate YC Kaibar business license. The Kaibar after been closed down has repainted the building from yellow to grey color. The reason behind the change of color is uncertain but it was believe the owner is trying to restore the image of the Kaibar. “Yesterday, I drove passed the Kaibar, it was repainted in grey color on the outside but if the inner part remains unchanged, HCC will not be lenient to the restaurant owner.” “HCC will monitor every restaurants in the city, both Chinese and locally owned. He said they will not announce when to carry out monitoring on local and Chinese restaurants. “It will come at a time they least expected. It may be this week, next week or the week after,” City clerk Sore said. He said HCC has ordinances to deliver services and improve social and economic livelihood of all city residents. He said HCC will enforce and monitor these ordinances. HCC will appreciate the efforts of public to report all offenders in the city for investigations and actions by the city council. “Together, with HCC, we can deliver a better city in the country,” Sore said. Meanwhile, many city residents calls for permanent closure of the restaurant and deport the owner while others want the owner to be prosecuted.

column31: PM launches Iumi Tugeda Campaign PRIME Minister Manasseh Sogavare today has launched the ‘Iumi Tugeda Campaign’ at the National Museum Auditorium. He said the COVID-19 global pandemic that began in Wuhan, China some 7 months ago has been an awakening call for the country. He said Solomon Islands is undeniably blessed to be amongst the very few countries in the world that is still COVID-19 free. “And for that we are forever grateful to our Father in Heaven,” he said. Prime Minister Sogavare said our status as a COVID-19 free country is also a testament of our unity as one people, one nation, one Solomon Islands. “This global pandemic has truly tested our resolve but we have stood our ground, and we will continue to move forward together as a country. This pandemic has indeed changed the global, political, social and economic landscape and we as a country have not escaped this change,” he said. The Prime Minister said our conventional way of doing things is no longer effective. He said the pandemic has taught us that we really need to explore ways of doing things differently. “Doing things the normal way is no longer normal. These are challenging times but with these challenges comes opportunity,” he said. The launching yesterday was also graced with a unity song sang by our local artists and musicians. Prime Minister Sogavare also acknowledged the musicians that have worked tirelessly in putting the song together. “Music is the universal language of the soul and it speaks to everyone from the mountains of Malaita to the shores of Western Province. From the beaches of Temotu to the jungles of Guadalcanal. It is common in all our cultures throughout all our provinces and it inspires and motivates,” he said. The event was also attended by government ministers, senior government officials, diplomatic reps, private sector reps, civil society reps, Church leaders and members of the public. --OPMC 1. PM Sogavare with the local artists, musicians and producers of the unity song. 2. PM acknowledges local artist Ronnie Riti commonly known as Paeva. 3. PM Sogavare and Tourism Minister Hon Parapolo visiting the Solomon Airlines booth.

column31: MARA ‘concerned’ with MPs’ action in province. BY SAMIE WAIKORI Auki The Malaita provincial government is concerned with Malaitan members of Parliament bringing in Chinese to engage in development in the province. The limelight has been shed on the MPs for Baegu Asifola (BAC) and Fataleka constituencies. Underlying this concern is the Auki Communique, which rejects and Chinese investment in the province. Advisor to the Malaitan Premier, Celsius Talifilu made a public statement questioning these two MPs. “Many of us by now would have heard that the MPs for BAC and Fataleka have brought in some Chinese nationals for the development of the much talked about road from Fouia to Manu. “This is despite the call by premier of Malaita province for national leaders to respect the Auki communiqué and leave out any engagement with any affiliates of the Chinese Communist party into malaita province. “Such show of behavior by the two leaders has shown the disregard to a call by an elected government of Malaita province. “I know for sure the two MPs are well aware that myself and the premier are from Baegu and Fataleka as well as a both of us are instrumental in putting together this communiqué. “I would have thought that as people from the same language groups and who is blood related, a courtesy to honour the views and the stand of Malaita province would be something respectful,” he said. Talifilu said he has been informed by the people that the two MPs have directly denounced the stand the Malaita province has taken. In this regard, he said the Malaita province will continue to speak against any developments from CCP affiliates, and will use all possible means under the powers of the provincial government to deal with such developments and behaviors of national leaders. “As I said before, the Malaita provincial government continues to support the national government initiative under the National Transport Core Initiative that see donor partners other than PRC developments the road infrastructure of Malaita province including the Fouia Manu segment. “We failed to see why the two MPs have seeing it fit and gone ahead to bring in China into the picture knowing very well that Malaita province is against any development from China into Malaita province. “We neither see the current engagement of the two MPs with the Chinese nor did different from the current action by the government that threatened to dissolve MPG. “Under such threats to the good will of Malaita province to protect its province, the province will not be taking these threats lightly. “The province will not back down from what it sees as threat that perpetuated with the aim of destabilizing the MARA government,” Talifilu said.

column31: Testing kits, PPEs soon to arrive via cargo flights Testing kits and Personal Protection Equipment (PPEs) are expected to arrive in the country via cargo carriers. This is according to senior member of the Government’s Oversight Committee, on the covid-19. Speaking during a talkback show over the weekend, Chief of Staff of the Prime Minister’s Office Mr Robson Djokovic said the Government began taking proactive measures to address the potential entry or spread of covid-19 into the country two months ago. The Oversight Committee confirmed other bilateral, multilateral and donor partners have pledged their support to assist Government in providing the much-needed PPEs and testing kits and Laboratory equipment. Some of the supplies are arriving in the country before the second week of April. Yesterday afternoon the Oversight Committee heard the first shipment of orders from the People’s Republic of China are on route via DHL. Secretary to Prime Minister Dr Jimmie Rogers updated, as soon as the batch gets to Brisbane, our Plane will transport them to the country. ‘Maybe by mid this week, we will have new stocks coming in because current limited stocks will not spread too far’, he underlined. There is a second arrangement he added. This is also from the People’s Republic of China coming through French Polynesia. This will most likely be dropped off in Fiji and our national airline will airlift it from there. The Committee is hopeful that by the end of this week, both supplies will be in the country. The Committee reiterated whilst most entry into other countries is restricted, Government is working closely with its bilateral and development partners to ensure the efficient delivery of these supplies. Although flights are currently suspended to limit the entry of passengers into the country, emergencies, refuelling and cargo carriers are permitted. Meanwhile, Government acknowledges the Australian High Commission’s donation of a batch of Personal Hygiene kits to the National Disaster Operation Centre yesterday. The kits contain sanitary items such as Toilet Tissues, Shaving Gear, Soap, Cleaning detergent, Colgate and Tooth Brush, Face mask and Gloves. The Democratic Coalition Government (DCGA) continues to commend the cooperation of bilateral, multilateral and donor partners for their support. The DCGA encourages all citizens to strictly follow the advice and instructions of the Government and its agencies so we can remain united in our efforts to defend against the covid-19 global pandemic. --OPMC PRESS

column31: More prefer aligning with liberal democratic nations. A RECENT opinion poll undertaken in Honiara following last November’s riots found more Solomon Islanders wanted the country to be diplomatically aligned with liberal democratic countries. APMI Partners, Asia Pacific region's leading provider of market research, social research, economic research, fieldwork services and market-intelligence based consulting, carried out the research. This is to determine the view of the adult population relating to issues such as which countries the Solomon Islands should be diplomatically aligned towards, which countries the Solomon Islands should receive financial aid from, the level of foreign investment in key industries such as forestry and the level of perceived government corruption. One question asked “Do you prefer the Solomon Islands to be diplomatically aligned more towards China or liberal democratic counties?” The overwhelming majority of 91% answered “Liberal Democratic Countries” with only 9% answering “China”. In another question, asked “Should the Solomon Islands receive financial aid from China?” 79% answered “No” and 21% answered “Yes”. In terms of the level of perceived government corruption, one question asked “Do you believe that there exists corruption in the national government?” where 83% answered “Yes”. A subsequent question asked “Over the last 12 months, do you believe that the level of corruption in the national government has decreased, remained the same or increased?” where 68% answered “Increased”; 21% answered “Remained the Same” and 11% answered “Decreased”. The survey used a methodology where a nationwide, representative survey of 1,526 adults throughout the nine provinces of the Solomon Islands was conducted between 25th November to 7th December 2021.

column31: Students set for 5pm touch-down today THE first group of students flying in from the Philippines is expected to touch down at Honiara International Airport at 5pm today. Solomon Airlines Airbus A320 left Honiara 10am yesterday, brief stop-over at Biak Airport in Indonesia and then to Ninoy Aquino International Airport, Manila. The airbus follows the same route for the return trip. A statement from National Disaster Council (NDC) yesterday said that prior to boarding, all returning student have completed three sets of covid-19 tests which were sent to SIG-Oversight Steering Committee (OSC) covid-19 response and the Ministry of Health for approval. Philippines is “high risk” for covid-19 infections. The change in the flight schedules was needed to give ample time for our health officials and the taskforce established by the OSC to liaise with Philippines Red Cross to coordinate changes to the passenger list for the first flight. “Timing for the second and third flights will be confirmed by the Oversight Steering Committee in due course,” the NDC statement said. “The returning students will be accommodated at government managed Quarantine Stations (QS) at Guadalcanal Beach Resort and Chengs Building both located in East Honiara,” it added. “This 1st Philippine repatriation flight will be the 12th flight the Solomon Airlines will do. “Of the previous 11 flights, six were from Brisbane, two from Vila and Nadi, one from Auckland, one from Guangzhou, China and one from Apia, Samoa. “Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS) continues to lead the Government’s multi-sectoral approach to stem covid-19 infiltration on our shores. “All government agencies and stakeholders are providing the required support through the National Disaster Operations Committees (N-DOC) and Provincial Disaster Operations Committee (P-DOC). “N-DOC Camp Management Sector Committee maintains and continues to manage all the government approved QS in Honiara and Western province.” At the moment, only 36 persons are undergoing quarantine at the government-managed quarantine sites. Solomon Islands remains covid-19 free to date. “The Government remains committed to implementing strict measures to prevent the importation and potential spread of covid-19 within its borders,” the statement said. --NDC PRESS

column31: Casava exporters shortlisted for $100,000 grant By EDDIE OSIFELO Some cassava and taro exporters are on their way to receiving $100,000 assistance from the ministry of foreign affairs. Ministry of Foreign Affairs and External Trade (MFAET) shortlisted some candidates at the deadline of application last Friday (April 24). The lucky candidates could receive $100,000 assistance from the ministry. Reliable sources told Island Sun a Committee is expected to meet to decide the recipients of the grant. “We are not sure how many people will receive the $100,000. “The project is expected to roll out around May,” reliable sources said. In 2010, former Foreign Affairs Minister and now Minister of Communication and Aviation, Peter Shanel held bilateral talks with Canada on the possibility of exporting cassava. It is still not sure whether Solomon Islands has exported any cassava to Canada to date. The cassava export markets are primarily in Europe and North America, which includes Canada. There are a number of important but smaller markets in Asia, such as Japan, Korea and China. According to MFET website, the ministry is responsible for implementing the Enhanced Integrated Framework (EIF) Programme in Solomon Islands. EIF is a multi-donor programme, which supports Least Development Countries (LDC) to be more active players in the global trading system, by helping them tackle their supply side constraint to trade. The EIF national Implementation Unit (NIU based at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and External Trade (MFAET) is responsible for the implementation of the EIF programme/ projects in Solomon Islands. The EIF NIU is currently implementing two (2) EIF supported projects, known as the EIF Tier 1 and Tier 2 projects. The Tier 1 project is on strengthening of national institutional capacities related to Trade while the Tier 2 project is on supporting / helping LDCs integrate better into the global trading system in a way which contributes to poverty reduction and sustainable development. Our recently approved Tier 2 project (ECAT) which aims to expand economic and employment opportunities through systematic interventions in selected agriculture value chains and associated trade and promotion activities is under implementation. Last week the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock has signed an SBD$2.7 Million funding agreement with the management of SAPE Farm representative Dr. Paul Bosawai Popora to further support the farm into mass commercial production of Cassava and Potato. The SAPE farm is base in Guadalcanal Plains in North Guadalcanal. Island Sun understands this is part of maintaining the food security during this coronavirus (COVID-19) situation and maybe to export internationally.

column31: ‘Dates can be changed’, PM’s worrying change of tone on Philippines flights BY BARNABAS MANEBONA THE Prime Minister is changing his tone on the plan to repatriate our students in the Philippines. Before the China-direct flight, Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare and his government communications released a lot of strong statements emphasising the urgency and reasons why repatriation of our citizens [in China and Philippines] is a must. However, yesterday, five days after the infamous China-direct flight landed in Honiara, in his nation-wide address PM Sogavare says the dates for the Philippine flights “are not final and can change”. This sudden change in tone has sparked worry among parents and concerned citizens. Sogavare said, in his statement, said: “Fellow citizens, as you might have been informed already, the next two repatriation flights will be from Manila, Philippines. “They are scheduled for 15th and 18th September 2020. However, as you, all know there are so many moving parts to planning an operation such as repatriation flights and as such, these dates are not final and can be changed.” Concerned parents share that government, after the China-direct flight, is suddenly bringing back to the forefront the issue of risk levels in the two countries [China and the Philippines], something which government had used earlier this year to explain why it has not rushed to repatriate our students when covid-19 began soaring in the Philippines. In his address yesterday, Sogavare said: “Unlike China, which the risk level is in category 3, Philippines is in category 4 and more riskier. “However, as a responsible Government, it is our obligation to repatriate our stranded students in the Philippines as keeping them there longer will increase their chances of contracting the virus. “Therefore, despite the risks, we must bring our students home and we are expecting to repatriate well over 400 of our students. “The Ministries of Education, Foreign Affairs and Health are coordinating the testing arrangements with the assistance from the World Health Organization for our students. “We will continue to keep our people informed of these two repatriation flights.”

column31: CHINA JOINS BATTLE TO PREVENT COVID-19 FROM SOLOMON ISLANDS THE Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has joined in the battle to prevent the deadly corona virus from infecting Solomon Islands. China yesterday has donated US$300, 000.00 to assist the Solomon Islands Government to buy testing kits and other laboratory equipment to strengthen the capacity and capability of health authorities. Solomon Islands so far has not recorded any positive cases of the virus since it was declared as a pandemic by WHO last month. The Chinese Government is also making arrangements to ship a total of 125,000 pairs of protective gloves to Honiara soon. Officials from the two Governments are also discussing the possibility of organizing a chartered flight from French Polynesia (Tahiti) to pick up medical supplies from China to Honiara. Meanwhile, the Chinese Province of Guangdong is currently making arrangements to ship thousands of facemasks and protective garments to Honiara as part of its assistance package to the people of Solomon Islands. The Solomon Islands Government commends the cooperation of bilateral, multilateral and donor partners for their support in efforts to prevent the entry of Covid-19 into the country. --GCU

column31: AFTER 45 years, Hela's Tari airport now stands immaculate with a completely new sealed landing strip. Measuring up to1.6 kilometers was built at the cost of K55million by the China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC) and launched today by Prime Minister James Marape. He described it as “ A gift for the province to mark the country's national day, Independence.” Thousands turned up to witness the inauguration. Hela Governor Philip Undialu thanked everyone who contributed to making the upgrade of the airport possible so aircrafts bringing in vital goods and services can now have a smooth landing on a sealed tarmac. "its a well fitted gift for the province and I am happy," he said. Apart from the airport, the province also signed an agreement with the University of Goroka’s Pro Vice Chancellor Academic Dr Sam Naike to offer degree programs for the people of Hela. See our full report By MELISHA YAFOI in tomorrow’s paper.

column31: GOVERNMENT COMMITS TO USD 170 MILLION CREATING MORE EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES The Government, through the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Finance and Treasury, McKinnie Dentana and Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Infrastructure Development, Stephen Maesiola today signed a Maritime Component of the Land and Marine Connectivity Project or LMCP with the international contractor, China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation or CCECC. This will see the rehabilitation of the old Honiara International Port and construction of the Honiara Domestic Port and two provincial ports- one in Kirakira, Makira Province and another in Ahanga, Renbel Province. The Maritime Component, is part of the USD170 million LMCP, the Government secured with the Asian Development Bank. Through the international tender process overseen by the ADB, CCECC was awarded a contract in mid, 2022, and the land component and contract was signed in 2022. Preparatory work on the land component has commenced. The land component includes improvement of the existing 4-lane road, from the Central market through to White River, as well as the 2-lane road from the Honiara International Airport to Mberande. Once complete, the project will contribute to a more efficient, safer and sustainable transport system that will improve access to education, health, and social service facilities as well as offering increased opportunities to local businesses and general improvement in the overall wellbeing of the people of the Solomon Islands. The Solomon Islands Government through the Ministry of Finance has executed the project signing. The Ministry of Infrastructure Development will be the key implementing agency. Ends//

column31: OFFICIALS from the Chinese Embassy in Honiara made a special trip to Malaita at the invitation of two MPs from the province on Monday. This was revealed exclusively by China’s Acting Ambassador to Solomon Islands Yao Ming, Tuesday. Ambassador Ming, who was part of the team, was invited by MP for Baegu Asifola constituency Makario Tagini and MP for Fataleka Rex Ramofafia. The two MPs are members of the ruling Democratic Coalition Government for Advancement (DCGA). It’s understood that this is the first visit Chinese officials to visit Malaita after the China switch last September. The switch to China from Taiwan was staunchly opposed by Malaita and their provincial executive has boldly declared they will not accept any funding assistance from China. Last year Suidani told the international media that Malaita province won't accept any development loans from China, as concern rises over investments from Beijing. But a breakthrough was made on Monday when the PRC Officials led by their Acting Ambassador visited the constituencies. MORE HERE... https://bit.ly/CHN-visit:=:http://www.solomonstarnews.com/index.php/news/national/item/23471-ming-we-want-to-improve-health-facilities

column31: A Chinese man has been ordered to pay a court fine of K40,000 or be imprisoned for four years following his conviction by the Waigani Committal Court this morning. Liu Zhong from Fujian province in China was guilty of being in possession of 148 cartons of Double Happiness, a cigarette brand labeled illegal on the Papua New Guinea market. Zhong who appeared from extended court bail of K10, 000 was charged under the Customs Act in January and had pleaded guilty when his charges were read out. The court found out that consignment note on the 24-foot container that contained the 148 cartons of cigarettes was falsely declared as plastic rakes and toilet tissues. Senior District Court Magistrate, Cosmar Bidar said the state losses large revenues through the import of illicit cigarettes and said Asians doing business in PNG must respect the PNG Laws. Zhong was ordered to pay the K40,000 within seven days and the illegal cigarettes be destroyed within 30 days. #EMTV #PNG #Papua_New_Guinea

column31: SOLOMON ISLANDS_CHINA, SIGNED COMMUNIQUE China and Solomon Islands have wielded a deal for political matrimony. Solomon Islands Foreign Affairs Minister Jeremiah Manele and China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi signed an agreement to form ties at a government guest house in Beijing in the last 24 hours. Aljazeera reports on signing the deal, Minister Manele said, the decision to switch recognition to Beijing from Taipei- is based on 'national needs'. His Chinese counterpart said, “We look forward to the quick development of bilateral relations between China and the Solomon's,” said Wang, pledging to support the country in moving “forward in the development path it has chosen for itself”, as reported on China's Xihua New Network. In the case of Solomon Islands, details of the signed Communique and MOU are up to this point, known only to the Government. From Beijing, China, Minister Manele will then travel to the 74th United Nations General Assembly in New York this week.

column31: Fear now is we might be positive through next tests: SISAP BY BARNABAS MANEBONA STUDENTS of Solomon Islands studying at Philippines said their fear now is despite having first negative Coronavirus (Covid-19) test results, they might later turn out positive through next testings. Members of Solomon Islands Students Association at Philippines (SISAP) said why they have this fear is because of the Covid-19 environment exposure they are in from a high risk country as Philippines. SISAP students wishing for anonymity said their first group’s second tests will be on this coming Friday while the second group undergoing tests last Sunday will have their second tests during this next coming Sunday. The third group from the ‘SISAP divided three groups’ are yet to undergo their Covid-19 tests. Adding to fear, SISAP students raise that they might only end up getting infected at the Red Cross hospitals arranged for them to undergo covid-19 tests too since the setups there cannot be fully trusted, and they also have records of many positive cases in Philippines being tested there. “Such exposure to such hospitals arranged with the Red Cross might also be the place the first group of our students undergoing first tests have taken positive results, who knows. They are said to be asymptomatic so Covid-19 cannot be found,” said stressed SISAP students. “We say such because according to rumours here also, roommates are questioning how come our students have been tested positive with Covid-19 when they hardly leave their homes.” Despite everything, SISAP members urge Solomon Islands government to get them home as soon as possible. “Please bring us back home, we have been asking to return since the beginning of this year when covid-19 cases were still less in this country compared to China already then,” said SISAP students. “Whoever with negative and positive cases, we must all return home before the situation here worsens. The government has no other option but to just bring us back home now because we are citizens of Solomon Islands. “The government should prioritise its citizens in the first place. We want to return back to our parents and families. The government should try putting them in our shoes.” According to strict departure requirements, it is the Solomon Islands government requirement that all those planning to travel to Solomon Islands must undergo three tests, and all these tests must be negative before they could travel. Secretary to the Prime Minister Dr Jimmie Rodgers during the weekly talk-back show last Sunday said that the answer to the question of ‘should students come home now’ is “Without the shadow of doubt they must come home because the longer they remain there, the higher the exposer to contract the virus”. “But before they come home, we have to make sure they fulfil the pre-departure requirement process in Philippines and when they get here, they have to undergo mandatory quarantine under our laws and will only be released after three consecutive negative tests during the quarantine period.” Dr Rodgers said since Philippines is one of the high risk countries in terms of Covid-19, the students upon their arrival have to undergo 21 days quarantine. Solomon Airlines (SolAir) through their ‘Communications Unit’ this week confirming the approval of SIG and the Government of Philippines to operate three repatriation flights from Manila to Honiara also reminded that passengers regardless of their nationality or status ‘will and must’ undergo strict testing and quarantine protocols prior to, during and after arrival. The three repatriation flights from Manila to Honiara are scheduled to be on September 27 and September 29, with the third flight on October 27 said to be in the process of being confirmed. “All passengers regardless of their nationality or status will and must undergo strict testing and quarantine protocols prior to, during and after arrival. All incoming passengers must be individually approved and each traveller will have taken three COVID-19 tests in the 21 days before the flight. They will only be allowed to board the plane if all three tests are negative for COVID-19. “On arrival in Solomon Islands, all travellers will undergo a mandatory 21-day quarantine period and they will have a further three tests which must all be negative before they can be released,” said Solomon Airlines Communications Unit.

column31: 4th USP Campus in Honiara ready to be constructed BY BARNABAS MANEBONA AS soon as China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC) arrives in the country this week, work will commence on the 4th University of South Pacific (USP) Campus in Honiara. Permanent Secretary (PS) of the Ministry of Education and Human Resource Development (MEHRD) Dr Franco Rodie confirmed this yesterday when queried over the Oversight Committee’s (OSC) update that a flight tomorrow (March 5) from Guangzhou will bring in workers to construct the fourth Campus. According to Mr Rodie, China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC) was awarded the contract to build the 4th USP Campus in Honiara. And, that mobilisation of the CHEC workers to the sites or location (next to KGVI School) was supposed to have started in January 31, 2020, however, it was moved to March 2021 (this month) due to the global (covid-19) pandemic. “The flight endorsed by OSC is supposed to pick up CHEC's foreign workers [24]. As soon as they get to Honiara work will start,” said Rodie. Secretary to Prime Minister (SPM) Dr Jimmie Rodgers early this week during the coronavirus (covid-19) ‘talk-back show’ said the 4th USP Campus to be constructed in Honiara “is one important project for the country”.

column31: VIRUS ALERT Opposition Leader calls on government to protect citizens from the spreading coronavirus, originated in China BY LORETTA BRIGIDIA MANELE While Solomon Islands is on high alert for Measles, another threat is being warned – the Corona-virus originated from China. Opposition Leader Matthew Wale is sounding the alarm, calling on the national government to start taking measures to ensure that the citizens of Solomon Islands are protected from the Coronavirus. Currently reports say that the virus is spreading around the globe, and fast. Health experts are cautioning countries not to take these warnings lightly. In an interview with Australia Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) this week, infectious disease physician at the University of Melbourne, Dr Irani Thevarajan, said the symptoms are “Cough, shortness of breath, rapid breathing, sore throat, runny nose. A bit like the presentation of the common cold but obviously more severe.” Just to give an illustration of how serious the current threat is, the previous deadly SARS and MERS viruses that killed thousands of people worldwide are types of coronavirus. In a statement yesterday, Opposition Leader Mr Wale calls on government to take preemptive steps through the Ministry of Health & Medical Services to protect Solomon Islands from the outbreak of the Wuhan Corona Virus from Wuhan, China. Wale stressed that with confirmed cases in other parts of the world, the country should take this threat seriously and start planning preventive measures. He said many confirmed cases have been reported by international media including one in Brisbane, Queensland, which is being closely monitored and China has confirmed that the virus can be transmitted from human to human. Wale urges the government to take preventative measures early so that passengers returning to the country after Chinese New Year celebrations in China who might have been exposed to the virus are identified, quarantined and dealt with appropriately. He also stated that anyone with symptoms of the virus who was recently in Wuhan should not be allowed to travel to Solomon Islands until they are cleared of the symptoms. “Recent measures taken against the measles outbreak, although perhaps were a bit late, were appropriate given the scale of the outbreak” said Wale. He emphasised that government should act now and quickly and take similar measures against the new threat. The Opposition Leader also calls on fellow Solomon Islanders, especially those traveling in and out of the country to take precautionary measures as they travel and stay safe.

column31: Public question kits and masks coming from China BY JENNIFER KUSAPA AMID fear of spreading covid-19 public has questioned Government on the quality of medical supplies coming from China. A concerned citizen Mr Johnson Mua said covid-19 originated from Wuhan in China and yet the Government is saying that testing kits will arrive in the country from China this week. While appreciating support from communist China, how sure and certain are we that the kits are not contaminated and will help Solomon Islanders conduct tests in the country accurately and safely? Mua asks. He said several countries around the world, for example Spain, have rejected kits from China for their low safety and accuracy levels. Just recently, Tonga cancelled an aircraft carrying medical supplies from China, he adds. With such reports, Mua questions why our government is not being vigilant towards having these China-supplies checked. Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare in his national address said testing kits from (PRC) will arrive next week and once these kits arrive, Solomon Islands will look at closing down the international entry airports. He said government understands international airports are possible entry points for COVID-19. On another news from the Government also said that China has expressed their commitment to provide support to the Government and people of Solomon Islands. A statement from the Embassy of the People’s Republic of China in Honiara stated Guangdong Province is now in the process of donating several thousand facial masks and a few hundred protective garments to Solomon Islands. Meanwhile the Minister of Health and Medical Services Dickson Mua confirmed that the test kits from China will arrive in the country sometimes this week. Mr Mua said Beijing Geonomics Institution BGI is the reliable company for lab sequencing. “They do quality work in the field of genomics and sequencing producing some good lab resources”, Mr Mua said. Mua said the flight from China will arrive in Brisbane last night and the kits are expected to arrive in the country today.

column31: GOVERNMENT FORMALIZED TRANSFER OF SINOPHARM VACCINES WITH PRC The signing of the transfer document certificate for the 50,000 Sinopharm Vaccine that arrived in the country last night took place in Honiara today. The transfer document certificate was signed between the Solomon Islands Government and the People’s Republic of China (PRC). Speaking at the signing ceremony, PRC Ambassador to Solomon Islands Li Ming acknowledged Solomon Islands for the continuous support in the fight against COVID 19. “The COVID 19 pandemic is still ravaging across the world, we can only defeat this pandemic by working in solidarity and in the process, vaccines are vital to win this battle,” He says. Ambassador Ming adds, China always uphold the vision of building a community with a shared future for mankind and a global community of health for all of us. He also acknowledged the Solomon Islands Government through the leadership of the Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare to keep Solomon Islands safe from COVID 19 community transmission. Minister of Health and Medical Services, Dr CulwickTogamana reiterated the government’s gratitude to PRC for the generous gift of 50,000 doses of the sinopharm vaccine. He says, the global pandemic has not made it easier to secure the COVID 19 Vaccines. “The global pandemic has not made it easier to secure COVID 19 vaccines this has led the Ministry of Health to accept the donation despite WHO’s process of reviewing the vaccine for its approval for its emergency use,” Mr Togamana says. The Health Minister adds, they are expecting WHO to approve the use of the Sinopharm vaccine soon. By Gina Maka'a

column31: Premier Mesepitu expresses concern over security deal. WESTERN Province Premier Christian Mesepitu says his government is deeply concerned with the proposed security treaty with China. In a statement yesterday, Mesepitu said the Government at no time consulted provincial premiers on the proposed security arrangement. “Like many other Solomon Islanders, we were only made aware of the security arrangement on social media, and we are indeed very concerned,” he said. “For contentious issues, the National Government has the moral responsibility towards its agents, as part of consultations, to talk to us, and in some situations, convince us of their position,” Mesepitu added. He said this is particular concerning when considering the uncertain impacts this new security treaty might have on the proposed patrol boat base in Shortland Islands. The premier said the patrol boat base in Shortland is key to our long-term development plan to improve trade, security and enhance the movement and traditional people to people relations at the western border. “The last thing we would want to see is this patrol boat project compromised as a result of geopolitical differences between our partners which will greatly impact the long-term development plan of the facility,” he said. The Western provincial premier also raised concerns on the question of Solomon Islands’ need to diversify its security when we have an existing regional security arrangement. He said that instead of diversifying security, the government should seriously think about pursuing its decentralization policy. Mesepitu said a lot of social and economical issues in the country emerged as a result of development being heavily focused in Honiara. “The lack of proper health care services, education and jobs are some of the pull factors that are causing more people to seek opportunities in Honiara which also resulted in a lot of social problems,” he said. Premier Mesepitu said decentralization should be the government’s priority policy rather than trying to diversify our security to protect us against our own citizens. “We should be focused on creating more opportunities and jobs for our people in the provinces, enhance capacity building and human resources to help develop our provincial centres. “In line of that, more powers must be given to provinces to manage its own affairs. It is a hard ask but we need to make critical decisions and start somewhere,” he said. Meanwhile, the Western Premier also expressed concern over the recent leaked diplomatic correspondence requesting arms for an embassy by a development partner. “We do not need guns to protect us or drive our development ambitions. “We need to set our house in order and deal with our own internal problems not by way of guns but empowering our people and making good economic policies that will benefit our country,” he said.

column31: The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has stepped in to help Solomon Islands in the fight to contain the spread of community transmission of the corona virus following urgent discussions with the Honiara government on the weekend. The first shipment of urgent medical supplies will arrive next week by a Chinese government cargo flight, the Chinese Embassy in Honiara announced in a press statement issued overnight. The first shipment of urgent assistance from China includes: Humanitarian funding of USD $320,000 (SBD $2,560,000); - 50,000 doses of SinoPharm vaccines; - 51,200 packs of disposable syringe (with needle); - 20,000 rapid antigen test kits (FAT); - PPEs and medical supplies; and - 50 units of 5 to 6 meter-tent kits for field hospital’s makeshift buildings - Field hospital tent kits are to be shipped by sea shortly, the statement said.

column31: Market vendors to wear facemasks By CHARLES KADAMANA MARKET vendors at the Honiara Central Market will soon be issued with facemasks as prevention measure to protect the country from covid-19. Honiara City Council City Clerk, Rence Sore confirmed this when receiving 3,000 masks from China Harbour Engineering Company Ltd yesterday. Sore said the donation of masks came at the right time as HCC is discussing a contingency plan to combat covid-19. He said one of the plans is to control the movement of people at the market and distribute facemasks to the vendors. He said central market is operating at the heart of the city and as such population of market vendors is huge and that social distancing is not controlled. He said each day there are more than 1000 vendors selling their products so it is important for market vendors to use masks. At the same time, he encourages customers doing their shopping at the market to wear masks. He said the other plan is to fast track the completion of Kukum market so that some of them can be shifted to Kukum to sell their products. Sore said by doing that it would help the council assist market vendors practise social distancing. Currently 85 percent of the building is now completed. Market master Nelson Sakui said once they finalise all arrangement, they will start distributing the masks to the market vendors. He said market vendors who use the central market fulltime will have to use mask. Meanwhile, Sore acknowledges China Harbour for displaying its social responsibility by donating the facemasks. He said the council will use them to the maximum and good use for the benefit of the people. Sore added the donation will supplement other supplies donated by the People Republic of China. Acting General Manager Jinxing Yin said they are happy to support the city council with its contingency plan because they saw a lot of people going to the market every day. He said the donation is part of their social responsibility to give back to the community. Yin added he hopes to donate further in the future.

column31: MANELE OFF TO BEIJING The Foreign Affairs Minister Jeremiah Manele is on his way to Beijing to execute the draft Communique and Memorandum of Understanding with his People's Republic of China counterpart on behalf of their governments. Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare told SIBC News this afternoon, processes to formalise the relationship with the People's Republic of China begun following the Cabinet and Caucus decision to recognise 'One China Policy'. Prime Minister Sogavare said, the draft communique and Memorandum to be signed between Honiara and Beijing in the coming days are as approved by Cabinet. Mr. Sogavare explains, with the 2020 annual budget and Solomon Islands' presentation at the United Nations General Assembly next week, a decision was essential to ensure proper planning for 2020 Development priorities and preserve our integrity in the international community. He emphasises, the decision by Cabinet to acknowledge the UN Resolution 2758 of 1971 requires the Government to sever diplomatic relations with the Republic of China, Taiwan. He says, the switch however does not affect the people to people relationship, cultural exchanges, Trade relations and investment between Solomon Islands and Taiwan. A statement by the Prime Minister on this will be aired this Sunday at 5:30pm, repeat 9:30pm on the National Voice. by Leni Dalavera

column31: ‘STOP CHINA FLIGHT’ Democratic Party calls on government to rethink its risky plan amid covid-19 PRESIDENT of the Solomon Islands Democratic Party (SIDP) Dr Alice Pollard has called on the Prime Minister and his cabinet to reconsider the timing of the planned flight to China and Philippines. The likelihood of the risk this trip poses to our health, wellbeing and livelihood is still high with regards to the covid-19 pandemic. This call comes after it was confirmed in the local media that the proposed direct flight to China will eventuate, despite the widespread opposition against it. Sharing her experience in quarantine as one of the returning nationals from New Zealand in one of the earlier repatriation flights, the SIDP President points out, Solomon Islands is nowhere close to being prepared to handle any outbreak of the covid-19 if it does enter. “Upon my return home from New Zealand, I went through its quarantine process and did the same again when I got back into the country. “I must admit that I am seriously worried, because a country with one of the best healthcare systems in the world, also resourced with highly trained health personnel, strong leadership, well organised team, modern technology and fully well-equipped are still experiencing a second wave of infections. This also seems to be the case for other developed countries. “Comparing theirs to our health system, along with the current level of our preparedness, I must add that we are still highly vulnerable, hence should be doing everything we can to avert any risk of importing the virus,” says Mrs Pollard. The SIDP President suggests that the government should prioritise the protection of our people above all else and not do anything to compromise that protection. “It is regrettable therefore that even with our obvious limitations, the government is still proceeding with plans for the PG2023. “This just does not make sense in light of the uncertain future covid-19 holds for the whole world. “Why should we take the risk just to run the Pacific Games programmes when according to World Health Organisation’s latest report on the future status of the virus, it will not go away until after two years’ time?” Pollard questioned. “I therefore strongly urge the Prime Minister to listen to the people and let us not do anything that we will live to regret later.” Solomon Islands Democratic Party is a member of the current Parliamentary Opposition Coalition group. --SIDP PRESS

column31: CHINA is stepping up its efforts to help countries in the South Pacific, including Solomon Islands, countries that Beijing has diplomatic relations with. Details of the areas of cooperation were given by State Councilor and Foreign Minister Wang Yi who also chaired the China-Pacific Island Countries Foreign Ministers Meeting on 21st October via video-link. Those who attended were the President and Foreign Minister Taneti Maamau of Kiribati, Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Fiji Josaia Voreqe Bainimarama, Prime Minister of Tonga Pohiva Tu’I’onetoa, Niue’s Premier and Foreign Minister Dalton Tagelagi, Foreign Minister of Papua New Guinea Soroi Eoe, Foreign Minister of Vanuatu Mark Ati, Foreign Minister of the Federated States of Micronesia Kandhi A. Elieisar, Foreign Minister of Solomon Islands Jeremiah Manele, representative of Samoa’s Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Strickland, and Secretary General of the Pacific Islands Forum Henry Puna attended the meeting. A statement issued after the meeting said Wang Yi told the discussion President Xi Jinping held a collective meeting with leaders of the PICs having diplomatic ties with China in November 2018. “They agreed to establish a comprehensive strategic partnership based on mutual respect and common development, which heralded the new era of all-round cooperation. The relations between China and PICs have set an example of friendly exchanges, solidarity and cooperation for countries in different regions and with different sizes, and systems,” the statement said. Read more: https://bit.ly/CHN-stps-Up:=:https://www.solomonstarnews.com/china-steps-up-its-efforts-to-help-pacific-island-countries/

column31: China flight strongly opposed By EDDIE OSIFELO THE Opposition and Independent Group have opposed Government’s move to allow Solomon Airlines flight to China on 29th August. Minister of Foreign Affairs and External Trade, Jeremiah Manele has confirmed in Parliament on Wednesday night that the planned direct flight to China and return to Honiara is chartered by the Chinese government. Manele said the PRC government is chartering Solomon Airlines to bring their diplomats and contractors to commence work on infrastructures for the Pacific Games in 2023. Among the confirmed passengers is China’s ambassador to Solomon Islands. All the passengers arriving on the flight will have to provide medical clearance of where they come from and when they arrive in Honiara will undergo mandatory quarantine. However, Independent Leader, John Dean Kuku queried if it is safe to organise flights from Brisbane and the proposed flight to and from China. “Why are we so concerned about the Western region borders and Bougainville?” Kuku asked. “Our people are moving in and out of Bougainville which at this moment is still covid-19 free compared to Australia and China which are not and therefore pose major risks to Solomon Islands,” he added. “We need to be consistent with the management and operational side of the Regulations.” Kuku said the Regulations should be advancing our cause to stop the pandemic coming into Solomon Islands and not impede our efforts to stop the risk. In addition, member of Opposition Group, Rick Hou said in this state of confusion, some government actions have seriously undermined its own policy and statements on the fight against COVID-19. “On one hand the government is telling our people of the danger from the virus and that it spreads through people, especially those coming from overseas; including China, where it all started. “The PM in moving the motion this morning (Tuesday), he reiterated further that the safety of our population takes priority over all else. “This is why the Government - through this Motion - is now asking Parliament to approve a new SOPE due to the continuing public health risk from the pandemic,” he said. “On the other hand, I understand the Government is now well advanced in arranging a special Solomon Airlines flight to pick 19 Chinese nationals, direct from China, into Solomon Islands to work on the PG 2023. “The delivery of an important project as the PG 2023 is a good call, but is it worth taking the risk? “The Government would like us to believe that China is now a low risk country – how can you be sure about?” Hou asked. The MP for Small Malaita and former Prime Minister said sending a Solomon Airlines aircraft and crew to China seems to him as too much of a gamble. “If that flight proceeded with it, it runs directly opposite to Government policy and would undermine government, steps needed to safeguard our people from the COVID-19 being introduced into our country. “Even if China was declared corona-virus-free (which it is not), the aircraft has to stop somewhere on its route to and from China. “How is the Government so sure that where the aircraft and its crew will stop is also corona free? “I cannot see how the Government, on one hand, is adamant that Solomon Islands remains very vulnerable to the virus – and therefore the urgency for Parliament to approve a new SOPE – while on the other hand, still prepared to take such a high risk action as this planned flight. “This is not the right message as to how the Government is fighting the virus. “So far the only luck we have had is that no infected person has entered the country as yet,” he said. Hou said on the importance of the PG2023, they know there are other more important, and bigger sporting events such as the Olympic Games, that had to be postponed, as a result of the pandemic. “What is so important and critical to this country about PG2023 that it cannot be postponed? “I think this is not only a bad idea, but in our current circumstances, it is a very risky one for the well-being of our people. “Additionally, proceeding with this flight will further undermine public confidence in government’s seriousness to deal with the virus and its efforts to ensure Solomon Islands remain corona-free,” he said.

column31: Malaita Health needs covid-19 kits: Dr Kako BY SAMIE WAIKORI AUKI POLITICS aside, Malaita needs medical kits which had been supplied by China, says Dr Henry Kako, director of the province’s health authority. Mr Kako, who is also chairman of Malaita Provincial Health Emergency Operation Committee (PHEOC), in an interview yesterday said he is aware of a plan to stage a peaceful protest against distributing the kits to Malaita. But, he says, the reality is Malaita needs those kits and this is one of those times where politics must be put aside for the sake of lives which are at stake. “Plans are in place and Malaita province will definitely receive the kits. We have process in place to clear the kits as consignment made for the safety of the kits. “Checks must thoroughly be done on the equipment to the extent that we are satisfied with it before distribution will happen. “So there shouldn’t be no fear on these received covid-19 supply kits from China. “People may question the quality of the PPEs as they came from China and covid-19 started in Wuhan, China, but let the kits subjected to checks. “If the kits are check and we satisfy, there won’t be no fear. And we really need the kits as preparation is mounting for this covid-19,” he said. On that note, Kako said Malaita province will receive the kits. He said MHMS prioritised distributing kits to Western and Choiseul provinces and Shortland Islands because they are the second emergency zone in the country. Dr Kako said this is because Papua New Guinea is currently with eight cases and there is risk that covid-19 may enter through the SI-PNG border. “So MHMS only disbursed kits to these areas including NRH as listed being in a red zone according to this state of emergency and covid-19 high risk criteria. “Other places or provinces are at the moment listed as medium or low risk and supplies will not yet prioritise for them. “But in a event where case is declared in the country, all provinces will be listed as red zone or high risk and supplies will distribute to all provinces,” he said.

column31: Solomon airlines to operate between Guangzhou and Honiara BY BARNABAS MANEBONA SOLOMON Airlines will operate two private charter flights between Honiara and Guangzhou (China) today and tomorrow, September 1 and 2. This goes with the approval of the Solomon Islands Government according to Solomon Airlines. From Solomon Airlines Public Relations (PR) Office, the Airbus A320 services will transport approved foreign nationals and bring home stranded Solomon Islands citizens. “All passengers travelling on the flights have been approved by permission of the Prime Minister’s Office. Every passenger will be subject to strict COVID 19 requirements including providing proof of negative COVID 19 testing prior to boarding, in accordance with Government regulations,” said Solomon Airlines Public Relations. “The charter operation will first operate from Honiara to Guangzhou on Tuesday 1st September [today] returning again from Guangzhou to Honiara on Wednesday 2nd September [tomorrow]. The aircraft will stop briefly in Biak, Indonesia, in both directions for fuel, with no passengers or crew disembarking the aircraft. “On Thursday 3rd September, flight IE601 will return from Honiara to Brisbane, departing 12.00pm and arriving 2:15pm. Limited seats will be available on this service to those who have the relevant approvals to stay or transit in Australia, and subject to Border Force and quarantine requirements. “Those interested in knowing more about the services are advised to contact the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and External Trade (MFAET) or their nearest Solomon Islands Mission. “All Solomon Airlines charter and repatriation flights comply with the COVID-19 regulations and requirements of the relevant countries. Solomon Airlines crew wear facemasks and gloves for duration of service and catering is minimal to reduce contact between passengers and crew.” The Government’s move to allow Solomon Airlines flight despite being heavily opposed by the general public in the country amidst Covid-19 Pandemic fear has raised eyebrows over such action. It was reported yesterday from last Sunday’s Weekly Talk-Back-Show that the flight returning will bring in a total of 88 personnel into the country.
