column31: CHINESE MONEY CLAIMS Maelanga denies allegation of attempting to bribe Malaita leaders to topple Suidani-gov’t By EDDIE OSIFELO DEPUTY Prime Minister Manasseh Maelanga has denied allegation that he carried a large amount of money to Auki on Tuesday night to lobby Malaita Provincial Assembly members to leave Premier Daniel Suidani. The Premier’s Political Advisor, Celsus Talifilu posted this on social media that the move is being made so that China can enter Malaita and force it to submit. Talifilu alleged that Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare has sent DPM Maelanga with orders and a big amount of Chinese money to ensure this happens as soon as possible to allow Chinese takeover. He said some Government members of Parliament from Honiara had informed Auki that Maelanga is on a mission to bribe MPAs for a no-confidence motion on Premier Suidani. However, Maelanga told Island Sun that he was shocked to learn of the allegations. “Rubbish,” he retorted when asked about the allegation. “I never visit Auki Township upon arrival but travel straight to my constituency in East Malaita from Gwounaru’u airport,” he said. The Deputy Prime Minister yesterday met with the Council, which consists of various leaders of the communities in the constituency. Maelanga will hand over school materials to Foumamanu Community High School today and visit the deteriorating roads in East Malaita following the recent rainfall. He is expected to arrive in Honiara on Friday. Earlier, Premier Suidani said his camp was rock solid because the population in Malaita is backing them. Suidani said this was evident when the Ministry of Provincial Government and Institutional Strengthening wanted to recall Provincial Secretary Fredrick Fa’abasua and it led to protests in Auki. “How much more if the Premier is removed?” he said. Suidani said the proposed motion of no confidence planned against him died its natural death because the Malaita population is behind MARA government. He said is government’s numerical strength will be back to normal after other MPAs are expected to arrive from Malaita Outer Islands yesterday. There are 33 wards in Malaita. Speaker of Malaita Provincial Assembly, Ronnie Butala said his office has not received any notice of motion of no confidence.

column31: An outspoken Civil Activist Lawrence Makili has called on the Solomon Islands Government to explain its position in regards to its citizens who are stranded in China due to the Coronavirus outbreak. Makili said the outbreak and current status of the virus has caused flight restrictions which also cause challenges for the Solomon Islands citizens especially those traveling on business tour who are now stranded. He said the most supportive neighbouring countries like Australia and New Zealand have already on to their planning strategy on evacuating their citizens out from China. “Their planning involves the set-up of quarantine processes for the citizens as part of the evacuation process,” he said. He said close neighbour PNG sought assistance from Aussie and New Zealand and were also supported as well as Fiji. Makili said currently more than 20 Solomon Islanders are in China and what can the government do about them given the flight restrictions and the threats to the Coronavirus. Read more..http://bit.ly/deal-stdnts:=:http://www.solomonstarnews.com/index.php/news/national/item/22739-deal-with-stranded-locals-in-china

column31: Government seized medical equipment, Malaita wants to know why THE provincial government of Malaita is questioning government and its institutions why medical equipment bound for the province have been seized. In a media statement yesterday, Malaita provincial government says, “Essential humanitarian medical equipment bound for Malaita to fight covid-19 was reportedly seized by police on Thursday. In a secret action, the equipment was seized from customs without warrant or explanation despite the fact that the import duty was paid and cleared by the Customs and Exercise Division. When customs officers sought legal basis for this, none was given and the equipment was taken away by the Police. The equipment was donated on humanitarian grounds by Republic of China and shipped to a Malaitan person who was going to donate them to Malaita Province. MARA Government calls on the Commissioner of Police and Attorney General to explain what legal basis was used to hold up this life saving equipment. The equipment included one set of Thermal Image Camera plus monitor and 2 Thermal temperature cameras to check people for fevers on entry to Malaita, and was specifically donated to assist with fighting covid-19. This appears to be a direct action against the fight of covid-19 in Malaita the most populated province of Solomon Islands. It is also an action that is contrary to the purpose for which a State of Public Emergency is declared. “We would like to know: Why is lifesaving equipment for Malaita held up when it is to fight covid-19? We know that a whole range of limitations to Constitutional Rights and Freedoms have been put on the people of Solomon Islands in the name of covid-19, including closing of boarders. However, exemptions have been made for the arrival of supplies from PRC and others. But when there is covid-19 equipment donated to Malaita, the DCGA based on advice from the AG has ordered the Police to seize it. This looks like it is an action against the public health of Malaitans, and against the justifiable purpose of the State of Public Emergency. The Malaita Provincial Government would like to see that the Commissioner of Police and the Attorney General quickly resolve this matter so as to ensure the equipment are freed.

column31: PRIME Minister Manasseh Sogavare has outlined key achievements of the Democratic Coalition Government for Advancement (DCGA) since taking office in 2019. Speaking during the OUR Party Convention on Tuesday this week, the Party Wing Leader said OUR Party has achieved a lot for the country in its current term in office under the DCGA. “We have delivered a lot in redirecting our resources to support our people in the rural areas, in line with our Party manifesto and objectives,” he said. The Prime Minister said Our Party as the largest single political party in the history of Solomon Islands has 36 members of parliament. The party wing leader said OUR Party continue to remain focus to its mandate in delivering to the people and improving their livelihood with the support of donor partners, according to the ideals and principles of the Party. “One notable policy achievement we have made since taking office in 2019 under the DCGA was the normalization of Diplomatic Relations with the Peoples Republic of China (PRC) in line with UN Resolution 2578 of 1971,” he said. Mr Sogavare said since the establishment of Diplomatic Relations, Solomon Islands and PRC have achieved a lot in a short span of time, most notably, the construction of the stadiums for the Pacific Games 2023. Prime Minister Sogavare said other notable achievements by the Party and DCGA are in the areas of Education, Aviation and Communication, Tourism, Fisheries Rural Development, and Infrastructure, to name a few. Read more...

column31: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO WALE: Wale Spreads Lies, promotes Non-procedural and Unlawful Behaviour The Leader of opposition is hereby advised by the Solomon Islands Government not to mislead or confuse the Public on the China-Taiwan issue as related to the Malaita Premier. This statement was made following the Opposition leader’s publication in today’s paper. The Solomon Islands Government is appalled by the comments of the Leader of Official Opposition. A statement from the Solomon Islands Government said, “this is the first time, a Leader of the Official Opposition and a very senior Member of Parliament, openly advocates for a breach of our laws in which as a legislator, he should instead be protecting and advocating for strict compliance.” “It must be noted that the letter by the Minister for Provincial Government and Institutional Strengthening (MPGIS) to the Malaita Premier is an internal matter by virtue of the Provincial Government Act 1997 and does not constitute any political motivations to suspend the Provincial Government.” “Hon. Wale knows that by law, all Provincial Governments are required to act in a manner that complies with the Provincial Government Act 1997 and Malaita Provincial Government is no exception,” the statement added. By promoting and inducing a contravention of an Act, such actions are bordering as a criminal offence including sedition and this is a matter for Police to investigate. Hon. Wale was ultimately advocating for all Provincial Governments to disregard legal obligations and expects the national Government to turn a blind eye. The Statement clarifies that the Minister’s letter to the Premier of Malaita Province is an internal matter, which outlines the various contraventions of the Premier and advising the Hon. Premier to take corrective measures in regards to compliance with the PGA 1997. The MPGIS Minister also advised that non-alignment of the Premier’s action to the National Government’s preparedness and emergency response priorities, potentially undermines public order and poses a risk to our national security with regards to the fight against COVID19 which requires intervention of the National Government. Non-compliance and breaches to the Provincial Government Act can result in consequences that includes the suspension of the Provincial Government under the Provincial Government Act. This is a matter of the application of law and not politics. The letter does not in any way call for a suspension of the Malaita Provincial Government and that must be made clear. It is unfortunate that certain media elements and the opposition leader are treating the matter as if the Malaita Provincial Government will be suspended or dissolved any moment from now. Mr. Wale’s outburst and wrongful assertion to the media releases is provocative, speculative and does not reflect well on him as a senior leader. Mr. Wale has quickly jumped to conclusions and rhetorically came up with irrational theories and ideologies that are designed to create disharmony and confusion in our communities. More so to provoke animosity against the Government during this critical state of emergency period to safeguard our nation from the threat of COVID-19. The Emergency Powers (COVID-19) Regulations creates offences for such publications and as stated above, will be a matter for Police to investigate. Further, in the call for the recent Premiers meeting, the Honorable Minister expected all Premiers to attend this important meeting in Honiara. The matter was to discuss measures concerning Government’s preparedness and responsiveness to the COVID-19 pandemic. Whilst, all Premiers attended, the Malaita Premier failed to attend citing attendance at an awareness program at his ward/community and therefore sending only his Deputy, however, he apparently arrived in Honiara the following day after the closing of the Premiers’ meeting. In a matter of significant national interest, it is expected that all commitments by all Premiers are to be set aside and their attendance as being paramount to the national interest. The Minister’s letter also called for dialogue with Provincial Governments. After the completion of the Premiers meeting in 23rd of April 2020, the minister also sent over through a circular on the limitations of powers, responsibility and expectations from the Provinces in the joint fight against the spread of the COVID-19. The Minister continuous to call for support in this regard from the provinces. It is surprising that the opposition leader continues to look for issues to arouse fear and resentment among members of the Public. The statement further added that the Hon. Opposition leader need to validate his sources firstly before misleading and spreading lies to the public at large. Hon. Wale stated in his media statement that in 2017 former Premiers of Guadalcanal, Malaita and Western Province did not obtain permission before taking overseas trips. These visits were made with the (truncated)

column31: LEAVE NO ONE BEHIND Sogavare’s DCGA government promises to find other ways to help the blocked five Malaita constituencies BY ALFRED PAGEPITU Government has played down outcry over blocking five Malaita constituencies from China-funded component of the rural constituency development fund (RCDF). In its media statement yesterday, the democratic coalition government for advancement (DCGA) said it is “fully committed to ensure that all constituencies in the country benefit from the Rural Constituency Development Fund (RCDF).” DCGA claims that it will not allow politics to get in the way of its commitment to “serve the best interest of all citizens of this nation”. Although DCGA is shying away from directly answering the question of what would happen to the five Malaitan constituencies it has blocked, it holds up its “leave no one behind” motto, which indicates that it may have other plans for these five. DCGA says it “believes and stands by its moral values and obligation to execute the RCDF program to ensure people from all our constituencies benefit”. “The government is now exploring how best to ensure the RCDF for the five remaining constituencies can be channelled to address the development needs and aspirations of the people in these constituencies.” On Tuesday, December 3, Caucus decided to block Aoke-Langalanga, East and West Are’are, Small Malaita and Central Kwaraae constituencies from receiving 30 percent of the total RCDF, which is the portion funded by communist China. The other 70 percent is footed by our taxpayers. This action by government is reportedly to “punish” these five constituencies for supporting the Malaita provincial government in its adamant stand against DCGA and its pro-China agenda. Public has since then been shaking their heads over this quite unprecedented move by government, many labeling it as a signature of a communist regime. Members of the opposition group have also appealed to national government to re-think its “childish” and “immoral” decision. DCGA’s latest response is vague on how the five constituencies will receive fundings. In DCGA’s media statement, it speaks on behalf of the government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC), saying that PRC “wishes to ensure its support to Solomon Islands reaches all our people”.

column31: Leaders of some of the Honiara based Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) in a meeting organized and held at the Solomon Islands National Council of Women last week, has condemned the proposed action of the Honourable Minister of Finance and Treasury, Mr. Harry Kuma, for attempting to solicit the $100USD Billion from China, without prior consultation with the Central Bank of Solomon Islands as reported in the Solomon Islands print media. A spokesperson from the Solomon Islands National Council of Women on behalf of the CSO leaders attending the meeting, said, that they have noted the action by the Minister in his official capacity as serious, violating the Public Finance Act of Solomon Islands. CSO Leaders also felt that his action is a breach of his Oath of Allegiance as Minister of the Crown, not been loyal to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, and in performing his duties of not protecting and serving the interest of Solomon Islands Citizens and the nation. CSO Leaders kindly requested the Minister to apologize to the nation on behalf of the DCGA Government because of the intended cause of action he took with the Broker by the name of Mr. Wong, to deal with few Businessmen in China for the purpose of lending to the Solomon Islands Government the total sum of $100USD Billion. This is a total breach of his Oath and Allegiance and therefore, should do the right thing by apologizing to the nation. Solomon Islands as a sovereign nation must follow protocols in dealing with such serious loan matters on government to government basis and not using middlemen with a predetermined 11% heavy interest fee, which will benefit only a few cronies to become Billionaires overnight if the Loan proposal is to be materialized. The Solomon Islands Government does not have the capacity to mortgage such a huge loan, and therefore will commit all Solomon Islands individual citizen, tribal land with its minerals and sea resources thus setting a new suicidal debt trap for all Solomon Islanders and our future generations to come. column31: Wale suggests options to contain covid-19 By EDDIE OSIFELO OPPOSITION Leader, Matthew Wale has suggested options if the coronavirus (covid-19) is not in the country. Speaking on the motion in Parliament to approve State of Public Emergency and for its continuation in the next four months, Wale said government should ban all international flights into the country, except for cargo and samples for tests (until testing can be done in-country). He also suggested regular tests for air crew who will be in isolation whilst in country and baggage handlers at Henderson. Wale said there should be appropriate isolation/quarantine for incoming international shipping freighters. “Economy needs to keep functioning to provide jobs and incomes for families. However, the PM’s hope that donor funded projects be brought forward may not be feasible, as it would involve mobility of labour,” he said. “Further, it is important to note that the spread of the coronavirus from China to other countries followed Chinese workers returning to those countries to work. “We must learn from that experience,” he said. Wale said the Pacific games construction project may be affected by this, if it will require Chinese workers. He said Government must not take the risk of importing covid-19 through foreign workers. “Our national security and public health safety cannot be compromised even for the Pacific games. Some pre-emptive planning must now commence to consider postponement of the games,” he said. Further to that, Wale said public service needs to keep operating to provide support services to the private sector to keep the economy functioning. He said the Public Service Memo dated 31st March 2020 should be withdrawn. 1. Ban on flights may only be lifted once source/destination cities/countries have demonstrated sustained reductions in the number of coronavirus infections. 2. In such an event, all travellers into the country must: a) obtain medical report confirming lack of covid-19 infection within 4 days prior to travel, and b) be quarantined on arrival for 14 days. 3. All Solomon Islands citizens abroad, including students, wishing to return must comply with 4 above. SIG to pay for tests for its sponsored students. 4. Quarantine facilities must be fit for purpose to not become fertile ground for the spreading of the coronavirus. Wale said conversely, the government could enter into dialogue with Australia to beg that Solomon Islands students be quarantined in their detention facilities on Christmas Island. He said this would work for our students in Philippines, if a decision was taken to evacuate them. Wale said all citizens with no jobs or business interests in Honiara to be urged to leave for their villages. “Ideally, all these should be tested for covid-19 to ensure the virus is not unwittingly spread to the provinces. “Close and police the border with Bougainville. “Set up lab to conduct all tests in-country,” he said. Wale said procure new test kits recently approved by the US FDA that takes 2 mins to get results.

column31: WALE CLARIFIES MEETING IN AUKI By Mike Puia The Leader of the parliamentary opposition group, Mathew wale, used the Sine Die motion moved by Prime Minister, Manasseh Sogavare, on Monday night to clarify issues surrounding his group’s attendance in a meeting in Auki. The meeting, called by the Premier of Malaita Province, was an attempt to bring the 14 Malaita Members of Parliament to discuss issues around the government’s switch diplomatic ties to China over Taiwan. Only five Malaita MPs in the opposition group attended the meeting. Malaita MPs in the government were blocked by the government. The five opposition MPs’ response to the invitation to attend the meeting cost their constituencies. This is when the government blocked the five Malaita constituencies whose MPs attended the meeting from receiving the China-funded component of the Constituency Development Fund. Wale told parliament on Tuesday that the position by the Malaita provincial government against the switch to China is the Malaita provincial government’s opposition. He said the position of the Malaita provincial government is based on the fact that no political party sought a mandate to switch to China during national general elections. Wale said the decision by the Malaita provincial government was based on the Prime Minister’s promise to consult all constituencies and leave no stone unturned prior to making a decision which did not eventuated. He said the Malaita provincial government and most in the province does not accept being told after the decision to switch to China was made. Wale said the provincial government and its people were hoping to be consulted prior to making the decision but that did not happen. “These issues have caused them to feel disempowered, disenfranchised and deceived,” the MP for Aoke-Langalanga said. He said this is a reasonable position. Wale revealed during the meeting in Auki they informed the Malaita full provincial assembly that the meeting must not issue a communiqué as all 14 Malaita MPs need to listen to the issues raised. He said no communiqué was issued during their meeting. Wale said the communiqué that came out after their meeting belongs to the provincial government. He revealed the situation in Auki was tense and during a public meeting many people expressed their desired for the government to reverse its decision to switch to China. Wale noted there was strong sentiment expressed to have the Prime Minister resigned if the government failed to reverse its decision. He denied rallying the public in Auki to travel to Honiara and demanded the resignation of the Prime Minister. Wale said this is far from the truth. ‘In fact, I told the meeting they have the constitutional right to peaceful protest as violence has no place in political process and that violence will not achieve anything. Peaceful protest is good and nothing the government should be worried about,” Wale said. He said allowing peaceful protest is good for the country to allow citizens expressing their desire. Wale said once peaceful protests are continued to be denied, the grievances of the public will piled up and once overflow leads to violence. He said Malaita’s desire for independence is a “direct reaction” to the ongoing “deceptive decision making process” of the government. Wale said Malaitans are fade-up of being fooled. He said this is a sentiment many Malaitans expressed which holds some truth in it. Wale said his group is merely carrying out its duty as watchdog of the government’s decisions, indecisions, actions and lack of actions. He said there is nothing personal in the criticisms his group have raised. Wale stated the government recognize and respect constructive criticisms.

column31: WILL SOLOMON ISLANDS CANCEL 2023 PG? By Taromane Martin Is the government and stake holders going to ask for the 2023 Pacific Games in Honiara to be cancelled? That is the question hanging over Solomon Islands preparations to host the games in 2023. With the coronavirus pandemic making things even more difficult for facilities constructions or athletes’ preparations to start due to the worldwide travel restrictions, critics are saying it is not worth it now and the government should not continue to pursue this especially with the country’s economy struggling to stay afloat. The government through the Sol2023 National Hosting Authority is set to review the stadiums and facilities progress in October according to Solomon Islands Pacific Games Association Chairman Martin Rara. Mr Rara said once the review with all stake holders involved in the 2023 Pacific Games preparations is done then the Sol 2023 National Hosting Authority will make an announcement on the matter. “At this time the thing we should look at before we make any decision is work on the facilities are they progressing. “When work commences then we will be able to project or make an estimation as to when and if we will still be able to host the games in 2023. “However, I cannot say or tell you the date or any decision regarding postponing the date for the hosting of the games in Honiara. “Additional updates on the matter will be known after October when NHA will make a review on the progress of the constructions of the facilities. “At this time any decision to postpone the 2023 Pacific Games will be deliberated and made by and only the Sol2023 National Hosting Authority board,” he said. SunSPORTS recently had contacted NHA for response whether the option of pulling out from hosting the games is now on the table especially with the COVID-19 pandemic causing a setback for the constructions of facilities. So far no response is yet to be received. However, NHA Chief Executive Officer, Christian Nieng had confirmed work is progressing on site and that facilities constructions will start after the UXO exercise on clearing the sites is completed by the end of this month. “The UXO work is on-going. Final reports expected by end of the month to prepare for PRC design work to start. “The Geo-Tech work has already started however these sites need to be cleared from UXO first before they do the Geo-Tech can resume,” Nieng said. The Pacific Games Council (PGC) last month had been forced to postpone next year’s Mini Pacific Games in the Northern Marianas to 2022 due to the pandemic. Despite the cancellation of the 2021 Mini games, PGC Chief Executive Officer Andrew Minogue had told SunSPORTS that they are going to continue to monitor and keeping a close eye on the situation. “The Pacific Games Council is pleased to note the progress Solomon Islands Government and the National Hosting Authority are continuing to make in securing the necessary donor arrangements to deliver the venues on time for the 2023 Pacific Games. “The PGC continues to monitor the situation closely watching developments in the making,” Mr Minogue had said. Meanwhile lead advisor to the National Hosting Authority, Clint Flood also admitted that they had not expected Covid-19 to impact the construction timeline at this stage. He said while the feeling in Solomon Islands remained positive, officials were preparing themselves for all possibilities and should have a better idea of the overall picture in a couple of months’ time. Flood, who himself was working remotely from his home in Canada, said even though Covid-19 had put a stop on international travel, work was continuing in China and the National Hosting Authority was in constant contact with its donor partners. Flood said all of the Pacific Games facilities were scheduled to be completed by the end of 2022 but with the competition not taking place until July 2023, there was some room to move. Provided all venues were ready to handover by the end of March 2023, Clint Flood said Solomon Islands' first ever Pacific Games would be good to go.

column31: All China passengers test negative before boarding: Gov’t ALL 104 passengers who arrived from China last night tested negative to covid-19 before boarding the plane, government says. A statement from National Disaster Council (NDC) said that prior to boarding, all incoming passengers conducted three sets of covid-19 tests which were sent to SIG-Oversight Committee covid-19 response and the Ministry of Health to determine their health status for approval. “These tests were conducted days prior to undertaking the journey. “All results turn out negative which gives the greenlight to board the special flight,” the statement said. The statement also clarified that a risk-assessment was conducted which categorised China as ‘low risk’- record of low virus infections. Camp Management Sector and supporting agencies are prepared to receive the arrivals. “Upon arrival, they should provide the latest proof of their negative tests and taken to government-managed Quarantine Stations (QSs). “Whilst in quarantine, all passengers are required to undergo another swab test within the first 48 hours and 2 additional tests for duration of the 14-days quarantine period,” the statement said adding that it all depending on health monitoring, there is possibility for extension of their stay beyond the mandated 14-days. For Solomon Islands, the norm for all repatriation flights; incoming passengers are advised to wear facemasks, hygiene practices on the flight and during disembarkation to the stations. NDC statement said that currently, a total of 21 returning nationals are half-way through to completion of their 14-days quarantine period. They are part of the batch of returnees repatriated last week. “Arrivals on this first China flight will be accommodated in hotels isolated from the current returnees. “All Standard Operating Procedures are adhered to ensuring there is no breach of the quarantine rules as set out in the regulations. “The Camp Management, Health Surveillance and Clinical teams will ensure that there is zero contact between the quarantine persons,” the statement said. 21 Solomon Islands nationals are amongst these incoming passengers. The rest are foreigners who will be engaged in the SP Games 2023 facility preparations and diplomatic officials of Peoples Republic of China recently established embassy office here. So far, more than 800 nationals and dozens of foreign nationals (exempted for essential service support) have entered the country since the first declared State of Public Emergency in March 24th. To this date, the country’s Solomon Airlines has conducted a total of 8 repatriation flights to neighbouring Pacific Island countries. Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS) continues to lead the Government’s multi-sectoral approach to stem COVID-19 infiltration on our shores. All government agencies and stakeholders are providing the required support through the National Disaster Operations Committee (N-DOC) and Provincial Disaster Operations Committee (P-DOC) Sectors. --NDC PRESS

column31: Malaitans protest gov’t decision to recall PS By EDDIE OSIFELO ABOUT 200 people took the streets of Malaita provincial capital Auki yesterday to protest the recall of Provincial Secretary Fredrick Fa’abasua to Honiara. Mr Fa’abasua received his letter from Ministry of Provincial Government and Institutional Strengthening permanent secretary, Stanley Pirione on Sunday 9pm, informing him to stop work and immediately return to Honiara due to workloads in the ministry. Provincial Police Commander, Stanley Riolo confirmed the protest and his officers being on the ground to monitor it. Mr Riolo said the situation can turn worse if the government does not respond to protesters’ demand to allow Fa’abasua to continue his job in Auki. But MPGIS PS Pirione said it is a normal thing to recall provincial secretaries back to the headquarters because they work under the ministry. He said PS Fa’abasua was recalled due to pressing issues facing Malaita province so they can re-strategise ways to provide service deliveries. However, Pirione said due to the issue that came out lately, the Public Service Commission and the ministry will consult with Malaita province to sort out the issue. Malaita Premier Daniel Suidani said his MARA Government is saddened by the action of the Sogavare Government to remove its PS. Premier Suidani said the reason for recalling Fa’abasua does not make sense because the province has a lot of workload since the absence of Deputy Provincial Secretary and Treasurer. “I see this as direct action against my MARA Government by a government that is so indebt to China,” Suidani said to those who staged the protest yesterday. “Make no mistake my people, the Sogavare led government do not want Malaita to progress. This action as you rightly stated is a clear message to us that the Sogavare government only interests in making us worst off. “I can see that what you have demonstrated today is clear reaction to the Sogavare Government that is no longer have interest in the affairs of this country but only his political power. “With the arrival of the PRC ambassador it is clear Sogavare have to take actions to please the PRC. There is no question about that,” he said. “But let me assure you my good people that the MARA government will stand with you in demanding for an explanation from the national government of its action. “As you know the MARA government through its Executive has made a resolution not long ago to not allow our PS to be moved from the Province. Clearly the Government is not listening to that resolution,” he said. “I will quickly call an urgent meeting of my executive to look into this issue and make appropriate statements soon. “My good people of Malaita today we are in trying times and we must not lose hope. I can assure you that we will be set free from any decisions that go against us. “Let me assure you also that as long as the MARA government is leading the province we shall not stop fighting any injustices against the government and the people of Malaita Province. “Let us united and stand for our rights. Let us continue to be responsible for our place and for our people,” he said.

column31: His Excellency Li Ming, First Ambassador of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) accredited to the Solomon Islands arrived in Honiara Wednesday night. Ambassador Ming was warmly received by senior SIG officials, the local Chinese community, and Embassy staff at the airport, a statement from PRC embassy office in Honiara said. In a written media interview released upon his arrival at the Henderson Airport, Ambassador Li Ming said that it is his great honor and pleasure to serve as the first Ambassador of the People�s Republic of China accredited to the Solomon Islands. “The establishment of diplomatic ties between the People�s Republic of China and Solomon Islands in 2019 has ushered in a new era for bilateral relations. “Since the inception of the diplomatic relationship between China and Solomon Islands, the bilateral relationship had been off to a good start with sound exchanges and fruitful cooperation in various areas. “Especially peoples of both countries have been working closely in the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic,”he said. “Especially peoples of both countries have been working closely in the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic,” he said.

column31: Civil society call on government to confirm withdrawal of intention to borrow USD100b LEADERS of some of the Honiara based Civil Society Organisations (CSOs) in a meeting organised and held at the Solomon Islands National Council of Women last week, have condemned the proposed action of Minister of Finance and Treasury, Harry Kuma, for attempting to solicit USD100 billion from China without prior consultation with the Central Bank of Solomon Islands as reported in the Solomon Islands print media. A spokesperson from the Solomon Islands National Council of Women on behalf of the CSO leaders attending the meeting, said that they have noted the action by the Minister in his official capacity as serious, violating the Public Finance Act of Solomon Islands. CSO Leaders also feel that his action is a breach of his Oath of Allegiance as Minister of the Crown, not being loyal to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, and in performing his duties of not protecting and serving the interest of Solomon Islands Citizens and the nation. CSO leaders request the Minister to apologise to the nation on behalf of the DCGA Government because of the intended cause of action he took with the Broker by the name of Mr Terry Wong, to deal with few businessmen in China for the purpose of lending to the Solomon Islands Government USD100 billion. “This is a total breach of his Oath and Allegiance and therefore, should do the right thing by apologising to the nation,” they say. Solomon Islands as a sovereign nation must follow protocols in dealing with such serious loan matters on government to government basis and not using middle men with a predetermined 11 percent heavy interest fee, which will benefit only a few cronies to become billionaires overnight if the loan proposal is to be materialised. The Solomon Islands Government does not have the capacity to mortgage such a huge loan, and therefore will commit all Solomon Islands individual citizen, tribal land with its minerals and sea resources thus setting a new suicidal debt trap for all Solomon Islanders and our future generations to come. The CSO group also call on the Governor General of Solomon Islands to summon the Minister because of his negligence and respect of the Oath he took prior to taking up his position as Finance Minister. It would be for the interest of the nation for the Governor General to advise the Finance Minister on behalf of all Solomon Islands Citizens for the Minister to apologise or even better resign accordingly. CSOs also want to know whether the DCGA will continue to formalise consultations on the loan through the so called Mr Wong, or now have formally withdrawn its intention to pursue further negotiations on the matter. -SINCW PRESS

column31: Fiji's borders are now closed to any foreign nationals who have been in Italy, Iran or Cheongdo county and Daegu city in South Korea within 14 days of their intended travel to Fiji. All visitors from China remain barred from entry. From Monday all international air passengers with handheld temperature scanners. Thermal scanners will be installed at Fiji's international airports from by mid-March. From tomorrow (Friday), all cruise ships entering Fijian waters will be required to first berth at Suva or Lautoka, where all passengers on board will undergo medical and travel history checks.

column31: United States President, Donald Trump, will not be attending the APEC Leaders’ Summit set for November. Instead, United States Vice President, Mike Pence will be coming in his place. In a statement yesterday, Prime Minister Peter O'Neill welcomed the announcement, describing Vice-President Pence, as an outstanding leader, and a man of great religious conviction. He said that Mr. Pence had played an important role in helping bring the 400-year-old King James Bible to PNG when he was the then Governor of the State of Indiana. US Secretary of State, Micke Pompeo, and US Trade Representative, Robert Lighthizer, will also be attending the APEC Minister's Meeting on November 15th. Other world leaders already confirmed to be in the country come November, are from China, Japan, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Russia. #EMTVNews #PNGNews

column31: PG2023 NEXT STEP Facilities designing concepts complete BY PETER ZOLEVEKE II Following the first phase of the exchange of notes between the People’s Republic of China and the Solomon Islands government earlier this year it has entered its second stage, with the signing of the ‘Implementation Agreement of the 2023 Pacific Games Stadium Project’ on the bilateral deal. On April the government signed the exchange of notes that allowed the PRC’s Central-South Architectural Design Institute [CSADI] mission into the country - purposely to do infrastructure design concepts of the Pacific Games 2023, and yesterday’s historical signing marked its completion with a task to achieve before the ‘green games’ which proposed construction works to start by May next year. “The PRC delegation has completed their mission and the governments have agreed on a task to PG 2023,” Secretary to Prime Minister and the Chairman of the National Hosting Authority (NHA) Dr Jimmie Rodgers said during the signing yesterday. "These signatures will outline what it is we hope to achieve before the games. Dr Rodgers assured that with the signings Honiara City will be transformed with modern facilities. “The rest of the Pacific will visualize the transformation of our city and that’s part of this project, it’s not just about the games it’s about changing the face of our city, about unifying the nation living the legacy for young people,” Dr Rodgers adds while thanking PRC for being the major part of the partnership. The NHA Chairman also gave the facilities construction outlined timeframe for the seven infrastructures. “We would like to start the construction by May next year, and then the idea is the construction period will be roughly 24 months to complete all the facilities,” Dr. Rodgers said. The seven infrastructures will include: -A 10,000-seat national stadium which includes 1,000 VIP seats, -An Aquatic center hosting a 50-meter competition pool, and a 25-meter training pool, -A six-court tennis center -A full-sized training track and field with a full-sized soccer/ rugby field -A 90 meters by 50 meters multi-purpose hall -A 5-aside competition hockey field -A double story food court and office space building for the Games Organizing Committee. His Excellency Ambassador, Li Ming in his brief remarks reaffirmed that the first stage of design now completes. “Today marks as a very important moment, after more than a month of working by the expert team from China. The first stage of designing is completed which we marked,” Ambassador Ming said. “The 2023 PG stadium project is a symbol of friendship between China and Solomon Islands. And also it is a symbol of national pride for Solomon Islands government and the people. H.E Ming also expressed that his government is overwhelmed to be part of the partnership to build the main stadium and the facilities to host the games. “Chinese people and the government would like to share the joy and excitement of this Pacific Games hosted by Solomon Islands, initiated by the Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare. He added that the project will become the largest and the most modernize facilities. With PM Sogavare who witnessed the brief ceremony conveyed the country’s gratitude to the President, the government and people of the People’s Republic of China. “The scope of work, the level of details, and the philosophy behind the design were impressive. Allow me on behalf of the government to thank the CSADI team for their excellent work,” he said. The Prime Minister said the 2023 Pacific Games ‘Friendship project’ bears testimony to the strengthening and consolidation of the relationship between both countries. “I ‘am very encouraged by the proposed construction schedule and timelines for the project, with the aim to complete all the facilities before the 2023 Pacific Games. The signing was also witnessed by government’s stakeholders and sporting entities.

column31: The Kiribati President’s office has denied Kiribati plans to sell its land in Fiji to a third party. This follows reports from Kiribati last week that there were plans to give the land at Natoavatu on Vanua Levu to Chinese interests to develop. A statement says this is untrue, but does clarify that here has been “ongoing consultation between the Ministry of Environment and China on possible projects, noting that a strategic plan for the land in Fiji has been developed and that we are seeking technical assistance from China to further improve the plan including ideas for the actual projects and activities. This is in light of the current agriculture cooperation with China to assist build local capacity in the agricultural sector in Kiribati and which can benefit the development plan for Natoavatu.” “The land in Fiji is ideal for future development to address the needs of Kiribati given the suitable soil for agriculture and access to the seafront and ports. In this regard, the government considers the development of the land in Fiji as an investment opportunity for the benefit of all I-Kiribati people.” The statement says Kiribati has continued to keep the Fiji government updated on plans and activities for the land. #Kiribati #Fiji

column36:
🔶 KIRIBATI OFFERS PIECE OF LAND IN FIJI TO CHINA

✳️ In 2014, the Kiribati government bought a piece of land on Fiji’s second largest island, Vanua Levu. 

✳️ Natoavatu estate, a 5460 acre piece of land, was purchased for AUD$9.3 million by former President of Kiribati, Anote Tong. 

✳️ The purchase is an “investment by the (then) government to explore options of commercial, industrial and agricultural undertakings such as fish canning, beef/poultry farming, fruit/vegetable farming to name but a few.” 

⚠️ In a recent press conference, incumbent Kiribati President Taneti Maamau announced it will give this land to China to develop it. 

⚠️ President Taneti Maamau switched diplomatic relations of Kiribati from Taipei to Beijing in September 2019. 

🟢 Stay tuned for FULL story, soon.

column31: Coronavirus threat- just next door BY BARNABAS MANEBONA THE world-spreading ‘Coronavirus’ which is said to be originated from China is just next door to Solomon Islands. Australia is now dealing with the crisis having a young Chinese woman tested positive for "probable" coronavirus in Sydney, becoming the fifth case across Australia in the past few days, it is reported on ‘9 NEWS’. In response to media inquiry, the Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS) yesterday confirmed that it is now taking proactive actions to prevent the virus, adding measures to strengthen the sea ports and airports and travellers leaving and entering the country are now being put in place. Being now next door, Solomon Islanders publicly debated that the country having no capacity to handle this crisis if it gets into Solomon Islands must now step up with immediate measures to monitor and prevent it. On social media some said Coronavirus threat to the country is real and people must now take precautions when at crowded areas such as at the airport where infection can transmit such as- through coughing. “The government should ensure that those travelling from China must be required to show medical clearance from a reputable health facility in China before they are allowed into the country,” an online commentator stated. The new virus is reported to have started in the Chinese City of Wuhan and has spread rapidly across China and to other countries, so far killing 17 people as of last Friday. Yesterday it was reported that the death toll in China rises to 56, with 2000 confirmed cases and a further 2600 people suspected of being infected. Suspect of many others being infected with coronavirus continues in other countries around the world as well. The Coronavirus symptom has a form of Cold- or flu-like symptoms usually set in from two to four days after infection. In more severe cases, infection can cause pneumonia, severe acute respiratory syndrome, kidney failure and even death. Most victims have been elderly people, suffering from other chronic diseases including Parkinson's and diabetes

column31: IN PICTURES: China Donates Coronavirus Prevention Supplies in Honiara The People’s Republic of China donated laboratory equipment and reagents, coronavirus test kits and personal protective equipment has arrived this afternoon (Wednesday 22nd April) at Honiara International Airport via a special Solomon Airlines Cargo flight from Brisbane, Australia. This support covers laboratory equipment, testing kits, Medical gloves, Personal Protective Equipment, various Masks, Medical, surgical and N95. Infrared thermometers and medical goggles. The People’s Republic of China (PRC) through its Embassy in Honiara has also recently handed over three distinct partnership programs last week which included grant assistance towards hosting the 2023 Pacific Games combined with cash donations to support the government’s COVID-19 response and Tropical Cyclone Harold rehabilitation. The Solomon Islands and PRC signed a Framework Agreement Establishing Diplomatic Relations between the two countries only 6 months ago and according to a statement by Sogavare last week, he was inspired that this relationship has not only developed, but made invaluable progress despite the limitations caused by the COVID-19 Pandemic. PHOTO SOURCE: GEORGE HERMING - GOVERNMENT COMMUNICATION UNIT

column6: Island Sun is the leading daily newspaper in the Solomon Islands. This is our official Facebook page.
column31: EDITORIAL- Yes, we attended that zoom session ISLAND Sun wishes to respond to a report the Adviser to Malaita Provincial Government, Celsius Talifilu, produced and circulated on social media this week. Firstly, we can confirm that our representatives attended a zoom session the Embassy of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) in Solomon Islands organized on 8 April 2021. We attended in good faith because we were invited. In fact, we always attend to invitations from the diplomatic missions in Honiara. For instance, just recently we attended an invitation the New Zealand High Commission sent us for evening drinks. So, there’s nothing sinister about our acceptance to attend the PRC Embassy’s invitation to the zoom session with media groups from Quandong Province. Secondly, we can confirm that during the zoom session we made a five-minute presentation about who we are. Again, the presentation was made on request from the PRC Embassy. In fact, all local media houses that attended made five-minute presentations about themselves during the session. The media houses from Quandong Province did the same. Thirdly, we can also confirm that Nanfang Media Group from Quandong sent us a letter after the zoom session enquiring about possible collaboration and partnership. We are currently looking into this request. One thing we can say is media houses in China have a lot to offer in terms of technical assistance, as well as other areas of media development. Fourthly, we can also confirm that the PRC Embassy has offered to assist us with our office equipment needs. The past year has not been easy for us financially. With significant drop in revenue due to COVID-19, we are barely struggling to survive above the waters. So, when this offer of assistance to meet our office needs came, we accepted it in good faith and with open arms. We wish to state that there were no conditions or strings attached to this assistance. It was a genuine assistance from a development partner to an organization that is struggling in the face of the pandemic. We’ve received similar assistance in the past from the Australian Government immediately after the ethnic tension. This was channelled through a media strengthening programme called SOLMAS, set up to assist the local media get back to its feet after the tensions. In fact, all media houses benefitted from the SOLMAS assistance. Fifthly, and finally, we wish to assure our readers that our independence as a private news organization remains intact. We have a very vibrant and dynamic newsroom managed by an experienced Editor, who is not giving away the independence of our news coverage to any external forces, just yet. We continue to pursue stories of national interests within all sectors of the country, and we’ll remain at the forefront of independent journalism in our beloved country.

column31: Gov’t to reshuffle nation’s diplomats By EDDIE OSIFELO A NUMBER of the country’s diplomats serving overseas will be reshuffled this year in a major exercise Cabinet approved late last year. A government minister involved in the discussions confirmed to the Island Sun that William Soaki in Suva, Fiji, will be shifted to replace High Commissioner Barnabas Anga in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea. Anga is likely to be recalled to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and External Trade headquarters in Honiara. Former Ambassador to Brussels, Belgium, Joseph Ma’ahanua is likely to replace Robert Sisilo in Canberra, Australia. Ma’ahanua is currently serving at headquarters in Honiara. Sisilo will be transferred to Suva to replace Soaki. Furthermore, Barett Salato is transferring to Auckland, New Zealand, after the closure of Solomon Islands Mission in Geneva, Switzerland, in June 2020 due to financial constraints. The Geneva mission opened in 2011 and with its closure, the Solomon Islands mission in neighbouring Brussels will take over all the functions performed by the mission. Meanwhile, Dr Transform Aqorau, who was appointed last year to head the country’s mission in New York, United States of America, is yet to take up his post. Sources said Government is yet to finalise the terms of service regarding Aqorau’s engagement. Aqorau is the country’s foremost expert in international maritime law. He had previously served with the Pacific Islands Forum Fisheries Agency in Honiara, Pacific Islands Forum Secretariat in Suva and founding CEO of the Majuro-based Parties to the Nauru Agreement (PNA). He’s currently here at home awaiting his travel. A cabinet insider said agreements from host Governments and appointments of Public Service Commission and Governor General and Prime Minister are next to happen. The country has 11 diplomatic missions abroad following the closure of the Malaysian and Taiwanese missions. The nation’s mission in Beijing, China, is opening soon while other missions in Cuba and United Kingdom are still operational.

column31: ‘Bu’ by machine What next? How about a ready-to-drink coconut (bu) from a machine? That’s what Fiji Sun managing editor digital Rosi Doviverata (pictured) found in China. Our Ms Doviverata is amongst elite editors from around the world now there after being selected for a month-long Dongfang fellowship on media transformation. Ms Doviverata paid for the bu from the machine using Alipay, the mobile payment platform established by internet guru Jack Ma’s Alibaba group. “And the bu was nice and cool,” she said in a message back to headquarters in Suva. The editors spent time at the Alibaba headquarters in Hangzhou city as part of their programme. The Dongfang fellowship is run by China Daily - China’s biggest English-language newspaper - in conjunction with leading universities in Shanghai and Beijing. Ms Doviverata is the first from the Pacific Islands to be selected for it.

column31: PAC vs HCC Inquiry starts today BY BEN BILUA THE Public Accounts Committee will today look into the Audit Report on the accounts and records of the Honiara City Council (HCC). The Committee will spend today and tomorrow excavating issues relating to the report. According to the hearing schedule produced by the National Parliament yesterday, former and current HCC treasurers, Honiara City Clerk and Mayor will stand before the office of the Auditor General, Permanent Secretary of Home Affairs, Permanent Secretary of Finance and Director Debt Management Unit within the Ministry of Finance. The hearing will be interesting as no one has been accounted for the allegations found in the Honiara City Council Audit Report last year. HCC councillors and certain officials have been at loggerhead since last year when the former chairman of finance Billy Abae made a call to investigate the unaccounted revenue collected for the sale of fire extinguishers, under what was found to be a Public Private Partnership (PPP) arrangement between the Council and a Chinese firm for buying of fire extinguishers. On November 15 last year a PPP Agreement was signed with Jingsan Anbao Firefighting Company Ltd of China on trial basis – an agreement Abae questioned HCC about and was sacked from his position as a result. Another Councillor, Regional Ngati was also kicked out from his portfolio on reasons that he was among the network of councillors who tried to destabilise HCC Administration under City Mayor Wilson Mamae’s leadership. Earlier this year, the office of the Auditor General began conducting what it calls a ‘Spot on Audit’ at the directive of the Minister of Home Affairs Chris Laore following allegations of widespread financial mismanagement and illegal borrowings. “Most of our officers are doing the reporting while assessing the books. “We are expecting to complete the auditing by end of this month. But this is subject to reporting if we are not satisfied, then might extend the deadline,” Auditor General Peter Lokay told Island Sun.

Manasseh Sogavare states, Solomon Islands believes, security for Solomon Islands is a collective approach. “Solomon Islands does not subscribe to the view that only a partner or partners of the same ideology is able to do that,” Prime Minister Sogavare told Parliament. Prime Minister Sogavare said, internally, the consequences of last November riots is around $800 million. 1000 jobs were lost and many more livelihood of our people affected. He stated, “from last November’s riots, it is obvious, current security agreement with Australia is inadequate to deal with our hard internal threats. The economic impact of the November Riots has nearly crippled Solomon Islands.” Prime Minister Sogavare explained, the tendency to frequently having to deal with riots leave the government no option but to enter into security agreement with other bilateral partners to plug the gaps that exists in our security agreement with Australia. He strongly maintains, the new SI-China treaty does not provide for a naval and/or military base. The Prime Minister further added, Solomon Islands is also working on security agreements with Papua New Guinea and Fiji to address our soft and hard security threats. *GCU PR

column31: The Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS) continues to be grateful for the ongoing support by the People’s Republic of China’s (PRC’s) commitment and dedication towards ensuring that the Ministry is well prepared to combat possible entry and outbreak of COVID-19 following the signing of a hand over certificate for more Personal Protective Equipment (PPEs) on Wednesday this week. The PPEs include 2500 medical disposable protective clothing, 5000 surgical masks, 500 medical facial masks, 500 medical protective goggles, and 100 infrared thermodetector. Following the signing, Yao Ming Deputy Head of the Chinese Embassy in the Solomon Islands stated that the government and people of China is pleased to provide the support to the Solomon Islands government through the Health Ministry to assist in Its preparedness and response to COVID-19. “It is indeed a pleasure to be handing over these PPEs to help the ministry, especially the frontline health workers and their supporting staff, in their efforts to track and combat any entry and spread of this deadly virus as well as enabling them to perform their COVID- 19 operations in a safe manner”, highlighted Mr. Ming. column31: 𝗣𝗠 𝗖𝗢𝗡𝗗𝗘𝗠𝗡𝗦 𝗟𝗢𝗢’𝘀 𝗠𝗜𝗦𝗜𝗡𝗙𝗢𝗥𝗠𝗔𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗖𝗔𝗠𝗣𝗔𝗜𝗚𝗡 PRIME Minister Manasseh Sogavare last week has condemned the Leader Of Opposition (LOO) of orchestrating a distasteful misinformation campaign in attempts to promote hatred against the reigning Democratic Coalition Government Advancement (DCGA). Opposition Leader Mathew Wale’s ongoing rants against the Prime Minister over the Security Cooperation with China claiming it as a personal “deal” and that the Prime Minister is exercising autocratic leadership are classic examples of a “leader” that has nothing good in place for people but mere hatred to create disunity in the country. Sogavare said while the Government continues to enlighten people about representative democracy and how the country is governed, some leaders such as Mathew Wale and East Are’ Are MP, Peter Kenilorea Junior (PKJ) chose to employ misinformation as their strategy to discredit the Government. “I find it really distasteful that these people have not been truthful, instead they have been feeding misinformation to our people,” Sogavare said. “It is indeed a shameful act by the Leader of the Official Opposition to continue to mislead the people of Solomon Islands in his so-called Press Statements and interviews,” the Prime Minister added. In recent weeks, a lot has been said on the decision by a democratically elected Government, empowered by the Constitution of Solomon Islands to enter into security arrangements with partners of choice. Quite interestingly, only the security arrangement between the People’s Republic of China and Solomon Islands is of concern to certain persons. Sogavare repeated that the Security Agreement is not a private arrangement. It is a bilateral treaty between two sovereign states, Solomon Islands and the People’s Republic of China (PRC). “The Leader of Opposition knows this very well but he chose to say otherwise to our people, deliberating lying to them. He then goes on to say that this security treaty is targeting Malaita, and in saying this he is indirectly saying to the people that I continue to be anti-Malaita. This is not the first time that the Leader of Opposition has made such ludicrous accusations,” Sogavare said. Sogavare further pointed out Solomon Islands also have a security arrangement with Australia that was signed in 2017 without consultation and it was also not a private agreement but agreement between Solomon Islands and Australia. “Let me make it clear to our people that both of these agreements with Australia and China were endorsed by Cabinet and executed in accordance with our national security objectives to maintain internal peace and stability in contrary to the misinformation trumpeted by the Leader of Opposition,” Sogavare said. “The Leader of Opposition is fully aware of the principles of representative democracy. Yet he has time and time again, continued to mislead the people as to its meaning,” he added. Sogavare said the Leader of Opposition knows that the processes that the Government has employed and continues to employ complies with the system of representative democracy, yet he fails to make that acknowledgement because he refuses to accept that it is this representative democracy that places him as the leader of Opposition. SOURCE: GCU

column31: DENTANA: ESP BEARS RESULT By EDDIE OSIFELO THE Government has achieved its underlying policy objectives of the controversial Economic Stimulus Package (ESP). This was despite public perception, mostly labelling the ESP as a failed project of the government because of the lack of stimulation of the economy. The two main policy objectives of the ESP were: 1. to prevent the economy from deterioration following the outbreak of the COVID-19 in China in December 2019, and 2. Promote aggregate demand in the economy. Permanent Secretary of Ministry of Finance and Treasury, Mckinni Dentana told reporters on Tuesday that when they did the model in 2020, they estimated negative growth of 4.5 percent on the economy. However, he said at the end of 2020 when they ran the model, it shows the deterioration of economy is not severe as expected in their initial assessment. “We come up to negative growth but at 3.5 percent compared to more than 4.5 percent,” Dentana said “We have achieved the objective of the policy to prevent the economy from further deteriorating,” he added. Furthermore, PS Dentana said to promote aggregate demand was to ensure domestic activity happened in the economy despite covid 19. He said this included supply of copra, cocoa and timber and other commodities must continue to reach markets during the year and throughout 2021. “There are some data we received at the end of 2020. “For example, copra productions have increased to 37,000 metric tones higher than in 2019,” he said. Dentana said in 2019 they recorded around 8,000 metric tonnes of copra. He said in 2020, they have around 12,000 metric tones which the country has exported. “That is one indication that there was continuation of trading activity despite the covid,” he said. Dentana said the Government has provided subsidies to transports and support farmers so they could harvest their products and bring them to the markets. He said cocoa experienced a mix result because Government supported farmers around July to September. However, Dentana said the peak season for cocoa was around the first quarter of the year. He said despite covid, around 4,000 metric tonnes of cocoa were exported. On timbers, Dentana said the reaction of timber in the market happened in 2021 because most of the activities and supports were offloaded to exporters. “For example, in 2019, around 542,000 cubic meters of timbers have been exported. “In 2020, around 500,000 metric tones, and in 2021 it increased to 763,000 metric tonnes,” he said. Further to that, Dentana said around 13,000 tonnes of kava have been exported. As such, he said the Government has achieved its second policy intention. In terms of recovery, Dentana said Government has assisted State Owned Enterprises, private companies and made commitment to big infrastructure projects. He said the Tauba and Kwai bridges on Malaita province are fully operational now. He said it is unfortunate for the Fiu bridge, it did not eventuate eventhough Government has committed $30 million to the World Bank. Dentana said Government also supported Raoe bridge in East Malaita and the ramp in Kirakira. He said upgrading of Sege and Taro airports are coming up this year. Further to that, Dentana said Government also supported Solomon Airlines, Solomon Water and Development Bank of Solomon Islands.

column31: 𝗖𝗛𝗜𝗡𝗔'𝗦 𝗥𝗘𝗦𝗣𝗢𝗡𝗦𝗘 𝗧𝗢 𝗨𝗦'𝘀 𝗖𝗢𝗠𝗠𝗘𝗡𝗧𝗦 𝗢𝗡 𝗧𝗛𝗘 𝗦𝗘𝗖𝗨𝗥𝗜𝗧𝗬 𝗔𝗚𝗥𝗘𝗘𝗠𝗘𝗡𝗧 On April 22, a high-level U.S. delegation visited Solomon Islands, discussing with Hon. Prime Minister Sogavare the recently signed China-Solomon Islands security agreement. The U.S. delegation alleged that there are potential regional security implications of the agreement, including for the United States and its allies and partners. If steps are taken to establish a de facto permanent military presence, power-projection capabilities, or a military installation, the delegation noted that the United States would then have significant concerns and respond accordingly. 𝗖𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗮'𝘀 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗽𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗲? A: We object to any third party’s intention to interfere with security cooperation between China and Solomon Islands as sovereign states. During its visit to Solomon Islands, the U.S. delegation openly warned the Solomon Islands government over the security cooperation between China and Solomon Islands, which had once again exposed some countries’ condescending acts in disrespect to other nations. In accordance with the principles of on equal footing, mutual respect and non-interference into each other's internal affairs, the cooperation in security and other fields between China and Solomon Islands conforms to international law and norms and is conducive to regional stability and development. Both China and Solomon Islands have repeatedly emphasized that reports on so-called Chinese military base in Solomon Islands are misinformation fabricated by those people with ulterior motives. Since the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and Solomon Islands, the exchanges and cooperation between two countries in various fields have yielded fruitful results and been warmly welcomed by two peoples. Any attempt to inflame the situation, provoke tensions and stir up confrontation in the Pacific Island region does not serve common interests of regional countries and is doomed to fail. 𝗕𝘆 𝗢𝗳𝗳𝗶𝗰𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗦𝗽𝗼𝗸𝗲𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗼𝗻 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗖𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝗲 𝗘𝗺𝗯𝗮𝘀𝘀𝘆

column31: ‘Women are not second-class citizens’ BY JENNIFER KUSAPA Madame Emmy Sogavare has highlighted that women are not second-class citizens. In her speech to mark the international day of women, the prime minister’s wife said women’s rights must be meaningfully acknowledged and appropriately placed in the decision-making process of our global societies. “I must congratulate all women, in all works of life to continue to fight against discrimination and marginalization of women and vulnerable groups in the world. “As a least developing country, Solomon Islands can relate to the realities of the issues raised by women every year, on gender-based violence, for example SI is ranked amongst countries with very high rates of violence against women, the reports are sickening to read.” She said the rising reported cases of sexual abuse committed by people in positions of trust in the homes is unbelievable, especially in a country that professes Christianity as its religion; that being the case, no amount of cultural and traditional reasons can justify such actions. “We must continue to fight against these abuses. “I must also acknowledge that women’s rights are one only of the many issues that we are grappling with in this country, we can raise the same kind of sentiments in many other issues that affect the lives of our people,” Sogavare said. She said while one cannot rule out the reality of the fixed attitude by leaders and people in responsible positions, which interestingly include women, like in many countries including Solomon Islands, one must appreciate the structural, cultural and other realities that influence the way the system thinks. which women must continue to bring to the attention of leaders. Chinese Ambassador Li Ming reinforces this message by saying women are creators of human civilization and drivers of social progress, and they have made extraordinary achievements across all fields of endeavour. “My Embassy staff often go shopping at Honiara Central Market, and we see women running business there. Some of them bring their kids. They work so hard, but always look happy and resilient. I think like women in China, they are fighting for the family, for their children, and for a better life. We should pay high respect to women, including to those medical workers, public service, policewomen who are at the front line of fighting the pandemic of COVID-19,” Mr Li said.

column31: Foreign Vessel Barred From Port Entry Solomon Ports in collaboration with the Solomon Islands Maritime Safety Administration (SIMSA) today have taken the decision to deny of entry into port to the Bulk Carrier Vessel MV. Worship Light. This comes after the vessel violated international and domestic maritime regulations. MV. Worship Light left Zhangjiagang, China on the first of April 1st 2020, and arrived in the country on the 15th of April, 2020. On 15 April 2020, the MV WORSHIP LIGHT entered the port of Honiara in Solomon Islands and anchored in the harbour area with no authorisation of the Solomon Islands Port Authority and failed to provide pre-arrival information despite request of the Port Authority and in accordance to the Maritime Safety Administration (Ship and Port Security) Regulations 2011. The following security regulations as per the International Ships and Port Facility security code (ISPS) and PFSP have been violated. • Section 5.8.1 (PFSP) “The Port Pilot controls the movement of vessels entering or leaving the port. • International Ships and Port Facility security code (ISPS) regulated that ships must report their intentions to enter a port 72 hours before arrival. • Any regulated ship that intends to visit the port, must be notified for clearance before entering the port. • Section 5.9.1 (PFSP), International ships intending to enter Honiara Port must notify the PFSO 72 hours prior to arrival. Ship profile must be screened by the PFSO to ensure the ship is complaint to ISPS Standards and that is safe for pilot to board. With the current state of emergency imposed in the country and the global Covid 19 pandemic, Solomon Ports view the ship’s behavior as suspicious and a threat to the country’s security. SIMSA has also requested the ship to leave the Solomon Islands waters immodestly. Solomon Ports strongly urge local shipping agents to ensure ships entering the country’s waters must abide by our maritime laws. ENDS/// Story and Photo Source: SIPA Media

column31: Parliament upgrades sound system By EDDIE OSIFELO PARLIAMENT has upgraded its sound system due to regular error on feedbacks during meetings. About $4.1 million was given by Republic of China (ROC) Taiwan for this project under the 2019 Supplementary Appropriation Bill 2020. Clerk to Parliament David Kusilifu told the Public Accounts Committee on Monday that the money was used for consultancy fee and upgrade on the sound system. He said Parliament had completed $173,639.77(AUD$29,000) payment for Information Communication Technology equipment already. The sound system was set up in Parliament in 2009. RAMSI through its Machinery of Government Program committed more than $1.25 million towards the installation of the new chamber system. Kusilifu said the challenge now is to get the technicians from Australia to upgrade the equipment. He said there would be upgrade on audio visual where instead of people standing in Parliament with camera, there will be automated camera from the media booth. The company that worked on installing the new system in 2009 previously worked together to install sound system in the Australian Federal Parliament, New South Wales State Parliament, High Court of Australia and the New Zealand Parliament.

column31: ‘Remain alert for signs of coronavirus’ BY BARNABAS MANEBONA Public have been reminded to take serious heed of health warning and remain alert for signs or symptoms of the coronavirus (COVID-19). This is especially to those who have recently visited China or with someone returning from affected countries and having similar symptoms to coronavirus. It is reported on ABC news this week that the first cases of person-to-person transmission of coronavirus have been confirmed in Australia. And, it is understood as well from report over last weekend that a person in Auckland Hospital has become the first case of coronavirus in New Zealand, raising high alarm for people of Solomon Islands being a country located in between these two big Pacific countries. The Ministry of Health Medical Services (MHMS) who this week in a Press Statement said they are continuing preparedness efforts to prevent potential importation of COVID-19 with other government ministries and partners, earlier issued that patients should contact their local clinic or nurse aid post if they think they could possibly have the disease. “Patients should contact their local clinic or nurse aid post if they think they could possibly have the disease, calling in advance if possible, so that they can be assessed at home or isolated on arrival at the health facility. “Anyone with suspected infection should avoid public transport and public spaces and remain at home except to seek professional health care, or as advised by a health professional. “To prevent the infection from spreading to others, practice health habits such as cover cough and sneezes, avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth, and wash your hands often. If your family member has flu-like infection, limit contact with the family member and keep your house clean,” aware MHMS.

column31: THE questionable actions and dealings of both the City Clerk Rence Sore and councillor John Szetu, owner of the Pinnacle Enterprises in Honiara, warrant a full-fledged investigation by responsible authorities. This sentiment was echoed by John Kina, a long-time resident of Honiara. Kina told the Solomon Star Sore’s reluctance to reveal the identity of the private entity that supplied the fire extinguishers to the council and his subsequent admission to the transaction which was alleged to be unbudgeted for amounts to gross negligence of due processes. “To me, the issue of the fire extinguishers has already warranted criminal investigation because it has not been budgeted for in the first place,” he said. He said Sore’s refusal to reveal the private entity whilst at the same time admitting to local transactions, is an indication that something fishy is going on at the highest level of the council. Kina said that since Szetu has denied being part of the deal, he needs to prove his innocence that the property in which the fire extinguishers are stored upon arrival from china is someone else’s. An insider within the HCC has revealed that the unloading of the fire extinguishers was done at Szetu’s warehouse at his Outback Shop at Rove, next to Children’s Park. column31: CLEAN RELEASE Police says no politics behind freed covid-19 equipment to Malaita province, investigation continues BY JENNIFER KUSAPA POLICE has crossed out any political connection to Monday’s release of the confiscated Taiwan-donated covid-19 equipment to Malaita province. The announcement by Deputy Prime Minister Manasseh Maelanga has nothing to do with the release of the covid-19 equipment, Police Commissioner Mostyn Mangau told reporters in a press conference yesterday. Mr Mangau implies that the premature announcement by DPM Maelanga undermines police investigations and processes, since they are not linked. “The announcement done by the Deputy Prime Minister in Malaita about the release of the medical equipment has nothing to do with police investigation or undermines the police investigation processes.” Mr Maelanga had announced to the provincial government and people of Malaita on Friday last week, during the celebration of the 37th Malaita Day, that the impounded covid-19 equipment would be released “soon”. Coincidentally, this statement was realised on Monday this week. Commissioner Mangau explains that police conducted investigation into the consignment after they received a formal complaint from the office of the Attorney General. Upon completion, and with police satisfied with their findings, Mangau said they forwarded their report to the Director Public Prosecutions (DPP) for viewing. Mangau adds, DPP then made their advice based on the findings, and police released the consignment back to Customs, which then made a proper release to the Malaita province. However, Mangau says investigation continues despite the consignment’s release; “investigation is still ongoing on areas of how the consignment has been channelled through”, says Mangau. The covid-19 equipment was confiscated on June 16 by government citing “suspicious nature surrounding the importation of the cargoes”. The cargo was the second batch of covid-19 equipment donated by Taiwan under its global counter-covid19 programme, which was offered to any country including those which do not have diplomatic relations with Taiwan. The consignment was sent for Malaita Province. Police said they had become suspicious at the cargo being addressed to a post office box belonging to a person who lived at Kaibia Settlement, Honiara, and the sender’s address being “not proper” and not addressed to the Malaita Provincial Government. Police in their recent explanation following public criticism on the seizure said the RSIPF Act 2013 gives police the powers to investigate any suspicious act by any citizen of Solomon Islands that might lead to the contravening of any laws of the country. This infamous move by government to impound the humanitarian aid has been widely criticised as a direct display of Beijing’s stooge oblivious of the welfare of the people of Malaita against the current covid-19 pandemic. Malaita declared following the seizure that it had sought assistance from our former ally, Republic of China (Taiwan), to help the province prepare itself for any possible covid-19 entry.
