column31: 𝗦𝗜- 𝗝𝗔𝗣𝗔𝗡 𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗲𝘄𝗲𝗱 𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘃𝗼𝘄𝘀 SOLOMON ISLANDS and Japan took stock of their positive, strong and firm relations and agreed to further bolster bilateral cooperation programs in a number of sectors. This was the outcome of Honiara’s meeting between Prime Minister Hon. Manasseh Sogavare and Japan’s Vice Foreign Minister Kentaro Uesugi. The 7-member high-level delegation comprise high-ranking officials from Japan’s Parliament Office, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Ministry of Defense who flew in from Tokyo over the weekend. Welcoming the high-level delegation, Prime Minister Hon. Manasseh Sogavare said Japan is one of the few Solomon Islands that forged diplomatic relations right from gaining political Independence in 1978. Since then Solomon Islands continue to benefit from Japanese infrastructure program to this day. Solomon Islands expressed its gratitude for Japan’s COVID-19 support to the country and looks forward to keep working with Japan in combating the pandemic. Solomon Islands assured Japan that it will continue to stand with Japan on very important international issues of mutual concerns. Prime Minister Sogavare assured Japan that the security pact signed with China poses no threat to Japan or the region. This security agreement is to address domestic soft and hard threats. Both countries underlined respect for each other’s sovereignty and their shared responsibility to nurture friendship, peace and stability in the region. Japan further assures Solomon Islands that it will not interfere with Solomon Islands sovereign decision on any issue but want lasting peace with Solomon Islands and the Pacific family. The treaty is about helping Solomon Islands when assistance is needed especially in times of disasters and to support police capability. A safe and stable Solomon Islands contributes to a safe and stable region. Solomon Islands assures Japan it has no intention whatsoever to have a foreign military presence in the country. Source: GCU

column31: We are preparing for COVAX: MHMS THE Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS) as the lead government agency working on the mitigation and control of the covid-19 pandemic, and co-chair of the National Coordinating Committee for the COVAX (Covid-19 Vaccines Access Facility), would like to assure the public that work on acquiring covid-19 vaccines once they are approved, and the preparations in country to receive and roll out COVAX is well underway and according to plan. This statement is made in response to claims made by the office of the opposition group that health is far from ready in its preparedness to receive and roll out the vaccine due to delays with appointments of technical expertise to support the government in this regard. On December 7, 2020 the Ministry working closely with its partners has submitted the country’s request to Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, a global health agency co-leading the COVAX facility which is a the only global initiative that is working with governments and manufacturers to ensure covid-19 vaccines are available worldwide on an equitable basis. Through the COVAX facility, participating eligible countries such as the Solomon Islands will receive an initial covid-19 vaccine to cover 20 percent of its population free and then able to co-finance the remaining doses with Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance. In addition, the Government is also in bilateral talks with our donors and partners to secure additional supply of vaccine to increase the coverage of vaccination against covid-19. As part of the MHMS preparedness, a National Coordinating Committee (NCC) for COVAX chaired jointly by the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Health and Medical Services and the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Finance and Treasury has already been established, and had its first meeting in the first week of December 2020, where the Solomon Islands application for covid-19 vaccines was reviewed and approved. Members of the NCC includes representatives from WHO, UNICEF, World Bank, Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), People’s Republic of China, World Vision, Solomon Islands Christian Association (SICA) and so forth with technical team comprising of technical staff from WHO and UNICEF. The committee is responsible to; o Review, analyze, guide and endorse technical and operational recommendations for COVAX shared by the Expanded Programme of Immunisation Technical Working Group. o Review global level information (WHO, UNICEF,) related to Covid-19 vaccines and incorporate it into the planning and preparations as needed o Guide the deployment plan with clear functions, responsibilities and deadlines o Establish an operations room for coordination, information and communication o Develop and implement accountability framework for vaccine deployment and use o Report to higher-level authorities, when needed, and communicate with partners and the press o Monitor progress using methods such as dashboard with key indicators, checklists The nature of the cold chain requirement for the approved vaccines present operational challenges. In order to address these, a National Deployment and Vaccination Plan for COVID-19 vaccines has been developed and is constantly being revised to rollout vaccination once vaccines are approved and delivered. The National Immunisation Programme of the Ministry developed the COVID-19 vaccines application and deployment plans with continued technical assistance from the Ministry’s partners regularly interfacing through the technical working group on immunisation. The COVAX deployment and vaccination plan outlines how the vaccine will be received, stored, distributed across the country, administered and the priority persons to receive the vaccine. In terms of the resources and the technical expertise to support the national roll out of the COVAX, the National Coordinating Committee with the technical support team have mapped out the human resource and materials resource needs including the budgetary requirements for an effective rollout of the covid-19 vaccines. While doing so, strategies to prevent duplication of needed specialized technical expertise and overlap of responsibilities were employed. Before the Christmas holidays, the Permanent Secretary MHMS approved the allocation of four additional human resource to the National Expanded Programme on Immunisation unit to assist with COVID-19 vaccination preparation and implementation. In addition, further mapping of existing technical capacities within the Ministry and partners is continuing so that any new appointments of additional expertise are done accordingly to ensure work efficiency and effectiveness as well as sustainability. Thrust is to train and deploy the in-country expertise for sustainable operations under the technical expertise available in-country through the partners such as UNICEF, and the World Bank. These principles are also applied to proposed financial support from (truncated)

column31: PM acknowledge continuous ‘donor’ support BY BARNABAS MANEBONA PRIME Minister Manasseh Sogavare applauds and thanks donor partners for their ongoing commitment and support to Solomon Islands fight against Coronavirus (Covid-19). Speaking during his Covid-19 nationwide address yesterday, the Prime Minister said Solomon Islands earlier this year received 13 million Australian dollars from Australia, and 3 million New Zealand dollars from New Zealand. Mr Sogavare said Solomon Islands has also received substantial funding support from the Governments of Japan and Peoples Republic of China. “In addition, we had also received substantial support from the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank. We continue to receive specialized support from our United Nations Agencies including the WHO and UNICEF,” said Sogavare. “Last week, we witnessed the exchange of notes with the People’s Republic of China for a total funding of USD 150 thousand, around $1.2 million SBD to the Solomon Islands government. This fund will re-purpose the current TB ward at the NRH into a 16-bed Isolation Ward where patients discharged from the higher level Isolation units could be accommodated while awaiting release into other facilities, or if the need arises, could be used to look after severe cases of COVID-19 infection. “To all these donors, and others that I may not have specifically mentioned above, thank you so much for your ongoing support to my government, to help us in our fight against COVID-19.” Of the 17 positive Covid-19 registered cases in the country announced last week Monday, ‘8’ remain positive while ‘9’ are now negative.

column31: MHMS supply chain affected: Mua BY MAVIS NISHIMURA PODOKOLO WHILST the country is battling to stop the importation of covid-19, the supply chain of the Ministry of Health is reportedly under threat. Dickson Mua, Minister for Health and Medical Services (MHMS), says, “On the issue of the Ministry’s stockpile, the supply chain has been severely affected due to COVID-19 and the Ministry has in stock particular items such as gloves, masks, face shield, googles protective, scrubs tops and pants, PVC Gum Boots, Hair head cover. “These items are part and parcel of the protective personal Equipment (PPE),” said Mr Mua. He said the ministry has yet to receive more additional orders from its emergency supply procurement through the country’s National Medical Stores system and from the its development partners particularly World Health Organisation (WHO) and DFAT this week. Mua said the ministry is also works closely collaborating with the office of the Prime Minister who is actively coordinating the airlifting of these goods. “People’s Republic of China (PRC) is also assisting us on Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) and test kits which are soon to arrive,” he said.

column31: No secret talks with China for Ports development: CEO BY BARNABAS MANEBONA Solomon Islands Ports Authority (SIPA), through its Board, has been holding constant talks with China to build and develop the country’s Ports, it is reported. It is said that several meetings have already taken place, with the current Board Chair and Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the State Owned Enterprise (SOE) taking lead over the initiative with a number of trips to China for the so-called development of the Ports Infrastructures, both in Honiara and Noro in the Western Province. From information, concern has it that the holdings in revenue of the Ports Authority is more than enough to cater for the developments cost, without having to risk borrowing for it externally on which the question raised is if whether the move for the so-called development of the Ports Infrastructures is necessary. To add, in the move to use China as the SOE’s development partner, it has been revealed that those involved to use China have looked into another move to push for the privatization of the Ports Authority, which currently operates under the government’s control, established with its own Act. PORTs CEO Mr Eranda Kotelawala in response to reports strongly rebuffs them saying these are just rumours with no substance. “Neither the Board nor me have had any discussions on port development other than with ADB. We are pursuing our plans with ADB and they have done lot of work by far in terms on pre-feasibility and feasibility for Honiara and Noro. Our visits to China were to buy the X-ray machine and participate on IAPH (International Association of Ports and Harbors) a regular member. “We are still negotiating with ADB and Government for borrowing, not with any other party. Moreover, we don’t have sufficient reserves to fund all infrastructure upgrades which would cost around SBD 600 Million. Our reserves are much lower than this,” responded Mr Kotelawala. On the alleged involvement of looking into another move to push for the privatisation of the Ports Authority, Mr Kotelawala said, “As I mentioned above our discussions are with ADB at present”. It is reported as well that with the move to push for the development in partnership approach with China, local but senior managers were seen as a threat and were therefore sacked with very short notice. With response to this, CEO Kotelawala said it is also just another rumour. “They had to leave as they had reached their retirement almost 5 years ago. Most of them should have left at the age of 55 but were given appointments by previous CEO Collin Yow. We should give opportunities to other staff. All new positions were filled by our staff within the company. SIPA is 99% local except me the only expatriate. Isn’t that good?” said Mr Kotelawala. When asked on how is the composition and operation of the current SIPA Board, as report has it that it has been running under a three-man watch, without having to fill up the total 5 member spaces provided for in the Act for quite a while now, Mr Kotelawala said “We have done the shortlist already and relevant line ministries will appoint another 3 Directors soon”. Questions are now asked as well surrounding the government’s motives and decisions to allow for the establishment of a privately owned port/wharf in the Ranandi area, owned by Lee Kwok Kuen. This in itself is said should be put under the radar as it may have breached the Ports Act and Regulations, and therefore need answers from both the Government and the Authorities responsible. And when asked on why SIPA is not taking actions against this development when it is their Act that is likely being breached, CEO Kotelawala said SIPA has already written to relevant authorities and they keep pushing this subject. “This private jetty was declared as a sufferance wharf by Customs and they need to revoke it first as it is under their prerogative. We haven't noted any substantial action against this facility so far,” said Mr Kotelawala.

column31: Great clarity, Compol by Tukai Lagonilakeba, Nadi I salute the Commissioner of Police for coming out in public to inform and reassure the Fijian public that there is no special speed limit for any Fijian. These include drivers of all Government vehicles and those who drive our country’s President, Prime Minister, Cabinet Ministers and any senior Government official on duty. As we all know special preference is only given to vehicles in an emergency like the ambulance, the National Fire Authority and Police. I would like to state that Government vehi­cle drivers are always abusing the road code rules. These Government vehicle drivers will overtake in areas forbidden on the roads they speed like it is no one’s business except them; they park on the roadside with no regard for other road users which is disre­spectful and rude. I would suggest the Commissioner of Po­lice provide a toll-free number where the public can report on these dangerous road users at any time where the Police patrol is not in sight. It is now great and very encouraging to see the many Police motorbikes and patrol vehi­cles on our roads daily. A big vinaka vakalevu to our Government and the People’s Republic of China for the donation of these vehicles’ to the Fiji Police Force because safety and security is the core role of our Police.

From Struggle to Success: Couple Behind DD Holiday Inn

BY TAVAKE SIMON HANA’AROA

THIS year marks another milestone for local entrepreneurs and couple owners of DD Holiday Inn John Deve and his wife Nester.

After almost a year in business, and almost four years from the actual time of planning and putting things together, DD Holiday Inn finally launched its official website. Anyone can access it at https://www.ddholidayinn.sb:=:https://www.ddholidayinn.sb/

John and Nester are the proud owners of the DD Holiday Inn, located at Mbumburu, Lengakiki in west Honiara.

Thanks to the Arietech, a locally owned private Information Technology (IT) Company for creating the website.

For Mr. and Mrs. Deve, it is a milestone achievement, adding that it will contribute a lot to marketing their product – in this case, DD Holiday Inn.

“I am very thankful to the Arietech Company for creating and designing the website.

“It would help to promote the Inn as a genuine accommodation for people can see it, especially those living outside of the country,” DD Holiday Inn Director John Deve said.

Arietech’s Eric Arifanata Junior said the launch of the website is an achievement for the DD Holiday Inn to promote their accommodation so that people outside can see.

“It is just a soft launch, which means it needs a further final touch up before it is complete and other features like online booking will be included as we go along.

“But this is a big achievement for them,” Eric said.

Having an official website is an essential part of the marketing strategy for any hotel business or accommodation in the current technology era.

Digital marketing for hotels and accommodation services has the key to continue sustaining the Solomon Islands tourism businesses in 2020 and beyond.

Mr. and Mrs. Deve were both former public servants who overtime decided on quitting their jobs and becoming full-time entrepreneurs.

John, a former police officer has been an entrepreneur since he was a lad and has been jumping from one business to another along the way.

Nonetheless, he said nothing beats being in the tourism business.

“Ever since I’ve ventured into this industry, this is the best business apart from other businesses that I have been established.

“It is environmentally friendly and causes no damage to the ecosystem,” he optimistically said with a smile.

DD Holiday Inn for sure is surrounded by what nature has to offer.

Nester Deve, on the other hand, is very supportive of his husband’s motives and business career paths.

“This is a family matter so I, including everyone in our family, are obliged to support my husband, our dad through thick or thin.

“We all work together to make this happen where we have witnessed this year (Friday 14th February) the launching of the website,” she said.

Catering and hosting workshops are the two main income drivers for the business since accommodation is not a marketable commodity this time of the year.

If the business meets all the minimum standards required by the Ministry of Culture and Tourism and with the help of the website, for sure, it will be meet their specific current market demand.

With her cooking skills, Mrs. Deve is in charge of the kitchen.

“My profession is teaching and I was once a Home Economics (HOME-CO) Teacher.

“I quit my teaching career eleven years ago.

“By venturing into this business and especially in food and pastry catering services, it forced me to recollect all my cooking books and kitchen utensil from the cupboard.

“It also motivated me to utilize my cooking knowledge and skills, which I had (left eleven years ago) from the classroom,” Nester Deve said.

The launch of the website, for them, is just icing on the cake.

The actual happenings, the sufferings, hustling and making things to reach this far started thirty years ago.

“I started my first business straight after I left school and that was in 1990 in Marau Sound, in the far eastern tip of Guadalcanal.

“With only $100 in my pocket, I manage to buy a drum of petrol which costs $97 per drum (44 gallons),” Mr. Deve recounted.

Deve’s petrol sales continued smoothly despite facing criticism from his customers for not selling mixed petrol, however, his next sell was perfect – he now can afford a mix from the profits he earned his previous sales.

He left to join the Police force in 1993 by leaving behind his business to his dad and siblings.

His petrol business thereafter reached a dead end when militants ransacked it during the height of the ethnic tension.

Still in the Force, he then ventures into other small businesses.

From running a fish market to hire, and then taxi services to chattering ships. He even owned a trade shop, DD shop used to be at the Kukum Highway.

He also owned a second-hand clothing at china town and was hit rock bottom as he competes alongside other Asian businesses.

He then sold the entire second-hand shop and invested on a Lucas Sawmill instead, which he started building his...

column31: Guangzhou flight delayed BY MAVIS N PODOKOLO THE flight for Guangzhou scheduled for January 24 will be delayed as Solomon Airlines still has not received approval from relevant authorities for the flight. This was confirmed by Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare yesterday in his nationwide address. “The flight scheduled for Guangzhou on 24th January will also be delayed as Solomon Airlines still had not received approval from the relevant authorities for the flight. “We are also watching the COVID-19 situation in China closely. Our health team will advise on the best possible time to reschedule based on quarantine spaces available and their assessment of COVID-19 risk to the country,” said Sogavare. He said repatriation flight scheduled for February 7 from Auckland is still on track. “We anticipate a total of 600-700 people entering the country on these flights in the January – February period,” said Sogavare. He said the third phase of Solomon Islands Governments repatriation plan has commenced with the 3rd and final flight to Fiji having arrived on Sunday night. This flight also brought in nine citizens from Kiribati. “We have another repatriation flight arriving from Auckland on January 17, 2021. “The 3rd and final repatriation flight from the Philippines had been delayed to 21st January because the final paperwork for about 30 of the students were not ready for the original date of January 11, 2020,” said Sogavare.

column31: #REGIONALNews SYDNEY (Reuters) - The Solomon Islands government says a contract signed by one of its provinces to lease the entire island of Tulagi to a Chinese company is unlawful and should be terminated. Details of the controversial long-term lease between Solomons' Central Province and China Sam Enterprise Group were made public shortly after the Pacific nation switched diplomatic ties from Taiwan to Beijing in September, which sparked a strong rebuke from the United States.

column31: Next Guangzhou flight March 5 BY MAVIS N PODOKOLO The next flight from Guangzhou has been approved for March 5. Dr Jimmie Rodgers, secretary to the Prime Minister, during the weekend covid-19 talkback show, said, “We have a flight that has been approved to come in on March 5 from Guangzhou. “The flight will bring in workers to come and construct the fourth campus of the University of South Pacific. This, is one important project for the country.” He said on that same flight about 79 workers for China Harbour will board the flight to go to Nauru. Rodgers said, “these workers will not disembark the aircraft. Only those who are destined to disembark here will disembark the airliner at the Henderson International airport. The plane will than take them over to Nauru on the same day.” He said last repatriation flight from Manila which will include students and commercial passengers is also set for March 16. Rodgers said on the 15th the flight will leave Honiara for Manila and arrive back in the country on the 16th. That flight will bring in our 44 remaining students in Manila. He adds, in April they anticipate another two flights - all those two flights are for Pacific games.

The signing took place yesterday at the Office of the Prime Minister (OPMC) between the NHA Chairman Dr Jimmy Rodgers and the Deputy PRC Ambassador to PNG and the Solomon Islands, Ambassador Yao Ming. The minutes were done following a dialogue between the NHA and the Beijing Institute of Architectural Design (BIAD). Dr Rodgers speaking during the occasion described it as a special day as it signifies the commitment the PRC government has to assist Solomon Islands. column31: In Country COVID-19 Testing– Very Soon: Sogavare BY ALEX DADAMU The capacity to do testing for COVID-19 in the country will be made available very soon at the National Referral Hospital (NRH). This was according to Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare when addressing the country today 17 th April, where he announced that most of the equipment have now being delivered to the hospital by the government and its stakeholders. PM Sogavare said, “We are grateful to New Zealand for providing the COVID 19 X-Ray machine that is now being set up at the Isolation Ward of the NRH.” He further announced that the People’s Republic of China has also donated laboratory equipment and reagents, coronavirus test kits and personal protective equipment (PPE). Many of these equipment and PPEs will arrive in the country this week by air and by sea and others will continue to arrive in due course. The PRC’s Support covers lab equipment, testing kits, Medical gloves, Personal Protective Equipment, various Masks, Medical, surgical and N95. Infrared thermometers and medical goggles. In the Meantime, Sogavare also stated that the Assistance from the World Health Organisation has arrived in the country whilst some Medical equipment and kits will arrive in the country in the coming days. Currently blood samples of COVID-19 suspects are being sent to Melbourne, Australia for testing and to date no positive case has been recorded. Ends/// Photo source: PMO

column31: LATEST NEWS Will PNG become the next stop for Chinese tourists? By Guan Juanjuan Chinese people love to travel. It’s a cultural thing, nicely summed up by the old Chinese saying: "It is better to travel ten thousand miles than to read ten thousand books." But although reading is important, traveling offers much more than what books can do. Traveling takes you beyond your imagination, and offers a unique first-hand experience of the world. That’s why China has been the home of the world’s largest number of outbound tourists since 2012. According to the United Nations World Tourism Organization, outbound tourism expenditure grew to 257.7 billion U.S. dollars in 2017 – accounting for nearly 20 percent of the world market – and is now worth 10 times what it was a decade earlier. CLICK LINK TO READ MORE: https://postcourier.com.pg/will-png-become-next-stop-chinese-tourists/

column31: Malaitans protest gov’t decision to recall PS By EDDIE OSIFELO ABOUT 200 people took the streets of Malaita provincial capital Auki yesterday to protest the recall of Provincial Secretary Fredrick Fa’abasua to Honiara. Mr Fa’abasua received his letter from Ministry of Provincial Government and Institutional Strengthening permanent secretary, Stanley Pirione on Sunday 9pm, informing him to stop work and immediately return to Honiara due to workloads in the ministry. Provincial Police Commander, Stanley Riolo confirmed the protest and his officers being on the ground to monitor it. Mr Riolo said the situation can turn worse if the government does not respond to protesters’ demand to allow Fa’abasua to continue his job in Auki. But MPGIS PS Pirione said it is a normal thing to recall provincial secretaries back to the headquarters because they work under the ministry. He said PS Fa’abasua was recalled due to pressing issues facing Malaita province so they can re-strategise ways to provide service deliveries. However, Pirione said due to the issue that came out lately, the Public Service Commission and the ministry will consult with Malaita province to sort out the issue. Malaita Premier Daniel Suidani said his MARA Government is saddened by the action of the Sogavare Government to remove its PS. Premier Suidani said the reason for recalling Fa’abasua does not make sense because the province has a lot of workload since the absence of Deputy Provincial Secretary and Treasurer. “I see this as direct action against my MARA Government by a government that is so indebt to China,” Suidani said to those who staged the protest yesterday. “Make no mistake my people, the Sogavare led government do not want Malaita to progress. This action as you rightly stated is a clear message to us that the Sogavare government only interests in making us worst off. “I can see that what you have demonstrated today is clear reaction to the Sogavare Government that is no longer have interest in the affairs of this country but only his political power. “With the arrival of the PRC ambassador it is clear Sogavare have to take actions to please the PRC. There is no question about that,” he said. “But let me assure you my good people that the MARA government will stand with you in demanding for an explanation from the national government of its action. “As you know the MARA government through its Executive has made a resolution not long ago to not allow our PS to be moved from the Province. Clearly the Government is not listening to that resolution,” he said. “I will quickly call an urgent meeting of my executive to look into this issue and make appropriate statements soon. “My good people of Malaita today we are in trying times and we must not lose hope. I can assure you that we will be set free from any decisions that go against us. “Let me assure you also that as long as the MARA government is leading the province we shall not stop fighting any injustices against the government and the people of Malaita Province. “Let us united and stand for our rights. Let us continue to be responsible for our place and for our people,” he said.

column31: Chinese Embassy donates PPEs to Makira-Ulawa MAKIRA Ulawa Province is the latest recipient of China’s continuous support to prepare the country should corona virus lands on our shores. A total of 2,000 disposal protective masks were donated to Makira Ulawa Province by the Chinese Embassy in Honiara, yesterday morning. During the brief handover ceremony, China’s Acting Ambassador to Solomon Islands Yao Ming highlighted the donation as a gesture of friendship to help Provincial Government and National Government COVID-19 preparedness and response efforts. He also shares his congratulatory note as the country marks its 42nd Independence Anniversary. Makira Ulawara Premier Julian Maka’a upon receiving the cartons of Personal Protection Equipment (PPEs) said they are grateful for China Embassy and Government for their continuous help towards the provincial centres preparedness efforts. He said the province is looking forward for further enhancement of the mutual relationship with China. Premier Maka’a then announced these supplies will go towards the Provincial Disaster Operations Committee (P-DOC) to assist work of front-liners in the Health sector. The Premier adds that there is a recording system put in place at Kirakira airport to keep track of incoming passengers. “These masks will be provided to these front-liners on the airstrip and sea ports should a corona virus case is recorded is Honiara.” “We have limited stock and this donation will stock-up our supplies as part of our preparedness mode,” he said. Officiating the ceremony is Policy Secretary Productive Sector from Office of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (OPMC) Dr Samson Viulu. Honiara’s Chinese Embassy and a leading construction group- Chinese Harbour Engineering Company has so far donated PPE’s to Honiara City Council, Guadalcanal Province and Central Province. In the meantime, Solomon Islands Government commends the cooperation of bilateral, multilateral and donor partners for their support in efforts to prepare the country to counter corona virus importation. --GCU

column31: MHMS receives more PPEs from People’s Republic of China The Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS) continues to be grateful for the ongoing support by the People’s Republic of China’s (PRC’s) commitment and dedication towards ensuring that the Ministry is well prepared to combat possible entry and outbreak of COVID-19 following the signing of a hand over certificate for more Personal Protective Equipment (PPEs) on Wednesday this week. The PPEs include 2500 medical disposable protective clothing, 5000 surgical masks, 500 medical facial masks, 500 medical protective goggles and 100 infrared themodetector. Following the signing, Yao Ming Deputy Head of Chinese Embassy in Solomon Islands stated that the government and people of China is pleased to provide the support to the Solomon Islands government through the Health Ministry to assist in Its preparedness and response to COVID-19. “It is indeed a pleasure to be handing over these PPEs to help the ministry, especially the frontline health workers and their supporting staff, in their efforts to track and combat any entry and spread of this deadly virus as well as enabling them to perform their COVID-19 operations in a safe manner”, highlighted Mr. Ming. He further added that the handing over of these PPEs is part and parcel of the overall support that PRC has continued to render to the government and people of Solomon Islands in light of COVID-19 and more importantly demonstrates PRC’s commitment and dedication towards its bilateral partnership with Solomon Islands. In response, Minister of Health and Medical Services Honorable Dickson Mua acknowledged the continuous support of PRC stating that it will greatly assist the Ministry in its current efforts to ensure Solomon Islands remain COVID-19 free but also provide safety for its frontline and supporting staff when conducting health checks at the borders. “On behalf of the Ministry I would like to thank the government and people of China for this generous donation which will go a long way in assisting the Ministry to effectively and safely perform their duties in protecting and preserving the health of its people”. Stated Minister Mua. Mr. Mua also explained the Ministry’s need to prepositioned PPEs at the provincial health facilities especially those at the country’s borders is also a priority. “With our current efforts to build capacity and enable our provincial health workers to tackle possible entry of COVID-19 by sea, these supplies will go a long way in enabling them to perform their duties effectively in a safe manner”. The first batch of the supplies were delivered from China to Honiara by air in the early May, the others were shipped from China to Port Moresby in Papua New Guinea and arrived in Honiara last week Friday. The PPEs have been jointly checked by PRC and the Ministry of Health to confirm quality, quantity and specification of the PPEs. Ends/// Source: MHMS Media Release. Photo Caption: Yao Ming Deputy Head of Chinese Embassy in Solomon Islands, left, Minister of Health and Medical Services Dickson Mua.

column31: Also in our latest issue, Netani Rika writes: The recent visit to Fiji by West Papuan freedom fighter, Benny Wenda, signals a shift which may just end in a new member of the Melanesian Spearhead Group. Since 2011, Fiji has been Indonesia’s closest ally in the South Pacific, blocking every attempt by the United Liberation Movement of West Papua to join regional discussions and gather support for an end to Jakarta’s rule. When Frank Bainimarama seized power in December 2006, Indonesia and China offered his interim government legitimacy which Fiji’s traditional allies withheld in the hope that he would return the country to democracy. At the United Nations, Indonesia supported Fiji’s nominations to key appointments within the UN system, allowing the Bainimarama regime to trumpet – through a controlled media – its recognition on the international stage. In return, Fiji ensured that human rights abuse – including torture and arbitrary killings of Papuans at the hand of Indonesian security forces – were treated in regional fora as “internal matters of a sovereign nation’’. Read more in 'Tide turns for West Papua' in the latest Islands Business https://bit.ly/3JLqO4d:=:https://islandsbusiness.com/2023/tide-turns-for-west-papua/

column31: #VIDEO: June the 4th marks the 30th anniversary of the government crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing's Tiananmen Square. The government has never released a death toll of the June 4, 1989 crackdown, but estimates from human rights groups and witnesses range from several hundreds to several thousands. China slid into economic chaos in 1988 with panic buying triggered by rising inflation peaking at more than 30 percent in cities. After weeks of protests in the square, troops backed by tanks crushed the demonstrations, prompting global condemnation. Chinese leaders denounced the demonstrations as a counter-revolutionary movement and the ensuing flurry of arrests, executions and exiles frightened many demonstrators into silence. In 2009, reformist Chinese leader Zhao Ziyang broke the official silence on the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown, denouncing the killings of protesters as a "tragedy" in recorded memoirs released four years after his death. China's President Xi Jinping has shown no sign that his administration will change their stance on the incident. [Reuters] #tiananmen #china #anniversary

column31: Cabinet approves PRC, Philippines repatriation flights CABINET at its meeting yesterday has approved the repatriation flights to Guangzhou in China and to Manila in the Philippines. The flight to Guangzhou will be on September 1, 2020, whilst the first two flights to Manila are scheduled for September 15 and 18 respectively, with the date of the 3rd flight to be confirmed. A statement from the Office of the Prime Minister & Cabinet (OPMC) stated that the decision was made after careful consideration, which also considered the risk assessment of intending travelers, the covid-19 status in both countries, and our requirement for all travelers to do pre-departure covid-19 testing which must be negative before they can be allowed to travel. “PRC is currently classified as a category-3 country. This means they experience less than 50 new cases of COVID-19 per day. All travelers from category-3 countries, must have two negative tests in the 14 days prior to travel with the 2nd test two to three days prior to departure,” it said. The statement said passengers could only board the plane if both tests are negative. “On arrival in the country all travelers from category 3 countries will undergo a mandatory 14-day quarantine period and they will have two further tests which must both be negative before they can be released,” it said. The OPMC statement said as for Philippines, it is a category-4 country. This means the country has more than 50 new cases every day (daily new cases in Philippines averages between 3,000 – 4,500). “All travelers from category-4 countries must have three Covid-19 tests in the 21 days before the flight with the 3rd test to be taken two to three days prior to the flight. They will only be allowed to board the plane if all three tests are negative for covid-19. On arrival in the country, all travelers from category-4 countries will undergo a mandatory 14-day quarantine period and they will have a further three tests which must be all negative before they can be released.” The statement adds, for both categories, doctors can keep a person longer than the 14 days and may do additional tests if so required. The maximum quarantine period is 21 days. “All intending passengers from both countries will be subjected to confirmation from the Ministry of Health & Medical Services that all pre-departure health assessment and pre-departure testing requirement are completed, and results sent to our health authority before they can travel. All incoming passengers must be individually approved,” the statement said. “All passengers regardless of their nationality or status will and must undergo strict testing and quarantine protocols prior to, during and after arrival. “According to our testing protocols, all passengers must undergo two tests before boarding the flight from category-3 countries and three tests before for category-4 countries. Anyone who is tested positive will not board the flight,” it said. The OPMC statement adds, the flight to China will be undertaken for purposes of repatriating our Solomon Island citizens. It will also bring in the new PRC Ambassador to Solomon Islands and some members of the Embassy staff, the PG2023 technical team and workers of major Chinese companies working in major infrastructure projects in the country comprising a total of 88 passengers. With regards to Philippines, the statement said about 403 students and dependents are to be repatriated through three charter flights. All students must do three covid-19 test each prior to travelling. It said the ministries of Education, Foreign Affairs and Health are coordinating the testing arrangements with the assistance from the World Health Organisation. The statement highlighted that the Government has acknowledged that these challenging and unprecedented times require Cabinet to make tough decisions for the betterment of our country. “The decision to repatriate our citizens from China was taken after a thorough analysis of risks and benefits. Cabinet is convinced that if our testing protocol is followed with pre-departure testing and post arrival quarantine and testing, we will prevent the introducing covid-19 into the country. The Cabinet believes that we can continue to conduct important business in the country and still keep covid-19 out of our beloved country,” it said. The statement clarified that the same treatment is given to all our bilateral and multilateral partners who are needed in the country to ensure our national projects are progressing. “China does not get preferential treatment as people might like to think,” it said. The statement adds other flights to repatriate citizens currently stranded in New Zealand, Australia, United Kingdom, USA and other European countries, as well as to bring in key foreign personnel for our development partner missions that help finance major development projects in the country are also in the planning process. The same arrangement will be done for engineers (truncated)

column31: GOV’T COMMITTED TO SPORTS: NIENG BY PETER ZOLEVEKE JNR THE Solomon Islands government through the Sol2023 National Hosting Authority for the 2023 Pacific Games is serious in its preparations to host the games in Honiara. Preparations towards building of the facilities for the games were forced to slow down due to the outbreak of the Coronavirus in China which saw many countries cancelling international flights to and from China. A second scoping team from mainland China was supposed to arrive this month after a first scoping team visited the country December last year. Despite the minor setback, NHA Executive Director Mr. Christian Nieng is confident everything will be done on time saying the government is very serious about providing sports facilities for not only hosting the games but also for sports men and women after the two weeks sporting event. Mr. Nieng said while the National Sports Council in the past has done and tried its best to provide facilities and help our athlete’s preparations but to no avail because there was no support from the government, however that is about to change. “The government is putting in place measures to make sure facilities are built and that sports activities are not only active in Honiara but also in all our provinces,” he said on Saturday. “It was not until we have the chance of hosting the 2023 Pacific Games that the government has seriously started looking and showing a strong commitment to have facilities and establish programs to help develop not only our athletes but also our local coaches. “Looking back the NSC has done its best in the past trying to set up federations, activities, building facilities and helping train our athletes without the support of the government. “But now the government has said they are committed to help address these areas in preparation for the 2023 Pacific Games,” he said. While there is now strong support from the government for sports development in the country, it seems some donor countries are already talking about setting boundaries to differentiate the facilities their government will be funding. “I still don’t know the whole details of the MOUs yet but we will get together soon to discuss with these key stake holders about the National Sports Facilities we are going to build,” Nieng said. But with only less than three more years to go, most critics of the government are already predicting the government will likely throw in the towel from hosting the 2023 Pacific Games due to the time wasted on signing MOUs after winning the bid in 2016. CAPTION: NHA Executive Director Mr. Chris Nieng

column31: Two Fiji citizens are currently in isolation at Nadi hospital after arriving from Guangdong, China on Monday with "mild symptoms." column31: Government Announces Repatriation of Stranded Nationals THE Government’s Covid-19 Oversight Committee has announced the repatriation of Solomon Islands Nationals who are stranded in Australia and Fiji as a result of flight closures due to covid-19. Chair of the Covid-19 Oversight Committee and Secretary to Cabinet, James Remobatu made the announcement in the latest Travel advisory number two issued on 14 May 2020. The announcement is made in accordance to the statement issued by Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare on the 1st of May 2020 on the government’s plans for repatriation. Remobatu said the government is pleased to announce that Solomon Islands will have the capacity to conduct tests for covid-19 in-country by this week. The first repatriation flight for stranded nationals in Australia and New Zealand is tentatively scheduled for 26 May. The flight will be from Brisbane to Honiara. All nationals boarding the flight must have valid Solomon Airlines tickets. The government is also looking at repatriating nationals in covid-19 free Vanuatu and Fiji thereafter. Flight information will be issued as soon as it is finalized. It is government’s standing position to have all returning passengers from overseas to undergo a mandatory 28 days quarantine in one of the state’s identified quarantine facility. The government of Solomon Islands is committed to take measures to prevent importation of covid-19 in the country and prevent subsequent outbreaks. “We urge the stranded nationals to take adequate precautions while being in affected countries and seek immediate medical care in case of sickness,” Remobatu said. The Government of Solomon Islands takes this time to thank the government of the people’s republic of china and the government of Australia for fast tracking the supply of the two covid-19 testing machines. “We thank the nation for its prayers, our gratitude to all receiving states for hosting our stranded citizens. Our respect to the families of all stranded Wantoks for your patience and solidarity. “We urge everyone to remain united in keeping covid-19 out from entering our borders. With the grace of god we will do all we can to ensure we come out of this stronger and united,” Remobatu said. ENDS/// Government Communication Unit Press Release. Photo: Outsourced

column31: Work on East Malaita mini-hospital progresses BY SAMIE WAIKORI Auki CONSTRUCTION work on the $40 million mini-hospital project at Tatali, Atori in East Malaita constituency is progressing well. The project is funded by the People’s Republic of China (PRC) through East Malaita constituency carrying on from an initial funding arrangement by ROC which stopped in 2019 following the diplomatic switch. Constituency Project Officer (CPO) for East Malaita, Mr William Kwalemanu told SunAuki yesterday: “At the moment we reach the concrete slabbing stage of the first component of the project which include outpatient, emergency and acute wards of the mini-hospital.” He said work on the slabbing is underway and construction is on time to complete the first component of the project within the three months given. Kwalemanu said they are left only with mesh-wires, cements and gravels from the first shipment of materials for the project. He said that he is in Honiara and they are working on the second shipment of materials to further progress constructions. “Materials already arranged with suppliers and soon they will ship to Atori to begin the second component of the project,” Kwalemanu said. Speaking during delivery of materials for the projects months ago, Member of Parliament of East Malaita constituency, Deputy Prime Minister and Ministry for Infrastructure Development, Manasseh Maelanga said the eventuation of project will be a lift to health services in the eastern region of the project. He said services the min-hospital will provide when complete will not only benefit people in East Malaita constituency alone, but people as far as East Are Are and Ata. The mini hospital project is constructed by Harly Designs Consultancy Limited, a local company from Isabel province. ////////////

column31: WUSI strengthens relationship with PRC By EDDIE OSIFELO WORKERS Union of Solomon Islands (WUSI) and Peoples Republic of China (PRC) embassy staff have reinforced their relationship following their meeting in Honiara on Monday 20th April. This meeting came after Solomon Islands had switched diplomatic ties from Republic of China (Taiwan) to PRC last September. WUSI was represented in the meeting by President, David Tuhanuku, General Secretary, Tony Kagovai and executive members and reps from Solomon Kitano Mendana Hotel, Pan Oceanic Bank, Guadalcanal Province. Shen Weizu and Shao Hesong represented the staff of PRC Embassy. Shao told the delegation that if there is no coronavirus, the WUSI members should visit China on March. He said the WUSI members will still visit China when the pandemic is over. WUSI President, Tuhanuku said the China relationship with Solomon Islands is very crucial when we are living in an advance world of technology. He said this is important for the Solomon Islands which has her bulk of population in the rural areas. As such, Tuhanuku said WUSI is looking forward to develop the relationship with PRC. General Secretary, Kagovai said WUSI used to be a non-active member of the All-China Federation of Trade Unions (ACFTU). However, with the new relationship with Solomon Islands, WUSI will now be the active member of ACFTU. ACFTU is the nationalised organisation federation of the People's Republic of China. It is the largest trade union in the world with 302 million members in 1,713,000 primary trade union organizations. The ACFTU is divided into 31 regional federations and 10 national industrial unions. The ACFTU is the country's sole legally-mandated trade union, with which all enterprise-level trade unions must be affiliated. There has been dispute over whether ACFTU is an independent trade union or even a trade union at all. Currently, WUSI has 7000 active members from the nine provinces mainly in industries and private sectors.

column31: Bula We hope your weekend is turning out the way you planned it. Here’s a sneak peek at some of the headlines in the Sunday Times – March 14. NEWS: NFP leader Professor Biman Prasad raises a point in the big one on Page 1. Fijians must be made aware of how the proposed Local Government (Municipal Market Regulations) was released, says National Federation Party leader Professor Biman Prasad. Prof Prasad said the Local Government Minister Premila Kumar must clarify who had circulated the regulations to numerous market vendors’ associations for discussion. Mrs Kumar had said that the copies of the regulations circulated among the market vendors was not the final document. PAGE 2: GROWING up on a maritime island in the Lau Group was not easy for Filipe Ratu. But it was this experience that motivated the Naceva villager on Cicia Island to work hard in school. Yesterday, he reaped the fruits of his hard work when he was among 12 recipients of the Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara Education Trust Fund Scholarships and Loans. FIJIANS planning to return to Fiji for personal reasons, such as visiting friends and family, will be required to pay for their mandatory 14-day quarantine. THERE was an increase in the use of methamphetamine in schools last year. This, according to data released by the Fiji Police Force. Police said methamphetamine was first discovered in Fiji in 1978. PAGE 3: TWELVE out of the 237 crimes against children recorded between 2019 and 2020 were siblings related. MINISTER for Women, Children and Poverty Alleviation, Mereseini Vuniwaqa says the Government recognises its obligation to prevent violence against all women and girls. PEOPLE living in poverty and the destitute should be the heart of service for anyone serving the Catholic Church in Fiji. PAGE 4: A TOTAL of 33 mineral special prospecting licences have been issued by the Department of Mineral Resources. While speaking at a public consultation in Lautoka yesterday, acting director of Mineral Resources Raymond Mohammed said the special prospecting licences were different from the mining licences issued by the department. THE Fiji Police Force recorded 20 murder cases last year. A report pointed out the cases had decreased when compared with 2019, when 26 murder cases were recorded. LETTERS TO THE EDITOR: Writers continue to voice their opinions on various issues they feel are important for the nation. PAGE 7: BEHIND THE NEWS with JOHN KAMEA – In recent years our country has witnessed a steady increase in illegal activities and the emergence of new forms of crimes. Violent robberies, sexual assaults, human trafficking and drug crimes have all injected a feeling of fear and insecurity in us and in the communities we live in. INTERNATIONAL: ROME – The big one is on the announcement that most of Italy, including its capital Rome and its financial centre Milan, will have curbs on business and movement intensified from Monday as the government ramps up its efforts to stem a steady rise in coronavirus cases. The country will also be placed under a nationwide lockdown over the Easter weekend for the second year running, the government said on Friday. WASHINGTON - The United States and three of its closest Indo-Pacific partners committed to supplying up to a billion coronavirus vaccine doses across Asia by the end of 2022 at a summit on Friday carefully choreographed to counter China’s growing influence. LOOK BACK IN HISTORY: A MAN who was out fishing discovered a body floating face upwards in the Dreketi River. It was the body of 24-year-old Dharam Wati of Natua. The villager who found Mrs Wati’s body had quickly alerted villagers who later informed the deceased’s husband at their home. The Fiji Times on this day in 1986 reported on the incident. DISCOVERING FIJI: IF you are on Nokonoko Rd and approaching Laucala Beach Estate, Nasinu Town’s premier residential area, the first right turn you come across will take you to Sekoula Rd. From here, the third right turn leads to Tagimoucia Pl, at the end of which, a short dirt track will end at one of Fiji’s cultural and historical gold mines. Virtually hidden and unknown, this is the site of the twin Laucala Beach Ring Ditch Fortification, remains of an old village that was demolished by war in 18th century Fiji. BOLLYBAAT: NEW Delhi - Kiara Advani has the right lines when she opens up about her future plans. She wants to be “that actor who is good in every film”, does not want to be defined by her hits and misses in Hindi film industry. FOOD with LANCE SEETO: If you have never heard of Manchurian chicken at your local Chinese restaurant, then chances are the chef has never travelled to India, as this iconic dish was invented not in China. Here in Fiji, those who are familiar with this stir fry dish have probably met a chef from India who has brought this spicy fusion dish to our shores. So how did a dish with Chinese origins end up becoming a popular Indian favourite? SPORTS: The big one in Sports is (truncated)

column31: Civil society call on government to confirm withdrawal of intention to borrow USD100b Leaders of some of the Honiara based Civil Society Organisations (CSOs) in a meeting organised and held at the Solomon Islands National Council of Women last week, have condemned the proposed action of Minister of Finance and Treasury, Harry Kuma, for attempting to solicit USD100 billion from China without prior consultation with the Central Bank of Solomon Islands as reported in the Solomon Islands print media. A spokesperson from the Solomon Islands National Council of Women on behalf of the CSO leaders attending the meeting, said that they have noted the action by the Minister in his official capacity as serious, violating the Public Finance Act of Solomon Islands. CSO Leaders also feel that his action is a breach of his Oath of Allegiance as Minister of the Crown, not being loyal to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, and in performing his duties of not protecting and serving the interest of Solomon Islands Citizens and the nation. CSO leaders request the Minister to apologise to the nation on behalf of the DCGA Government because of the intended cause of action he took with the Broker by the name of Mr Terry Wong, to deal with few businessmen in China for the purpose of lending to the Solomon Islands Government USD100 billion. “This is a total breach of his Oath and Allegiance and therefore, should do the right thing by apologising to the nation,” they say. Solomon Islands as a sovereign nation must follow protocols in dealing with such serious loan matters on government to government basis and not using middle men with a predetermined 11 percent heavy interest fee, which will benefit only a few cronies to become billionaires overnight if the loan proposal is to be materialised. The Solomon Islands Government does not have the capacity to mortgage such a huge loan, and therefore will commit all Solomon Islands individual citizen, tribal land with its minerals and sea resources thus setting a new suicidal debt trap for all Solomon Islanders and our future generations to come. The CSO group also call on the Governor General of Solomon Islands to summon the Minister because of his negligence and respect of the Oath he took prior to taking up his position as Finance Minister. It would be for the interest of the nation for the Governor General to advise the Finance Minister on behalf of all Solomon Islands Citizens for the Minister to apologise or even better resign accordingly. CSOs also want to know whether the DCGA will continue to formalise consultations on the loan through the so called Mr Wong, or now have formally withdrawn its intention to pursue further negotiations on the matter. -SINCW PRESS

column31: The Papua New Guinea Government and Business delegation, headed by the Prime Minister, Hon. Peter O’Neill CMG MP, was accorded full ceremonial honours by the Government of China on their arrival in Beijing overnight. Prime Minister O’Neill, Mrs Lynda Babao-O’Neill, senior Government Ministers and Members of Parliament, together with a delegation of senior business representatives, now begin a series of engagements that includes bilateral meetings with the Premier and President of China, and current and potential Chinese investors. “Papua New Guinea must reach out and engage with our foreign partners so we can increase trade, stimulate business and create new jobs,” the Prime Minister said. “China is now the second largest economy in the world and has enormous market potential for our exports. “This includes exports of oil and gas, but now that we are broadening our own economic base in areas such as agriculture and tourism, we can attract future business from China. “This is important for current economic growth, and even more important, the economy opportunities we are creating for our children and future generations.” Source: Press Release #EMTVNew

column31: More trade deals for the country By EDDIE OSIFELO MINISTRY of Foreign Affairs has signed up to a number of trade frameworks. These included: 1. Pacific Agreement on Closer Economic Relations (PACER plus); 2. European Union – Pacific States interim Economic Partnership Agreement (EU iEPA); 3. United Kingdom – Pacific States interim Economic Partnership Agreement (UK iEPA); 4. Melanesian Free Trade Agreement (MFTA) and 5. Peoples Republic of China (PRC) Non-Reciprocal Duty-Free Preferences Minister of Foreign Affairs and External Trade, Jeremiah Manele told Parliament last week that on PACER plus, current developments are now directed towards continuing the implementation of ongoing support from Australia and New Zealand towards implementation of the agreement and fulfilling their obligations in transparency, trainings of contacts point, customs procedures, implementation of market access commitments and identification of priority areas for implementation under the PACER Plus Development and Economic Cooperation Work Programme. The PACER Plus was ratified by Solomon Islands 23 June 2020 and entered into effect on 13 December 2020. The Agreement was signed by eleven (11) Pacific countries and ratified by eight (8) countries On EU iEPA, Manele said on 7 May 2020 Solomon Islands completed accession procedures, the Agreement provisionally commenced 17 of May 2020 for Solomon Islands. He said Solomon Islands requests for derogation for global sourcing and application of customs duties on exports was granted by the European Union with notification received September 2020. “The derogation on global sourcing is where Solomon Islands stands most to gain in enabling export of processed fish to the EU and attain preferential market access, even if sourced from foreign vessels beyond our EEZ,” he said. On UK iEPA, Solomon Islands deposited its Instrument of Accession on 2nd December 2020. Solomon Islands and the UK signed the MOU on 21 and 22 December 2020, which allows the application of the UK iEPA from 1 January 2021. Manele said the UK iEPA which is a duplication of the EU iEPA contains the same commitments and even a replicate of the time bound commitments and derogations as contained in the EU iEPA. He said the agreement is important for our Oil Palm exports as our main export destination is UK. On MFTA, Solomon Islands is currently implementing the MSGTA2 concluded in 2005. Manele said the revised comprehensive Melanesian Free Trade Agreement (MFTA) was concluded and signed by Solomon Islands in 2017, Vanuatu and PNG have yet to sign the Agreement. He said the agreement requires two (2) countries to sign and ratify the agreement. “Solomon Islands has completed internal processes and is prepared to submit an instrument of ratification,” he said. Furthermore, on PRC Non-Reciprocal Duty-Free Preferences with Solomon Islands, an exchange of notes done between two countries on 11 December 2020 to formalize utilization of non-reciprocal preferential market access into China. The arrangement came into force on 1 February 2021. Manele said the arrangement allows for Solomon Islands exports to receive preferential tariff treatment for 97% of tariff lines if meeting the originating requirements as per the Rules of Origin (RoO). He said the Ministry is exploring trade and economic opportunities that China offers that will help in developing a more comprehensive trade framework.

column31: Sogavare hails donor support towards covid-19 fight Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare has praised donor partners for their ongoing support to the Government towards the fight against covid-19. Sogavare made particular mention of the Governments of Australia, New Zealand and the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for their ongoing support towards Solomon Islands even when these countries are battling covid-19 which has affected their own people. Solomon Islands and PRC signed a Framework Agreement Establishing Diplomatic Relations between the two countries only six months ago and Sogavare was inspired that this relationship has not only developed, but made invaluable progress despite the limitations caused by the covid-19 Pandemic. The Government of the People’s Republic of China through its Honiara Embassy has handed over three distinct partnership programmes last week which included a grant assistance towards hosting the 2023 Pacific Games combined with cash donations to support the government’s covid-19 response and Tropical Cyclone Harold rehabilitation. The People’s Republic of China has also donated laboratory equipment and reagents, coronavirus test kits and personal protective equipment. Many of these equipment and PPEs will arrive in the country this week by air and sea and others will continue to arrive in due course. These support covers laboratory equipment, testing kits, Medical gloves, Personal Protective Equipment, various Masks, Medical, surgical and N95. Infrared thermometers and medical goggles. All other bilateral partners and donors including Australia and New Zealand are continuously supporting the Government during this hard time. --GOVERNMENT COMMUNICATION UNIT

column31: ‘Closely watched’ PGC impressed with Sol2023 progress BY PETER ZOLEVEKE II THE Pacific Games Council has been impressed so far with the Solomon Islands government progress towards hosting the Pacific Games 2023 here, as the regional body ‘closely watched’ the facilities development taking place. Speaking exclusively to SunSPORTS, PGC Chief Executive Officer, Mr Andrew Minougue said despite the delays posed by the Covid-19 pandemic the Sol2023 National Hosting Authority is making significant progress. “The Pacific Games Council is pleased to note the progress Solomon Islands Government and the National Hosting Authority are continuing to make in securing the necessary donor arrangements to deliver the venues on time for the 2023 Pacific Games,” Mr Minougue stated. “The PGC continues to monitor the situation closely watching developments in the making. The CEO will be making monthly visits to the country once restrictions are lifted, and the situation returns to normality. NHA recently have locked in all funding donor partners confirmed to kick off facilities constructions on the ground although the State of Public Emergency is still effective. “The Solomon Islands government (SIG), Peoples Republic of China (PRC) and the Republic of Indonesia (ROI) has finalized the funding assistance for most of the facilities needed to host the 2023 Pacific Games,” an NHA statement last week reads. “COVID 19 has posed a lot of challenges to the construction of the sporting facilities needed to host the 2023 Pacific Games but a lot of work is going on behind the scene and the donors are doing everything within their means to ensure that the facilities are completed in time before the opening ceremony. Following a visit by PGC late last year the CEO assured the national government that there will still be enough time to prepare for 2023, despite the uncertainty over the spread of the deadly virus. Meanwhile, NHA will be establishing a Games Organizing Committee, especially to oversee the immediate matters of the games.

column31: Wale’s Claim Aims to Create Political Instability THE Democratic Coalition Government for Advancement wishes to correct the leader of the Parliamentary opposition’s media statement claiming that the Prime Minister’s $200,000 NDF is not for development but for political expediency. This is not true. The NDF was first established by the ROC when they provided these funds for discretionary use by the Prime Minister. Previous Prime Ministers have exercised their discretion in allocating these funds. However, when ROC gave these funds they did not require that these funds be used for development projects. This has now changed under the Peoples Republic China but only until 2022. This arrangement is to ensure a transitionary period after we switched diplomatic relations and will end in 2022. However, under PRC, the NDF will only be used for development projects upon application. It says, Opposition MPs may wish to submit their proposals to the Prime Minister’s Office if they wish to. Wale’s false ignorance is shameful. It is NOT the PRC’s intention to interfere with national politics nor an egregious breach of Solomon Islands sovereignty as Mr Wale erroneously claimed. PRC does not even intend this to undermine the government’s ability to maintain semblance of independence in its foreign policy, far from it. These funds are for developing the constituencies through projects. For example, these NDF was used in the Marovo Constituency to connect the hospital to the main power grid, repainting of the full hospital, electrical rewiring and refitting, purchase and installation of ceiling fans and air cons. Hon. Wale was there last week during the inquiry into the Public Health Emergency Bill, yet he has accused the Government of using the funds for political purposes when these funds were actually used to benefit the sick people of Marovo Constituency. The politicization of the diplomatic switch to PRC overt and covert by some of our politicians is becoming childish and tedious. We should all be focusing on development and not on politicking. Source: GCU Press

column31: RSIPF Investigates the Suspicious Death of a Chinese National in Honiara POLICE investigators at the Naha Police Station in East Honiara are investigating the suspicious death of a Chinese national inside the compound of the Top Timber Company at Ranadi, yesterday 7 April 2021. The deceased from Guandong Province in China, was employed by the Top Timber Company as the Grading and Consultation Supervisor. He resided at the Top Timber compound where the incident occurred. Provincial Police Commander (PPC) Honiara City Superintendent John Matamaru said, “An initial report states that in the early hours of 7 April 2021, the deceased was seen by a neighbor arriving back home with a female in his car. Few hours later the same witness saw the deceased and the female leave his house and drove out in his vehicle from the Top Timber compound. Later at about 5am the same witness saw the deceased arrive back alone and went straight into his house.” “At about 7am the deceased’s house girl went up to the deceased room and knocked on his bedroom door but he never answered.” PPC Matamaru added, “At 1:30pm on 7 April, a male colleague went to check on the deceased after he failed to answer his phone. The body of the deceased was discovered in his room after his colleague managed to enter with the key located in the car of the deceased.” The body of the deceased was transported to the National Referral Hospital by the St John Ambulance where he was pronounced dead by a doctor. “I want to appeal to members of the public living near and around the area of incident to come forward with any information to help police with their investigation into this sad incident,” said PPC Matamaru. Ends/// SOURCE: RSIPF MEDIA UNIT

column31: Confiscated covid-19 supplies released, investigation continues: Police. THE Royal Solomon Island Police Force (RSIPF) has released confiscated covid-19 medical equipment supplied by the Republic of China, Taiwan, to the Malaita Provincial Government equipment following advice from the Office of the Director of Public Prosecution (ODPP). The RSIPF and the Customs Department seized the equipment last month following a formal complaint from the Office of the Attorney General about the suspicious nature of the consignment. “RSIPF has investigated the complaint and a report was sent to the ODPP. The ODPP then advised the RSIPF to release the equipment but the investigation into the matter continues. Our investigators have taken photographs of the equipment as evidence before releasing them,” says RSIPF Commissioner Mostyn Mangau. “No one has been arrested or no charges have been laid against any one so far as the investigation into the matter continues.” The COVID-19 medical equipment was released to the Malaita Provincial Government on August 17, 2020. --POLICE MEDIA

For the China region alone, the lost revenues could total $12.8 billion.

column31: IN PICTURES: GPG Courtesy Visit to Gold Ridge Mining Site. THE Guadalcanal Executive and Assembly members have paid a courtesy visit to the Gold Ridge Mining site today morning. The team was led by the Premier Francis Sade and his Deputy Premier, Hon. Lazarus Rina. The courtesy visit is part of the ongoing approach that Mr. Walter Naezon, Director of Gold Ridge Mining Limited (GRLM)/ Goldridge Company Investment Limited (GCIL) had with the Guadalcanal Provincial Government in terms of its tax obligations (basic rates, property rates, and business license) since early this year. Now that GP Assembly had passed the relevant ordinances, Mr. Naezon is looking forward to working closely with GPG to ensure both parties are satisfied. Upon arrival, the GPG team was briefed on the GRLM’s history, past challenges, ongoing developments, and future opportunities in the GRML main office. In addition, the GP leaders also learned about the process of the extractions of ores and also the tailing dams. Speaking of tailing dams, Mr. Naezon stated that they are closely monitoring the risks level of the dams to stop another possible overflow like the one that happened in 2016 which resulted in the SIG to declare the site as a “disaster zone”. To do this, Mr. Naezon explained that drains were being dug beside the tailing dams to divert the runoffs from hills during heavy rains. He said “Communities downstream are regularly consulted and informed about the water levels. The diversion measures should give some leverage until proper treatments are completed”. Mr. Naezon then told the GP team “running the only major mining company in the Country is not an easy task, especially when you have to start from scratch”. He explained that Cyclone Ita devastated the mining in 2014, the St. Barbara (Australia company) had sold the mine for only AU$100. “So, there are tonnes or issues; from cultural, social, economics, and legal issues thrown to us at the very beginning!” he exclaimed. However, five years later, the GCIL is redeveloping the mine with loan-contract worth of $823 million dollars. The leading redevelopers and equity shareholders of the mining site are Wanguo International (Chinese miner) and AFX Group (Chinese based Australian company). They had contracted China Rail ($275 million) to start with the production since last year. The GCIL Director then stated that the company planned to recruit 200 plus workers next year, and will increase the figure once the mine is fully operational. The employment priorities will be giving to Guadalcanal people first before other provinces. He explained that this is to address Guadalcanal’s unemployment rate issues. He furthered that GCIL is doing all its best to follow the legal process under the mining laws and regulations in the country. In response, Premier Sade thanked Mr. Naezon for his hospitality during the courtesy visit, and more importantly his determination and vision to redevelop the mining company and prioritize employment to the people of Guadalcanal. He told Mr. Naezon that the current Executive Government is willing to support Mr. Naezon, especially in addressing the ongoing “illegal miners” issue at the mining sites. The illegal miners, according to Mr. Naezon, has posed great health risks for themselves by digging golds in these sites. In relation, the current Guadalcanal Provincial Executive is also proposing a mining ordinance sometimes next year. Ends/// With Pictures SOURCE: GP MEDIA

column31: -China Red Cross steps in to help SI in Tropical Cyclone Harold relief efforts -PRC handed over $2.5m to combat COVID-19 BY ALEX DADAMU The China Red Cross with reports of damages done by recent devastating cyclone Harold, has decided to contribute to help Solomon Islands Government in its relief efforts. A total amount of US$100,000 which was equivalent to SBD$800,000 was handed over to the government of Solomon Islands on Wednesday 16th April as part of its assistance towards rehabilitation efforts in the aftermath of Tropical Cyclone Harold. The official handing over of the funds was made to the Country’s Foreign Affairs and External Trade Minister, Jeremiah Manele at the Prime Minister’s Office by Counsellor Yao Ming of the Republic of China Embassy. The assistance towards SI Government’s TC Harold relief efforts was one of the two cheques worth SBD$3.3m delivered by the People’s Republic of China (PRC) Government to the Government help combat COVID-19 and to support the country’s rehabilitation efforts post TC Harold. $2.5m (USD$300,000) of the total $3.3m will go towards combating COVID-19 whilst the $800,000 (USD$100,000) from China Red Cross will assist the country in its recovery efforts following Tropical Cyclone Harold. The People’s Republic of China has also recently donated corona virus test kits and personal protective equipments which according to Hon Jeremiah Manele, will arrive in the country in due course. Ends///
