column31: Bula Here are the headlines for Monday’s edition – March 8. The big one is about dialysis and how it has impacted a young man. A 22-YEAR-OLD Lautoka man diagnosed with End-stage Kidney Disease says he feels cheated because medical staff in Lau­toka misdiagnosed him until it was too late. Shynal Narayan claimed that despite nu­merous visits to the Kamikamica Health Centre and Lautoka Hospital, doctors had failed to diagnose his kidney issue. While Ministry of Health’s permanent secretary Doctor James Fong said juve­nile diabetes was rare and difficult to diag­nose, Mr Narayan maintains his family has had to scrape together $400 a week to pay for life-sustaining hemodialysis. In the second report on Page 1, those having legal custody over children could face a five-year jail term and $10,000 fine for negligence over children during a natu­ral disaster under the draft Police Bill 2020. Parents and guard­ians are to ensure that their children are safe out of harm’s way dur­ing disasters. The Bill has received wide public outcry from political parties who have labelled it as draconian and an in­sult to human rights. PAGE 2: FIJIANS have endured too much, says Social Democratic Liberal Party (SODELPA) leader Viliame Gavoka. He made the comment in relation to the proposed Police Bill that was recently launched by the Ministry of Defence and National Security to replace the existing 1965 Police Act. "It is draconian and should raise an alarm to all right-thinking citizens as it encroaches into civil liberties, democratic values, and fundamental rights of our people," he said. WE are always looked at as a woman and not a leader. These were the words of Minister for Education, Heritage and Arts Rosy Akbar while speaking at the Soroptimist International hosted International Women's Day celebrations in Ba yesterday. PARENTS and guardians will face a five-year jail term and $10,000 fine if they fail to ensure the safety of their children during a natural or man-made disaster, states the draft Police Bill 2020. The proposed law requires parents, guardians, or any other person to ensure a child is made aware of adverse weather, natural or man-made disaster. PAGE 3: THE Attorney-General and Minister for Economy Aiyaz Sayed-Khaiyum needs a reality check, says National Federation Party president Pio Tikoduadua. He made this comment while responding to Mr Sayed-Khaiyum's appeal to Fijians who were receiving unemployment benefit assistance through the Fiji National Provident Fund (FNPF) to look for employment. THE COVID-19 pandemic has been a blessing in disguise for musician William Waqanibaravi enabling him to work on his newly released album Rai Lesu. Known in the local music industry as Big Wilz, the Dakuiloa native of Oneata said the pandemic gave him time to finish his album especially after being laid off from Fiji Airways. UNTIL now Fiji has recorded 167 dialysis patients surviving on machine reveals the Health Ministry permanent secretary Dr James Fong. Responding to questions from this newspaper, Dr Fong said of this 106 were from the Central Division while 40 were from the West and 21 cases in Labasa. BACK IN HISTORY: Page 6 - Joe's Farm Supermarket is a well-known shop in Tamavua, and the story behind the success of this business was published in The Fiji Times on July 11, 1984. Things had come a long way for the founders of Joes Farm Produce, Joe Youn and his wife Linda. Mr Joe arrived from China 30 years ago determined to carve a good life for himself and his wife. LETTERS TO THE EDITOR: Pages 8 and 9 – Read letters on various issues that matter to readers. PEOPLE: YOGA has nothing to do with race, it is all about receiving physical and mental benefits. These were the sentiments of Sangeeta Devi Kumar of Kuku, Nausori, a yoga instructor for more than 10 years. At present, she teaches the ancient Indian discipline at the Swami Vivekananda Cultural Centre at the Indian High Commission, Suva. POINT OF ORIGIN: This column comes out every Monday. Read about Geoff Taylor. AFTER calling Fiji home for about 50 years, Mr Taylor has many a tale to tell. There was the time he met movie star Robert Redford at the Savusavu Yacht Club, a plan hatched at the same venue to sail eight-foot dinghies around the world and how he turned an old copra storage shed into a major attraction in the Hidden Paradise of Fiji. And because he did so much over the past five decades, Mr Taylor jotted it all down in a book titled Not My Fault – Memories of a Field Geologist in Fiji. SPORTS: The big one is on soccer. In the tale of two cities, defending Digicel Premier League champion Suva and Western giants Lautoka are currently tied at top of the points table with round one done and dusted at the weekend. Suva and Lautoka booked 1-nil wins yesterday over opponents Rewa and Navua respectfully. There’s so much more to read in your Monday edition. But you’ll have to get a copy to know what we are talking about. Happy reading!

column31: S.I – U.S Bilateral Talks a success: US Committed to Do More SOLOMON Islands Prime Minister the Honourable Manasseh Sogavare warmly welcomed US National Security Council Coordinator for the Indo –Pacific, Kurt Campbell to Solomon Islands following a friendly and productive meeting on 22 Friday April, 2022. The two countries reaffirmed their friendship and committed to strengthen their relations and work together on all issues of mutual concerns. Visiting delegation leader Kurt Campbell reassures Prime Minister Sogavare that the United States is back “We will do better,” and committed to do more in Solomon Islands. Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare acknowledged with gratitude United States revitalized relations with Solomon Islands and welcome once again US decision to re-establish its Embassy in the country and acknowledge the recent signing of MCC Threshold Programme. The senior White House Official added, US will provide more assistance in addressing unexploded ordnance, supplying COVID 19 vaccines, provide medical support, reopen the Peace Corps program and look at expanding the SCALE Programme to other provinces. US is committed to ensuring the clearing of the WW2 EOD and would look into the issue of oil spill in the Iron Bottom Sound. On the China-Solomon Islands Security Cooperation, “We have no say on the SI-China agreement. We respect Solomon Islands sovereign decision. There is no misunderstanding,” stated the White House Official. US’s core concern is China establishing a military base in Solomon Islands, this will have regional security implications. The Prime Minister responded, contrary to misinformation promoted by anti-government critics, the Solomon Islands – China Security Cooperation is not about China establishing a military base in Solomon Islands but is about supporting the state to address its internal hard and soft security threats. It is not directed at any external security interest. The Solomon Islands – China Security Cooperation compliments other bilateral and regional security arrangement Solomon Islands is a Party to. Prime Minister Sogavare was also acknowledged for his outstanding leadership through the many challenges facing the young nation. The two states registered appreciation for the talks and committed their officials.to meet in September to advance identified areas of cooperation. SOURCE: PM Press Secretariat

column31: IN PICTURES: Astra Arrives: Rollout Wednesday - China’s Sinopharm Vaccine Next Month TODAY Friday 19th March marks a significant milestone in the country’s fight against COVID-19 with the arrival of the first 24,000 doses of COVID-19 AstraZeneca vaccine. Minister of Health and Medical Services, Culwick Togamana said this is the first of the many more consignments of COVID-19 vaccine that the government and partners are working hard to bring into the country in its endeavour to protect all of its citizens against the global pandemic. According to the Health Minister, despite the high global demand of these vaccines, Solomon Islands are amongst many countries in the world to receive the AstraZeneca vaccine and also among few Pacific Island Countries to have received the COVID-19 vaccine. “This 24,000 doses of AstraZeneca vaccine is the first tranche of the 108,000 doses confirmed by COVAX Facility to cover 20 percent of our population. “Those vaccines are provided by Serum Institute in India through GAVI,” Health Minister Togamana said. Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare early this week has as announced that the country is also anticipating 20,000 doses of Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine early next month from the People’s Republic of China. Meanwhile in a special address to the nation today, Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare said the rollout of the vaccination program will commence with a launch on Wednesday morning 24th of March 2021 at the central field hospital. Following the launching, Prime Minister Sogavare will lead the nation into the vaccination program and become the first to be vaccinated. “I'm very happy to lead our nation into this vaccination program after the launch on Wednesday morning,” Prime Minister Sogavare stated in his address today afternoon. The vaccination program is expected to be completed within one week and according to PM Sogavare, the vaccination teams and medical teams will then deploy to the western border to roll out the vaccination program along the western border. “Fellow citizens, it is crucial that we commence the COVID-19 vaccination rollout in Honiara so that our teams are seasoned by the time they deploy to the western border, where support facilities may be a little more limited. Prime Minister Sogavare has also advised the public not to be afraid to take the vaccination. “Every medicine we take has side effects. Some of us may develop some mild side effects, such as pain, or each illness at the injection site or a short period of feeling unwell. Such side effects are common in other injectable medicines we take when we are sick. “So far, the serious side effects reported in the media overseas are not directly linked to the COVID-19 vaccines. So I encourage you all to be ready to receive the vaccine when the vaccination teams are deployed to the western border,” Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare said. Ends/// ARTICLE AND PHOTOS SOURCE: ALEX DADAMU

column31: All Schedule Flights Suspended – NO other Incoming Flights BY ALEX DADAMU Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare in his address to the nation today said that the process of closing down borders for international flights that are being progressively implemented with a parcel lockdown of international flight services is currently in effect. PM Sogavare said Solomon Islands scheduled flights have been suspended and will only provide flight services as and when required to support emergency operations and the repatriation of the country’s citizens that and when to become necessary. “Only returning citizens are permitted to enter the Solomon Islands from the Brisbane – Honiara flight and upon arrival are placed in strict and compulsory quarantine facilities for 14 (Fourteen) days. PM Sogavare further revealed that the government is expecting a COVID-19 testing kit from China next week. “The Government is working with the People’s Republic of China (PRC) to establish our capacity to conduct testing locally as a strategy to speed up the process of establishing the status of a suspected case.” Sogavare said that with that capacity in place, the Government should be able to review the Brisbane – Honiara flight arrangement with the view to reduce it to essential flights only. “The government is taking this seriously because the only way that the virus can enter the country is through passenger arrivals by air.” The Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare in the meantime said that the Government appreciates that this measure is going to put the Solomon Islands under serious financial situations but the government is holding talks with the Airline's management to establish the effects of this measures on the Airlines and to agree on measures to keep the Airlines operating during this difficult times.

column36:
SOL2023 XVII PG Stadium: Largest, State of the Art Multipurpose Sporting Facility in the Pacific

BY JOHN HOUANIHAU

The 2023 Pacific Games National Stadium Project is the first major infrastructure project from the People's Republic of China to the people of Solomon Islands and also the largest state of the art multipurpose sports facility across the Pacific island region.
 
The People's Republic of China ambassador to SI His Excellency Li Ming made the assurance when delivering his key note speech at the event to mark the ground breaking of the PG2023 national stadium project recently.
 
"This project is the first major infrastructure project from China government to the people of Solomon Islands and it is also the largest state of the art multipurpose sports facility across the Pacific Island region.
 
“With our join efforts, in two years’ time where we are standing now will become the sport city of Solomon islands," Mr. Ming uttered while addressing SIG officials, NHA guest's, diplomatic corps and stakeholders at the KG6 PG2023 site during the ground breaking ceremony.
 
He said the project will not only contribute to the success of Pacific games in 2023 but also will become landmark of the Solomon Islands. It will help drive SI economy, bring new jobs, business opportunity in areas like tourism, infrastructure, Technology transfer, labor training and many more.
 
"Ladies and gentlemen as you may have noted the architect of this stadium has made very deep studies. Under the roof of the main stadium is designed in the shape of a traditional pot of SI. It shows the respect and appreciations to cultures and customs of SI and symbolize a friendship which carried with expectation and a bright future for the relations between China and SI," said Li Ming.
 
Mr. Ming revealed that as a genuine development partner and responsible large country, China’s assistance to Solomon Islands is under the free world of south to south cooperation (SSC) as china always honored its commitment and conditions.
 
“China will always be there as the genuine partner, friend on the path of development of Solomon Islands. Today’s ceremony marks another milestone, stepping forward to the Pacific games. Construction work starts and the successful stories will continue,’’ said Li Ming.
 
The national stadium consist of a total of seven sporting infrastructure that includes 10,000 seats, an aquatic center to host a 50 meter pool competition and 25 meter training pool, six tennis Court center, a full size training track and soccer/rugby field, a 90 meter by 50 Multipurpose hall, 5 aside hockey field, double space food court and office space building for games organizing committee.

column31: Opinion Editorial: Happy birthday, America! By U.S. Ambassador to Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, and Vanuatu Erin E. McKee This Sunday, July 4th, the United States celebrates 245 years of independence! After a tumultuous start to 2021, we have a new administration and a renewed dedication to restoring America’s role in the world. This is a critical moment for the United States and our global leadership. That leadership requires relentless focus on global crises like climate change and COVID-19. Higher temperatures, rising sea levels, and more intense storms affect everything from military readiness to human migration patterns to food security. As the COVID-19 pandemic has made abundantly clear, our health security is intertwined, and only as strong as our weakest link. Speaking of global linkages, while we celebrate America’s independence this weekend, it’s important to acknowledge we did not achieve that independence alone. We relied on our partners - partnerships between people, allies, and nations, were critical to our country’s birth and to our survival. And they still are. To achieve our national security priorities and deliver tangible results for the American people, as well as for our friends and allies, we must revitalize our international alliances and partnerships. Today, more than ever, America’s fate is inextricably linked to events beyond our shores. We confront a global pandemic, a crushing economic downturn, a crisis of racial justice, and a deepening climate emergency. We face a world of rising nationalism, receding democracy, growing rivalry with China, Russia, and other authoritarian states, and a technological revolution that is reshaping every aspect of our lives. Ours is a time of unprecedented challenges, but also unmatched opportunity. The United States will always promote partnership, not rivalry; prosperity, not dependence; security, not domination; opportunity, not threats. This is what President Biden means by “building back better.” And we all need to build back better to combat the threats we all face and to secure a better future for the planet. But what does that really mean for Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, and Vanuatu? First, we will strengthen global health. We have all seen the troubling spike in COVID-19 cases in Papua New Guinea and the government’s valiant efforts to address the issue. Defeating COVID-19 is paramount – as the President has said, this isn’t over until we stop the pandemic everywhere. But we must also ensure our partner nations are better equipped to prevent, prepare for, and respond to future global health crises so we can stop outbreaks before they turn into pandemics that put our safety and prosperity in danger. In PNG alone, we have contributed more than $6.9 million to fight COVID-19 through PPE donations, ventilators, and technical assistance. President Biden announced June 3 that PNG will also receive a significant vaccine donation from the United States – and we will announce more details on those vaccines soon. Second, just as important to our collective futures, we will accelerate the global response to the climate crisis by funding international climate programs, including the Green Climate Fund, to help developing countries implement climate adaptation and emissions mitigation programs. USAID’s Lukautim Graun project will reduce risks to Papua New Guinea’s rich biodiversity, which is among the most threatened in the world. At the national level, we will help promote transparent policies, including environmental safeguards, for effective stewardship of natural resources. At the site level, we will preserve biodiversity in priority locations by supporting local governments, civil society, and communities to mitigate risks and reduce key threats. The project is also part of the Women’s Global Development Prosperity Initiative (W-GDP). This component, in conjunction with our Women’s Business Resource Center run by The Center for International Private Enterprise, will equip women entrepreneurs with the skills to run businesses, particularly in natural resource-based industries. USAID’s Ready project is helping Pacific Island countries to become more environmentally secure and disaster resilient to protect the lives and livelihoods of their peoples. To date, USAID’s Ready has helped Pacific Islands countries, including PNG, Solomon Islands, and Vanuatu mobilize $26.7 million from various international funds. Ready has also helped prepare bankable project proposals valued at $147.8 million that have been submitted as final applications to the Global Environment Facility. Ready is further working on additional proposals that will target to access more than $280 million for programs in the Pacific Islands. But climate change is not the only challenge we face in the Pacific. Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, and Vanuatu straddle key shipping routes, manage lucrative fisheries, and protect the deep-sea resources of wide swathes of (truncated)

column31: EDITORIAL- A project worthy of our unwavering support. WORK on the multimillion dollars Pacific Games stadium official started yesterday. Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare, who was instrumental in bringing the Games here during the bidding process in 2016, was at hand yesterday to officiate in the ground-breaking ceremony. China is funding the project at a cost of around $2.5 billion. Constructor, China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC), has exactly two years to complete the stadium before the Games kick off in July 2023. This is a huge project of considerable proportion. It will occupy 26,000 square meters of land, spanning from the King George Sixth School to the lower Panatina campus in east Honiara. More than 110 Chinese engineers and other technical people are already here to work on the project. CCECC is expected to recruit up to 300 locals – both skilled and unskilled – to work on the project. The stadium project will include seven separate sporting infrastructures. They are: A 10,000-seat national stadium which includes 1,000 VIP seats, An Aquatic centre hosting a 50-meter competition pool, and a 25-meter training pool, A six-court tennis centre A full-sized training track and field with a full-sized soccer/ rugby field A 90 meters by 50 meters multi-purpose hall A 5-aside competition hockey field A double story food court and office space building for the Games Organising Committee When completed, the stadium is set to transform the eastern side of the capital. It therefore is only appropriate that it be called the Sports City. The project will allow us to own a modern sports stadium for the first time since independence. The benefits the facilities will bring to the nation – financially, socially and physically – will also be many. It’s a project that is worthy of our thanks and unwavering support. And so we thank China and its people for funding it. For it will help the country to finally host the region’s biggest sporting event – the Pacific Games.

column31: NCDs impede nation from achieving SDGs: PM By EDDIE OSIFELO NON Communicable Diseases (NCD) remains one of the challenges facing Solomon Islands in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). This was based on the Voluntary National Review Report on the implementation of Agenda 2030 Solomon Islands presented in July this year. Addressing the 75th session of United Nations General Assembly in New York, United States of America over the weekend online, Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare said seven out of 10 deaths in Solomon Islands are caused by non-communicable diseases. He said it remains the largest single cause of death in the country. “We are seeing increasing numbers of undernourished children and over nourished adults,” he said. In addition to this, Sogavare said the report also highlighted the vulnerability of our economy to external shocks and natural disasters. He said these coupled with the impacts of COVID-19 will continue to affect Solomon Islands for the foreseeable future. Sogavare said the report highlights some of the achievements the country made to date. He said despite the technological challenges, Solomon Islands continue to see an increase in number of children enrolled in the formal education system. “Secondly, we are proud to have established a National Financing Framework for Development which underpins the financing of the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals,” he said. Sogavare said Solomon Islands believes in the importance of Agenda 2030, the Istanbul Program of Action and the SAMOA Pathway in charting the course for sustainable development. “We have factored these into our national development strategy as the path forward for a sustainable future for our people. “I urge all development partners to remain committed to working with us to achieve our aim of sustainable development,” he said. Some of the development partners including, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, the Peoples Republic of China, the United Arab Emirates, Asian Development Bank, World Bank, United Nations agencies and in particular, the World Health Organization, and regional institutions.

column31: GG announces measures to respond to covid-19 By EDDIE OSIFELO GOVERNOR General Sir David Vunagi has reiterated measures stated by Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare to respond to the Coronavirus (covid-19). Sir David highlighted these measures when he declared the State of Public Emergency in Honiara yesterday for citizens to follow orders of the government in the next seven days. The following measures are: 1. Wash your hands regularly with soap or alcohol-based hand rub; 2. When you cough or sneeze, do it into your flexed elbow or use a tissue and dispose of the tissue immediately into a closed bin and wash your hands. 3. Do not cough/sneeze into your hands; 4. Clean your house, office or stores. Disinfect surfaces, tables or work desks; 5. Avoid crowded spaces and practice social distancing of 1.5m apart from the other person; 6. No handshakes; 7. Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth. The Novel Coronavirus (covid-19) first emerged in China in 2019. The spread of the Virus continued into 2020 and on January 30, 2020, the World Health Organisation (WHO) declared covid-19 a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (the PHEIC Declaration). The PHEIC Declaration triggered the Solomon Islands Government to introduce Regulations under the Immigration Act 2012 known as the Immigration (Amendment) Regulation 2020 which was intended to restrict entry of persons into Solomon Islands. Sir David said the spread of covid-19 was not contained and covid-19 continued to spread to other countries and this resulted in the increase of mortality rates caused by covid-19 worldwide. In light of the uncontrolled global spread outlined above, WHO on March 11, 2020 declared covid-19 “a pandemic”. Since that declaration, WHO has now confirmed 195 Countries have now contracted the infection including our close neighbours Australia, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea and Fiji. In addition to the above, New Caledonia, French Polynesia (Tahiti) and Guam have also recorded confirmed cases of covid-19. Currently, the statistics on covid-19 are 422,566 cases with 18,887 deaths worldwide. A Coronavirus Oversight Committee (the OSC) was established by Cabinet and was responsible for the monitoring and providing advice to the Solomon Islands Government. The OSC included amongst others, Permanent Secretaries from the Ministries of Health and Medical Services, Office of the Prime Minister & Cabinet and Ministry of Commerce, Immigration, Labour and Industries.

column31: For the folks at the Golden Age Home in Samabula, it was time to Tai Chi yesterday afternoon. World renowned Tai Chi master, Wu Dong, held a class for the elderly at the Home. Tai chi, short for T’ai chi ch’üan or Tàijí quán, is an internal Chinese martial art practiced for both its defence training, its health benefits and meditation. Mr Wu said in China, the elderly practiced it daily and this allowed many of them to stay fit.

𝐍𝐇𝐀 𝐂𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐟𝐢𝐞𝐬 𝐂𝐂𝐄𝐂𝐂 𝐅𝐢𝐫𝐞 𝐀𝐜𝐜𝐢𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭

Sol2023 NHA (National Hosting Authority) would like to clarify reports regarding the CCECC (China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation) workers dormitory fire accident. The workers accommodation that caught fire was not part of the Pacific Games National Stadium Project. 

Although CCECC is the major contractor for the Pacific Games National Stadium Project, they also have other projects in country. The building that caught fire was used by CCECC during the construction of the SINU Faculty of Education and Humanities Complex project. All workers on the National Stadium Project are accommodated within the National Stadium Project site. No casualty was reported in the recent fire incident.
 
As of now the cause of the fire is unknown and will have to wait for the fire department to complete their investigation. 

NHA Chairman and board sympathize with CCECC for their capital loss.

SOURCE: NHA MEDIA

column31: ISLANDSUN FLASHBACK JANUARY Crime Rates Worrying In his New Year’s message, Governor General Sir David Vunagi is concern about the rise of crimes like burglary, thieving, domestic violence and extra-marital affairs that grip our society. New Airbus Coming Soon Solomon Airlines will welcome a new Airbus in mid-February for the current Airbus A320. Manager Commercial, Collin Sigamanu said the new airbus is currently leased by New Zealand Airlines from a leasing company. Sigamanu said when the NZ Airlines lease ends, the airbus is expected to arrive in Honiara around mid-February. ANOTHER PETITION DISMISSED Minister of Mines and Energy Bradley Tovosia remains the Member of Parliament for East Guadalcanal after his petition case was dismissed yesterday. His case was dismissed on the grounds that the evidence does not meet the standard. Also, the petitioners’ witnesses lied. UNSEEN SELECTION Provincial Member for Choiseul Bay Ward 8 in North west Choiseul, Josiah Vanabachu has raised concern over unfair selection in the placement of forms one. Vanabachu raised this concern after he found out that their top grade six students were placed at Community High School despite being recommended for Senior High schools. He said it is unfair despite Ministry of Education and Human Resources phase out the grade six examinations which allow all grade six students to register in Year 7. WIFE STABBED TO DEATH A man believes to be in his 40s stabbed his wife to death with a knife at Putagita in Marovo Lagoon, Western Province yesterday. Police at Noro confirmed the unfortunate incident occurred at about 1pm when the victim was pronounced death after her husband stabbed her. Details surrounding the cause of the death are still sketchy as police officers have been deployed to investigate the matter. 1 ESCAPEE RECAPTURED Police have recaptured one of the three escapees, Willie Olo yesterday between 4am and 5am at LDA area, Betikama following assistance from the members of the community. Olo escaped the Correctional Facility on December 15, 2019 with Frank Firimolea and Dilo Faiga who are still on the run. He was brought to the Honiara Magistrate court by police for remand. DISASTER PLEDGE Ministry of Environment Climate Change Disaster Management and Meteorology is ready to expend $700,000 to $800,000 as part of relief assistance towards the bushfire in Australia. Permanent Secretary, Dr Melchior Mataki confirmed this during a meeting with officials from Prime Minister Office, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and External Trade, Royal Solomon Islands Police Force, Solomon Islands Development Trust, Ministry of Communication and Aviation and media in Honiara yesterday. Mataki said the ministry could afford this money because it has $2 million in its budget and the country is in the middle of Tropical cyclone season from November to April. Two new overseas missions open soon Solomon Islands will open residential missions in the two most populous nations on earth – China and India this year, a Staff Circular issued by the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and External Trade, Collin Beck, shows. At the same time, Mr Beck has foreshadowed reforms to appointments of honorary consuls and that the Ministry would start “recalling DC (diplomatic corps) number plates of vehicles driven by non-diplomats including those serving in the UN agencies. “A number of Missions will be opening up next year – Beijing and New Delhi, the 16 December 2019 Circular, addressed to All Heads of Missions and All Staff at Headquarters,” Mr Beck in the Circular said. MEASLE ADVISORY FOR SCHOLARS Ministry of Health and Medical Services has advised students who have not been vaccinated to receive vaccine against measles before leaving the country for studies. This advice was issued by Doctor Divinal Ogaoga director of Reproductive and Child in MHMS. Ogaoga said this is a must for students who will be going to institutions in countries that have reported with measles outbreak particularly in Fiji, Samoa and Papua New Guinea. FUGUI INVEST MORE ON EDUCATION International scholar and Minister for Education and Human Resources Development, John Moffat Fugui, has again pit his signature on education by increasing the number of scholarship awards for Solomon Islands students this year. “As long as Iam the Minister of Education, I will ensure that more students are given scholarship opportunities each year,” Fugui told Island Sun. Minister Fugui also revealed that law studies, which for some reason were left out from government scholarship for quite some time, would be reinstated. INDO KILLED IN WEST RENNEL An Indonesia, identified as Mr Alex Manullang, died shortly after being stabbed in West Rennell, Renbel Province, over the weekend. Late Manullang is an employee of Bintang Mining Solomon Islands (BMSI). He was a driver Late Manullang was on the West Rennell road heading west when stopped and attacked by two local boys (names withheld) on (truncated)

column31: Gold Ridge unaffected: AXF Group By EDDIE OSIFELO MINING operation at Gold Ridge on Central Guadalcanal remains unaffected despite the restructuring by one of its shareholders, AXF Group. Sydney Morning Herald reported on Saturday that court has appointed Malcolm Howell to replace former boss of AXF Group, Richard Minfeng Gu, to liquidate the business which collapsed under debts of more than AUD$200 million. Mr Gu refused to provide books, records or company accounts covering the past five years. This has meant that Howell did not have a complete picture of how the company used its funds. However, Director of Gold Ridge Mining Limited (GRLM), Richard Gu assured Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare and landowners yesterday that the current AXF Group restructuring has no impact on the Gold Ridge Project, because: 1. Firstly, Wanguo completed its acquisition of 70 percent stake in the Project in April this year. As such, Wanguo is now the majority shareholder and the main sponsor and operator responsible for the Project. AXF Group’s stake in the Project is reduced to around 20 percent and therefore has a much less significant Project role. 2. Secondly, AXF Group’s internal restructuring has no bearing on the Group’s mining investments (which include the Gold Ridge Project). AXF Group is undergoing group restructuring to consolidate its assets and liabilities so that it can better focus its business on mining investment. This involves liquidating some of the subsidiary companies that are not involved in mining investment within the Group. 3. Thirdly, the media reporting is not factually accurate. The Group has recently replaced its previously appointed liquidator for the Group restructuring purposes due to his ineffectiveness. “We understand the negative media reporting was initiated by the former liquidator following the Group’s decision to replace him. “We fully understand the importance of this Project to the Gold Ridge community and Solomon Islands as a whole and have taken on this Project with a great sense of responsibility and honour,” Gu said. “We remain fully committed to the Project and have detailed plans to recommence the Project for production as soon as possible,” he added. Auyeung Hencent & Day Lawyers firm has been instructed to act for MingFeng (Richard) Gu and companies of which Gu is the sole director including AXF Holdings Pty Ltd (AXF Holdings) ATF Australia Xiang Fu International Trust (AXF Trust), AXF Resources Pty Ltd and other companies. “We have been instructed that over the recent days there have been numerous media publications relating to Gu and his companies and in particular statements made the former liquidator of AXF Group Pty Ltd (AXF Group), Malcolm Kimbal Howell. “In December 2019 Gu transferred the trusteeship from AXF Group to the new trustee being AXF Holdings. From that date, AXF holdings became the group holding company of AXF Resources,” the firm said. Vincent Zhu, partner in the firm said recent media hype has surrounded the liquidation of the former trustee arising as a result of the removal of the former liquidator Mr Howell, who is unhappy about his replacement. “Mr Gu has plans to restructure and consolidate the debts in AXF Group but those plans were not able to be realised due to lack of corporation from former liquidator. “The new liquidator of AXF Group has indicated that he will assist in this debt restructuring and consolidation process and Mr Gu hopes to achieve this within the next 4 weeks,” he said. “AXF resources including the Gold Ridge mining project remain unaffected and business will continue as usual. “Mr Gu is committed to his continuing relationship and work with regards to stakeholders and assures them that the recent events have not real impacted to his commitments and his group’s ability to continue with the project,” he said. Zhu said it is with most regret that the events surrounding the liquidation of AXF Group has been misleadingly described by Mr Howell to the press and that the complaints and allegations made by Mr Howell have been effectively been resolved or dismissed by the court (see AXF Group Pty Ltd & Anor v AXF Holdings Pty Ltd & Ors [2020] VSC 375). According to Australia Broadcasting News, Hong Kong-listed Wanguo International Mining, has contracted state-owned China State Railway Group USD$825million to complete the works over several phases at Goldridge. The previous owner, Australian-listed St. Barbara, sold the mine for a nominal $100 to a landowner group in 2015, and that group went on to secure interest from Australian-based Chinese company AXF Resources, and then Wanguo. Island Sun understands Gold Ridge is venturing to export concentrate gold which is new in the country but not new in the mining industry. The company intends to put the ore on a platform and spray it with acid to produce gold bar before exporting, rather than exporting gold bar straight to overseas.

column31: PM denies signing MOU with Sam Group BY MIKE PUIA PRIME Minister Manasseh Sogavare has refuted reports claiming his government signed an agreement with China Sam Enterprise Group (CSEG) or Sam Group. Deputy Opposition Leader Peter Kenilorea during the question and answer session in Parliament on Thursday questioned an agreement Sam Group signed with the government. According to Kenilorea Jr, the agreement was mentioned by Sam Group in its website. He also question why Sam Group was part of the government delegation. But Prime Minister Sogavare in his respond said Sam Group was not part of his delegation to the Republic of China (PRC) and there were no agreement his delegation signed with this firm. Prime Minister Sogavare stated Sam Group representatives persuaded his delegation and later he had an informal meeting with Mr. Wong Yim Kau, the promoter of Sam Group. “No, we did not sign any agreement,” Prime Minister Sogavare said. He encouraged the people not to believe everything shared through the media. “There are so many rubbish posted in the media where people simply swallow them,” Prime Minister Sogavare said. He said this is worrying because once people continue to rely on the media for everything, over time the country will be influenced by what they read and saw in the media. Sam Group is probably the first Chinese company that welcomes the country’s diplomatic switch to China over Taiwan. Sam Group’s first move here was the signing of a Strategic Cooperation Agreement with the Central Islands provincial government. The signing of the agreement sparked a lot of interest and the Attorney General has declared the agreement illegal.

column36: The Vanuatu Government has refuted claims by Fairfax Media, that it has been approached by the government of China in the pretext of setting up a permanent military presence in Vanuatu. "The Vanuatu Government will fiercely oppose any attempt to build a military base in the country that is the happiest place in the world and which is a direct affront of its policy to promote peace and security in the region," Prime Minister Charlot Salwai stated this morning. He said Vanuatu greatly values its relationship with the government of China as an important development partner, friend and global leader for the benefit of our people in terms of employment and economic development.

column31: Facebook Ban is an Attack on Human Rights CIVIL Society Organisations in the Solomon Islands are utterly disappointed with the Cabinet’s decision to suspend the world’s biggest social networking site, Facebook. A statement from the Development Services Exchange (DSE) said at a time when Solomon has confirmed cases of Covid-19 and updates are shared through the platform, the government moves to shut it down is clearly an attack on human rights. the rights of people to express their concerns on issues affecting citizens of this country. It is indeed a sad time for the people of Solomon Islands. DSE understands the Solomon Islands Government is putting a temporary ban on the social media platform after the Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare and Communication and Civil Aviation Minister Peter Shanel Agovaka told Cabinet the forum had been grossly abused by the people, claiming that character assassination, defamation of character are issues of concerns. However, DSE also understands the government itself also uses Facebook widely to disseminate information on public health during the Covid-19 pandemic. DSE has recognized facebook to be a people’s-go-to platform to gather information, updates and share knowledge on national crisis. As the national CSO/NGO umbrella body in the Solomon Islands with a constituency of 65 members the platform is used to amplify their work on the ground and for sharing information. Solomon Islands will now join China, Iran, and North Korea as outlawing Facebook. Other countries have temporarily blocked it, including the island nation of Nauru which prohibited Facebook in 2015 but unblocked access in 2018. DSE expresses concerns that this move will have a huge impact on the work of civil society organisations’ who continue to inform, update the populace given the different sectors they represent from Health, environment and conservation, climate change, advocacy on development issues, youth and women, faith based organizations, media, Human rights advocates, child protection, social welfare, etc. Facebook has been a advocacy and lobbying platform for our members. “Community visitations, monitoring and feedbacks from the people on the grounds especially our provincial NGOs/CBOS, before, during and after any natural disasters, will no longer be shared on Facebook if the ban is going to eventuate.” The Solomon Islands is home to about 685,000 people. While the archipelago stretches across a vast area of ocean Facebook has played a bigger role during Covid-19. “DSE on behalf of its members is reiterating calls by the private sector, Transparency SI, young people and the public for the government to reconsider its decision to temporarily ban face-book. Banning face-book is not the solution, penalizing the law breakers for defamation of characters and character assassination as claimed by the government should be the immediate action and the law enforcers should be put to work to ensure such bad practices are dealt with accordingly” DSE also call on the government to be responsible in putting resources for a mass awareness on how to use social media responsibly if it is serious about the impacts -social media platforms like facebook is or will be having on the country. Ends/// DSE PRESS STATEMENT PHOTO CREDIT: DSE

column31: The former Ambassador of Vanuatu to China has filed a multi-million claim against the Government of Vanuatu last week, through his legal counsel, over outstanding money allegedly owed to him. Mr. Dennis Nai claims that “he has not been paid for over a year, has no assistance with repatriation, and is owed nearly Vt25 million in outstanding salary, severance and travel and also expenses he personally paid when the embassy had no funds”. After a year without pay and months of inaction by Foreign Affairs, it has left him and his family “destitute in China”, a statement issued to Daily Post stated.

column31: EDITORIAL- Road work must start unhindered FINAL documents for Phase II of the Kukum Highway Upgrading Project were signed in Honiara Monday this week. Japan is funding the multi-million dollar road project. It’s a continuation from phase I, which runs from the Honiara City Council round-about to Kukum Fisheries headquarters. Phase II extends from Kukum up to Henderson. Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Infrastructure Development Stephen Maesiola and Emelito Recalde of Kitano Construction signed the final documents on Monday. This process paves the way for work on the project to start next month, with its estimated completion on 30 June 2023. This second phase is as important as the first. It’s a project that Honiara desperately needs, especially as it prepares to host the 2023 Pacific Games. More so, Honiara’s businesses need better roads to boost their operations and maximise profits. Japanese engineers Kitano is bringing in for the construction are expected in the country on July 23, pending travel documents and approval from the COVID-19 Committee. We can hope the COVID-19 Committee will efficiently play their facilitative role to ensure the engineers are here on schedule. This project augers well with the 2023 Pacific Games Stadium Construction, funded by China, and the Honiara International Airport Upgrading Project, another Japanese Government project. These three major projects are expected to significantly transform the physical face of Honiara at their competition. With work about to start with the road project, betel nut vendors along the road must now dismantled their stalls and remove themselves. The project and those carrying it out must be allowed to do their job unhindered.

column31: OPMC holds dialogue on FPAS THE Office of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has held a consultation with key Government Ministries and Agencies on the proposed Foreign Policy Advisory Secretariat (FPAS). The meeting was facilitated by the Policy Implementation Monitoring and Evaluation Unit (PIMEU) within the OPMC. A Government statement said the meeting was purposely to brief key line Ministries on the establishment of FPAS, its framework, TORs and its proposed organization structure. It said FPAS was approved by Cabinet in October 2019 and it serves as the body responsible for coordinating, disseminating information and advancing the implementation of all relevant MOUs and Agreements signed between Solomon Islands and the People’s Republic of China (PRC). “It is also mandated to facilitate meetings under the directive of Cabinet, as well as a think tank body in carrying out research and analysis on the global and regional politics, economics and security developments affecting Solomon Islands,” it said. The statement said FPAS will be the vehicle used by the DCGA Government in driving its policies with PRC. Meanwhile, the National Consultant, Fundamental Reform Sector Mr Bernard Bata’anisia said further consultations will be made with other line Ministries and key stakeholders on the proposed work of FPAS and its implementation process. “Under the guidance of Cabinet, FPAS will liaise closely with all key government ministries, provincial governments, State Owned Enterprises, and stakeholders responsible for the implementation of the relevant MOUs and government development polices,” he said. Those that attended the consultations included the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Police, National Security & Correctional Services Ms Karen Galokale, other senior government officials from the ministries of Foreign Affairs and External Trade, National Planning and Development Cooperation, Commerce Industries, Labour and Immigration, Central Bank of Solomon Islands, Royal Solomon Islands Police Force and the PIMEU. --OPMC PRESS

column31: Stimulus package to address impact of covid-19 By EDDIE OSIFELO SOLOMON Islands faces an uncertain period, not only as it prepares for covid-19 but as it deals with the actions taken by neighbours and key trading partners as they attempt to contain the pandemic in their respective countries. This was revealed in the Magazine released by Solomon Islands Government on Economic Stimulus Package during the launching at Heritage Park on Monday 4th May. It said the country’s key trading partners in Asia (China, Hong Kong, Korea, Singapore and Japan) are all affected by the pandemic. This is seriously disrupting the supply chain for consumption and investment imports into the country. The impact on trade, commodity prices and volumes, restrictions on international travel and cancellation of flights affecting tourism and movement of people, disruptions to shipping are the channels for transmitting shocks to the Solomon Islands economy. When launching the Stimulus Package, Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare said the Covid 19 pandemic is unleashing havoc and generating a lot of uncertainty around the world, including Solomon Islands that requires the government to take a pragmatic and progress approach towards stabilizing the domestic economy while also safeguarding our population from the pandemic. Sogavare said preliminary predictions from Central Bank of Solomon Islands (CBSI) and the Ministry of Finance indicate that Covid-19 is ‘likely to have considerable negative impact on the Solomon Islands economy’. He said the country is heading towards recession in the second half of 2020 with a significant decline in GDP growth is expected to decline further to [-4.9] percent in 2020 as a result of reduction in logging and fisheries exports; a contraction in tourism, as well as the negative impact of containment measures that include suspension of all international flights, entry restrictions of non-citizens and strict mandatory quarantine for all returning passengers “The forestry sector expects an 11% decline in log output, 9% fall in foreign exchange receipts and a 6% drop in government revenue from duties on logs. “With nearly half of the Solomon Islands workforce thought to be directly or indirectly associated with the logging sector, the economic impacts will reverberate across all parts of the country,” he said. Sogavare said the tourism sector is also being hit hard. He said the tourism operators in Honiara predict a 10% occupancy rate for April and the predictions for May and beyond are expected to be lower. “This all points to a dire prospect for the national economy through business closures, loss of jobs, pressure on government revenues, and a serious contraction in aggregate demand,” he said. Sogavare said in their efforts to dampen the impact of the pandemic, especially the immediate impacts, his Government has decided to provide a first round Economic Stimulus Package of SBD309 million or approximately USD$38 million, to ease the fallout of the pandemic on businesses and the general population and to keep the economy afloat.

column31: The Lae District Court today adjourned the trial of the four Chinese men who entered the country illegally, to Friday. The men were caught in Lae for breaching Immigration Laws. A translator will be available during the trial because the four men cannot speak English and Tok Pisin. These men originate from Fujian Province in China. They were employed with the Sany Limited Company, a Chinese-owned factory in Lae, that produces Lipo Juice and purified water. In July, the Lae Police through the assistance of PNG Immigration in Lae, arrested these men on four separate charges, for illegally entering the country. They were charged for entry into the country without a valid permit or visa, false information on their entry permit and were in possession of an entry permit without lawful authority. Their trial has been adjourned to Friday, this week. The men were released on bail at K700 each two months ago, after they were remanded at Buimo Jail for two nights.

column36:
IN PICTURES: Chinese Embassy Celebrates 2021 International Women’s Day in Honiara 
                                                                          
BY JOY OFASIA

THE Chinese embassy held a small event to mark the 2021 International Women’s Day with Chinese and Solomon Islands women at the Iron Bottom Sound Hotel Dynasty Restaurant yesterday.

During the official program, H.E. Ambassador Li Ming in his speech shared his sincere wishes to all women and girls in the Solomon Islands and China.

“I would like to wish all women and girls good health, forever young and to fulfill our common dreams of gender equality and women empowerment,” H.E Ambassador Li Ming said.

He said we should pay high tribute to women in the Solomon Islands and China who are working hard for their families for jobs and better lives for the country and more especially our women who are working as front liners to fight the pandemic of COVID-19.

During the short event, there were also remarks made by women leaders including Madam Emmy Sogavare and Honorable MP Freda Rotutafi Rangirei. They wished all women throughout the country on the celebration of this year's annual event.

After the official program, there was a demonstration on how to make Chinese dumplings, a Chinese traditional food. The women guests watched and tried out how to make their dumplings.

column31: PRC funds for covid-19 is with CBSI: Sogavare BY BARNABAS MANEBONA PRIME Minister Manasseh Sogavare said the ‘1.2 Million dollars’ provided by People’s Republic of China (PRC) to support health efforts against Coronavirus (Covid-19) is with the Central Bank of Solomon Islands (CBSI). The Prime Minister made this assurance after several media reports last week speculated that the 1.2 Million Solomon dollars provided by PRC to support health efforts against Covid-19 has already been used for the Economic Stimulus Package (ESP). Mr Sogavare during his first 2021 ‘Nationwide Address’ yesterday said the funds are with CBSI under Solomon Islands Government Covid-19 account. “Good people of Solomon Islands, last week, several media reports speculated that the 1.2 million Solomon Dollars provided by the People’s Republic of China to support health efforts against COVID-19 has already been used for the Economic Stimulus Package. “Let me assure the public that the funds are with the Central Bank of Solomon Islands under Solomon Islands Government COVID-19 account. Relevant documents are being drawn up now to transfer the funds to the Ministry of Health’s Development Partner account to commence its utilization. “The funds had already been earmarked for refurbishment and repurposing of the NRH’s TB ward into a COVID-19 isolation ward which will have 16 self-contained rooms. “Part of the funds will also be used to strengthen the ministry’s capacity and capabilities to swiftly detect, and effectively and safely contain and eliminate the virus as agreed with the donor partner,” said Sogavare.

column31: COVID-19 testing for 104 arrivals from China including one additional test from an alleged breach of quarantine protocol returned negative. THE Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS) would like to inform that the first COVID-19 test for all 104 passengers who arrived last week on the China-Honiara flight all returned negative. Additional test conducted by MHMS on the person alleged to have breached quarantine protocols also returned negative. Despite the negative results generated from the test, the individual is now being held in quarantine for further assessment and will follow through the quarantine and testing protocols. Due to the nature of the breach NHEOC surveillance team immediately commenced the investigations which are still continuing. With this, the Ministry of Health would like to strongly advise the general public that the Quarantine Stations are restricted areas and the public is not allowed to enter nor to have any direct contact with any occupant of any Quarantine Station. Any contact is a breach of the Emergency Powers (COVID-19) (No.3) Regulations 2020. Quarantining of arrivals from overseas is established strictly to prevent any contact with those outside of the quarantine stations so that any possible entry of COVID-19 would not lead to spread and community transmission. As per the Quarantine protocols, no item can be sent outside from quarantine station without prior approval from the relevant authorities. Breach of quarantine regulations is not only illegal but poses health risk to our own children, families, communities and the country as a whole. That said, it is of utmost importance that each one of us must cooperate and work together to ensure that our quarantine regulations are respected and fully adhered to in order for the country to remain free from COVID-19. Ends/// Source: MHMS Press Release

column31: All Arrivals from China Last Night Cleared to Quarantine Stations FOLLOWING thorough health screening of all arrivals from the China-Honiara flight on September 02, the Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS), National Health Emergency Operations staff on sight have cleared all 104 passengers to their designated quarantine stations. All the incoming travelers were assessed for the symptoms of COVID-19, temperature check upon arrival and detailed history on testing including documentary proof of having tested for COVID-19 as per the requirements put by the Solomon Islands Government. Health operations at the airport went smoothly and according to the standard operating procedures. Though all arrivals were tested negative for COVID-19 at least twice prior to boarding the flight from China, they are still subjected to mandatory quarantine and health assessment and testing during quarantine as per existing requirements governing entry into Solomon Islands. The usual daily health monitoring for any signs and symptoms of COVID-19 will commence as of today up until the last day of quarantine. Should there be any persons in the quarantine stations showing signs and symptoms of COVID-19, the, person will be examined by a physician at the NRH and tested for COVID-19. Depending on the test report and based on the condition of the quarantined person, appropriate medical management will be carried out. The NHEOC is reviewing the procedures again today and in the coming days will conduct short training rehearsal to enhanced readiness of the response Teams. We are thankful to our partners for successful integrated operations between MHMS, Camp management, Customs, Immigration, Biosecurity, and Civil Aviation among others and thankful to the patience and approach taken by the incoming travelers to ensure successful operations to keep Solomon Islands safe. Ends/// Source: MHMS Press Release

column31: 13072019Sports-Pacific Games-Agari down but not out PARA TABLE TENNIS BY SIMON KESLEP IN SAMOA TEAM PNG Para table tennis player Haoda Agari lost in the gold medal playoffs but still not out. Agari lost to Avelino Monteiro (New Caledonia) earlier this afternoon at Harvest Centre indoor complex in Samoa. He won silver medal losing three sets (11-8,11-9,11-7) to his New Caledonia rival of 2015 Pacific Games. Despite losing he was still grateful to his coach Robert Loi who spend his (Loi) time training him for four months while other PNG table tennis able players were out training in China prior to travelling to Samoa. "I'm not retiring as yet, I will still play," said Agari. "I should have done better." Agari was also congratulated for his efforts by fellow Team PNG table tennis squad members. Coaching in absent of Robert Loi was Agari's nephew Geoffrey Loi. "My advice to him was not to give up. Fight till the war is over," said young Geoffrey Loi who was mentoring 50 year old Agari from the table side. Geoffrey said he was advising Agari to capitalise on his opponentvs weaknesses and also minimising of long service. This achievement would see Agari claiming his second silver medal at the Pacific Games level.

column31: Green Party Solomon Islands Launches Convention Aiming 2024 Elections
column35: Environment Media Solomon Islands
column36:
IN PICTURES: Green Party Solomon Islands Launches Convention Aiming 2024 Elections

BY MIKE TUA

THE Green Party Solomon Islands launched its election campaign for the 2024 National General Elections over the weekend. 

The two days convention was held on 22 and 23 May at the Anglican’s St Alban Church compound, Rifle Range, and Solomon Islands Development Trust Conference room, China Town.

68 local participants including key guest speakers, Solomon Islands environmental activist, Lawrence Makili and the Registrar of Political Party's Commission, Jasper Anisi were also present at the convention and they provided insights to attendees on how they prepare ahead for the 2024 National General Elections.

The Green Party Solomon Islands (GPSI) says the convention is aimed for the 2024 upcoming National General Elections, pledging interested individuals to become members of the Party.

The slogan of the convention – ‘Challenges the Green Philosophy to face in today’s Political Environment’ aims to campaign on delivering a greater change for the future of Solomon Islands and also a detailed action that is needed to address ‘environmental issues’.

The convention was collaboratively organized by the Interim President of the GPSI, Ernest Kolly with the support of two volunteers, Eddie Pae and Ruddy Oti (who are members of the Party).

PICTURES CREDIT: Eddie Pae - Green Party Solomon Islands

column31: Solomon Airlines Continues to Offer Limited Passenger Seats On February Cargo Flights FOLLOWING special approvals by the Solomon Islands and Australian Governments, Solomon Airlines is continuing to offer a limited number of passenger seats for booking on the airline’s regular Friday cargo flights between Brisbane and Honiara. Seats on the Airbus A320 international flights are available to those who meet special conditions and each passenger must have travel approval granted by the Solomon Islands Prime Minister’s Office. Passengers who meet all eligibility conditions will be able to travel on flights scheduled to operate throughout the next month. Seating allocation on the aircraft will be limited in line with available capacity at Government approved quarantine accommodation. FLIGHTS FROM BRISBANE TO HONIARA – 5, 12, 19 AND 26 FEBRUARY Flight IE701 will depart Brisbane at 10.00am and arrive in Honiara at 2:15pm. Spaces on services from Brisbane to Honiara will be limited to those who have spent the 28 days prior to intended departure, in a ‘low-risk country’ as classified by the Solomon Islands Government. Those countries currently include Australia, New Zealand, China (excluding Hong Kong and Taiwan), and South Pacific countries (excluding Papua New Guinea and French Polynesia). Each passenger will be required to have two negative COVID-19 PCR test results, one between 12 and 14 days prior to departure and a final test taken 72 hours prior to departure. All passengers will be responsible for self-funding their required quarantine in approved accommodation in Honiara. FLIGHTS FROM HONIARA TO BRISBANE – 5, 8 AND 12 FEBRUARY On 5 and 12 February, Flight IE700 will depart Honiara at 3.15pm, arriving in Brisbane at 5.30pm. On 8 February, Flight IE700 will depart Honiara at 9.00am, arriving in Brisbane 11.15am. Passengers on these flights must have the right of entry to Australia or be transitting onward to other international destinations. Facemasks must be worn in all airports and for the full duration of the flight. Bookings can be made via phone or email with Solomon Airlines Sales Offices in Point Cruz (+677 20152 or sales@flysolomons.com.sb) or Brisbane (+61 7 3860 5883 or reservations@flysolomons.com). All Solomon Airlines flights comply fully with the COVID-19 regulations of the relevant countries. Solomon Airlines crew onboard the airline’s A320 aircraft wear facemasks and gloves for the duration of service and catering is minimal to reduce contact between passengers and crew. Ends/// Source: Solomon Airlines

column31: China's MBHS grant by Joseph R Kamali, Namaka, Nadi Fiji Sun’s edition on Saturday June 2nd, 2018, references a grant of $8 million from the Chinese government towards the redevelopment of the Marist Brother’s High School (MBHS) ground. We give our sincere gratitude to the Government and the People’s Republic of China through our ambassador, together with the Prime Minister, Voreqe Bainimarama for the generous donation. The Chinese ambassador linked the grant to China’s One Belt One Road programme and the Marist gift is a China Belt Road Initiative. Funded by the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), China’s development outlay from Asia to Africa will be US$1 trillion (FJ$2.08tr) by 2020. A new chapter of economic development and prosperity greets developing nations on a scale not fully understood by many today. Neighbours, Australia and New Zealand, are among the first to join the AIIB. As students of MBHS in the early 1950s, the school, through that ground, developed great teams in athletics, rugby, soccer and cricket. Athletic high performers like Sakiasi Nagani Vavulagi, Joe Tokuna, Karen Mafatolu, Dan Veitata, Jone Makasiale, John Vavala and many scores of athletes pounded the turf of the ground with training sessions and practices. Holistic education was the theme. Academic performance, with time, was matched by sporting activities and record results. A multiracial school with highest order at the time. The Chinese Government at the Beijing Olympics spent US$62 billion (FJ$128.74bn) on their Olympic complexes. Their performance at the World Olympics speaks for itself. Fiji looks forward to a long and happy relationship with the Chinese Government. As for the Prime Minister, words of gratitude are not enough.

column36:
WE WILL DELIVER: CCECC
Construction to Commence On 7 Sol2023 Pacific Games Projects

BY ALEX DADAMU

Today marks a significant day on the road to SOL2023 Pacific Games, as a ground-breaking ceremony is hosted for construction to commence on the KGVI East and KGVI West sporting facilities.

Speaking during the ceremony today, Prime Minister, Manasseh Sogavare urged China Civil Engineering Construction Company (CCECC) to deliver the projects within the agreed 24 months projection.

CCECC Country Manager Mr. Huang Pengfei, in a very short response to the PM said they will deliver the projects on schedule and with the required quality.

According to a National Hosting Authority (NHA) statement today, Mr. Pengfei, stated that CCECC are expecting the KGVI East running track and football field to be completed by the end of this year.

Mr. Pengfei further stated that the officially handing over of all the sporting facilities and complex to the Solomon Islands Government is expected to be done by May 2023 before the Pacific Games opening ceremony.

In the meantime, CCECC are looking to employ local workers in the field of steel bar works, bricklaying, carpenters, paint workers and unskilled construction workers. As the projects expand, CCECC are expected to employ up to 300 local workers.

Sol2023 XVII Pacific Games ground-breaking event today was attended by the Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare and Deputy Prime Minister Manasseh Maelanga along with Members of the Parliament, various members of the Diplomatic corps and other stakeholders.

Photos of the Ground-Breaking Event today 5 May, 2021. (All Photos by Alex Dadamu)

column31: Study visit to copyright related institutions in South Korea SOLOMON Islands participated in the Study Visit to Copyright Related Institutions in Seoul, South Korea. The programme was held from November 18-22, 2019. The country was represented by Mrs Knowrell Rove, Principal Data Officer, of the Registrar Generals Office, Ministry of Justice and Legal Affairs. It was organised by the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO), in cooperation with the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism (MCST) of the Government of the Republic of Korea, and with the assistance of the Korea Copyright Commission (KCC), and the Korea Copyright Protection Agency (KCOPA). The objectives of the study visit are to share the Korean experience and knowledge in the development of national copyright regime and the active use of the copyright system contributing to the development of creative industries and the administration of copyright and related rights as well as to promote WIPO-administered treaties in the field of copyright and related rights. The Study Visit was arranged to include various aspects of the copyright system and address issues identified as of key interest and concern. The programme covered presentations on various topics related to copyright including: - Copyright System in Support of Creative Industries and Cultural Prosperity - The Creative Industries of the Republic of Korea – Key Milestones - The Legal Framework Governing the Korean Copyright System and Current Issues - The Roles and Functions of the Korea Copyright Commission (KCC) - Recent Developments of National Copyright System and its Future Perspectives - The International Framework of Copyright and Related Rights and the Work of WIPO - Copyright Registration and Documentation System in the Republic of Korea - Collective Management System of Copyright and Related Rights and Collective Management Operational Framework in Republic of Korea - Copyright Infringement Online: Challenges and Opportunities for Effective Enforcement - Introduction to Integrated Control and Observation Platform - Anti-piracy Activities Undertaken by Korea Copyright Protection Agency (KCOPA) - Public-Private Cooperation Framework for the Effective Overseas Protection of Copyright - Copyright Dispute Settlement in Republic of Korea - Building Respect for Copyright: Education and Awareness Programs - The Economic Contribution of Copyright-Based Industries in Republic of Korea - Prospects for Future Development of National Copyright Regimes of Participating Countries Participants and Moderators also held group discussions on the priorities, challenges and importance of updating National Copyright Frameworks and Enhancing Institutional Capacity. Participants also attended the ‘Seoul Copyright Forum 2019’ held at the JW Marriot Hotel on November 20, 2019. The theme of the Forum is ‘Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Copyright’. Mrs Knowrell Rove also had the opportunity to present Solomon Islands Country Report on the topic: ‘Recent Developments of National Copyright System and its Future Perspectives’ at the Study Visit. Participants in the Study Visit came from Argentina, Botswana, China, Guatemala, Honduras, India, Kazakhstan, Kenya, Kiribati, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Nigeria, Peru, Solomon Islands, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Tuvalu, Uruguay, Uzbekistan, Vanuatu and Zimbabwe. International Speakers, Copyright Experts and WIPO Officials also attended the programme. - RGO Media

column31: Voices from Tuvalu #COVID19
column35: Tuvaluan From Within
column36:
"I’m currently the Acting Chief of Public Health for Princess Margaret Hospital in Funafuti. I’ve been doing this since October 2019. We heard about coronavirus first from social media, and then we were formally notified by the WHO in January 2020 about the possible ongoing global outbreak. At that time, it was only China, and then they started to investigate the borders. That’s when we started to pick up. So, our first meeting for the Health Taskforce was held in that same week. This Taskforce includes all of the agents for the vessels. The fishing vessels, the cargo, and the petrol boats. And even the Airport and Immigration were also involved as well as Customs, Agriculture, and all the Foreign Affairs Officers at the Airport. We all met together with our technical people here in the hospital. So, we met up and had to come up with our plan on how we could respond or prepare in terms of coronavirus.

We have 2 objectives. We want to strengthen the public-health coronavirus response system. That’s more the public-health side. That includes how we prepare and secure our ports: the seaport and the airport. We also have to get more stakeholders including businesses and all the other Government departments and community leaders involved in the Health Taskforce. We meet every week, and we are constantly updating our activity plan. We also have to cover risk communication. We have to inform the public and raise awareness through radio and TV and any source we can use to reach the public. Also, under public-health coverage, we have to participate in community engagement. We have to include the media, church leaders, and all of the relevant people. We’ve been successful in most of these public-health tasks.

Aside from our Health Taskforce, we also have a National Taskforce. It includes the same members as the Health Taskforce, but it also consists of the Cabinet and all of the Secretaries in all of the Departments. That Taskforce has met twice now. They are the ones making most of the decisions. Whatever the National Taskforce is trying to plan, the Health Taskforce implements. We brief the entire Government with whatever we’ve planned so far and where we are so far and update them on coronavirus. Because there’s lots of social media news and false news. We are the ones providing reliable sources of information. We’ve been working with the Ministry of Justice, Communication and Foreign Affairs, and what we do involves the Police. Ultimately, our first goal is not to let the coronavirus set foot in Tuvalu. We have lots of travel restrictions in place, and anyone who tries to come to Tuvalu from a high-risk country has to spend 14 days in a non-high-risk country. Even our Ministers, our Minister of Health and our Secretary, went to Fiji to talk with the Minister of Health in Fiji and Fiji Airways to strengthen the enforcement of our regulations so that everyone respects the 14-day rule.” Dr. Christine Lifuka

column36:
Tourism Solomons ‘very much still here’ at Virtual PATA MART 2021

THE Solomon Islands’ international visitation may currently be at a standstill but this has not stopped Tourism Solomons and local tourism partners from reaching out ‘virtually’  to remind the world “we are very much still  here.”

The tourism team – including Solomon Airlines, Bilikiki Cruises, Dive Munda, Travel Solomons, and Uepi Island Resort – is ‘attending’ the Pacific Asia Travel Association’s ‘Virtual PATA MART 2021’ one of the world’s most high-profile travel industry events, which, being beamed from China,  started on 02 September and attracts hundreds of participants.

Read more here: https://tourism.islesmedia.net/tourism-solomons-very-much-still-here-at-virtual-pata-mart-2021/

Photo Caption: Tourism Solomons senior marketing officer, Nelson Manepura ‘meeting’ PATA Mart 2021 participants from the Tourism Solomons boardroom. Photo Supplied.

column31: People of Hela Province today (March 15) witnessed two important projects that is hoped to improve the living standard and benefit communities. Tari airport will be upgraded at the cost of K55 million. The upgrade will see a two-story terminal, new runway, and fencing. Minister for Civil Aviation Alfred Manase, Hela Governor Phillip Undialu, and China Civil Engineering Company did the groundbreaking which signifies groundwork to commence. The second project is the construction of electricity transmission and substation at Wabia. The electricity project is a partnership between PNG Power and Kumul Petroleum Holdings at the cost of over K67 million.
